story:
Short Summary

Humanitarian Aid Express is a volunteer organization (NGO) who transports goods and cargo as Humanitarian Aid to rural and remote areas of Ukraine and other Eastern European countries. We are situated on the west coast of Norway and travel the distance between the two countries two to three times every year.

We mainly focus on Ukraine, the township of Malyn, near Korosten, and the surrounding villages. However we frequently cooperate with both Lions Clubs, Salvation Army and Amadia International, so we are headed where they all need there aid brought to.

Transport is arranged with an old 1995 model, volvo b10m- cargo (Half bus/half truck). We rent a trailer for each run, to maximize volume of cargo.


What We Need

We need to purchase our own trailer for this task. The one we rent is too small and costs us money in rental fees every time we run with it.
  • New/Used trailer is upwards of Euro 25.000,- 
  • We can carry 3 extra TONS of cargo, equal to 235 - 250 extra boxes/bags of clothes. This amount would potentially keep children from two to five extra villages warm through winter.
  • Through owning our own trailer we save Euro 1000,- pr. run, making us able to spend more on our Local Humanitarian Aid projects in the township if Malyn and surroundings, Zhytomyr region of Ukraine.

An example of trailer we wish, and approximate price here: Trailer For Sale

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Visit our campaign herecregularly, even withiut contributing you are helping by generating traffic.
  • Write comments in campaign.
  • Please spread this to those you feel can and will help (Please do not spam).
  •  Visit our webpage www.humanitar.no (Norwegian only)  for further information and documentation. 
  • For questions, please contact Ted Walter Sjøen

story:
My name is Cricket Ellis and I am a movie producer, director, writer and actor.  I have worn many hats for many projects.   I’ve been in “the business” of movies since 2004. It all started with wanting to make movies that were good, relatable and entertaining.  As I have gotten older, I realize that with making movies, you can also bring awareness where there wasn’t before.  Shedding light on the darkness. 

I am raising funds for my feature film Conditional Love. It is the story of a young girl who was raised by her father in a strict religious home and thrown out when her father learns she is a lesbian. This teenage girl has lived a very sheltered life and does not know how to survive life on the streets. She finds herself in some of the worse living situations and living conditions imaginable.

Although this story is fictitious, circumstances of what can happen when a teenager tells their parent or guardian they are gay is real; 40% of all teenagers living on the streets are LGBT. These kids have been punished for expressing who they are and forced into a life of darkness. Many of these kids end up in prostitution, on drugs, abused or even dead. Some teens are so afraid to tell their loved ones or peers they are gay the consider suicide, or they will cut themselves or turn to drugs. They fear being humiliated in social media or bullied and beat up at school. With this film I intend to shed light on this very sad topic by taking you on a journey of one young lady’s story. I will show you what can happen when a teenager is not allowed to be who they truly are and the damage that bullying can do, even when it’s not meant to do significant harm. This story is an important lesson in life, love and being the person you were meant to be. 

There are a few organizations that are trying to help. The Diane Conklin Foundation is reaching out all children gay, straight or questioning and giving them a chance to become stable, functional, and contributing members of the community. But we need to do more. I hope people walk away from this film and feel inspired to get involved with organizations like the Diane Conklin Foundation because no child should feel unloved or be thrown out like trash. 

“Once you learn to accept and love them for who they are, you subconsciously learn to love yourself unconditionally” -Yvonne Pierre-

What We Need:

We are working to raise $60,000 USD to make this film. This money will go to productions cost such as renting lighting, cameras, crew, actors and feeding everyone. Not to mention post-production which includes editing, scoring, color correcting and sound editing. It will also go toward film festivals, traveling accommodations and marketing. 

Please check out the cool perks we are offering to the right of your screen. 

The Impact:

Unfortunately many kids living on the streets seem to be forgotten. People pass by them as if they were invisible or they see them and assume they must be thugs or prostitutes strung out on drugs, never giving a thought to why or how they ended up on the streets.

We want to open people’s eyes with this film. We want to stop the hate crimes, the bullying, the loss of young life. We want parents to watch this film and consider what can happen to their children if you don’t listen to who they are telling you they are. We want more warriors fighting for these kids giving them hope, and letting them know they don’t have to be afraid of being gay because who they are is beautiful in God’s eyes no matter what their sexual orientation.

Pre-Production:

Once this campaign starts off, we want to start casting so hurry and donate so we can get this started!! 

We need your help to make a change. Please join our campaign. Any size donation can get us one step closer to our goal. Your help is greatly appreciated. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Please tell everyone you know about our campaign. Please share it on your social media pages, like Facebook, Twitter, Instragram, etc… Like us on Facebook at conditionallovethemovie. We thank you for your support!!!

story:
Production costs! :) They are limited, but are still there. We will need money to feed the staff, props, wardrobe, pay for shooting locations, IMDB pro, etc.

Our actors and crew are all donating their time for the pilot. Everyone loves the idea behind the story, and so many have been willing to come aboard with no promise of money.

Any money left over from the first episode will go towards the 2nd one!

story:
Project Verso

I'm David, and I created Project Verso. I believe the future of project management will allow us to share project information on a web page, and an incorporated professional network will allow us to join multiple project teams to view all of the information in one place. This is what I'm creating with Project Verso. 

Project Verso is a construction project professional network. The app is for construction project management. I have been a project manager working with subcontractors for 15 years. I am also working toward my MBA in Project Management. Straight A student, I'm no dummy. I taught myself to build a web site, and then I created Project Verso.

  • The web site is live now at http://projectverso.com
  • This is my dream, to have my own business, and this project will get my business started.
  • This project will allow us to create iPhone and Android apps to complement the existing web-app

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We need $75,000 to get the business started and get us through the next 4-5 months.
  • $10,000 office costs, $15,000 phone app development, $15,000 web-site development, $20,000 sales & marketing, $15,000 president salary (I need to eat & want to leave my current job to focus on the business)
  • If we don't reach the entire goal, the money that is raised will go into the phone apps and web-development. This is our most critical project for now. 

The Impact

Your contribution will help us get Project Verso off the ground! My vision is to create a platform where people create free accounts and then can be added to project teams to do their work, like a friend request.

  • As Project Verso grows, contractors, subcontractors, engineers, architects, and designers can all join the social network and be invited to projects
  • Imagine logging into Facebook to do your job! All of the project information is on the site, on your phones, iPads and you're networking with coworkers too!
  • We also offer project organization as a services P.O.A.A.S! We are the first PM web-app to offer this service. If my plans take off it could change the way people do business in this industry for the better!

Risks & Challenges

The risk is that there are dozens of other project management apps out there to compete with. Project Verso meets this challenge head on by providing a comprehensive system for sharing files, messaging, planning and also adds in the professional network.

  • My experience as a project manager has allowed me to create a system that is efficient and effective and I believe Project Verso is the best tool out there!
  • It will take some convincing to get people to change from current practices and adapting to our new system. But, I am CONFIDENT it WILL catch on!!
  • Soon, everybody in the industry will be joining and jumping to project teams like sending a friend request. This is my vision.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please go to http://projectverso.com and create a free professional network account! It's free and we need users! We are in BETA mode, but things will get much better from here! You can create an account and add up to 5 users on your team for free.
  • And PLEASE use Indiegogo's SHARE TOOLS to help spread the word!!

story:
Welcome to your summer sandwich party. Let's eat!

Hey! Are you hungry? We thought so... Earlier this year, we had an idea. What if we connected people who care about LGBT (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender) equality across all 50 states, through a twist on the classic BLT (bacon, lettuce, tomato) sandwich? Veg friendly options, of course.


To launch our idea, we created a $150,000 crowdfunding campaign for BLgT USA - America's First 50 State Food Tour For Equality. Why? Because policy action needs a dinner date to change hearts and minds. Earlier this year, from MLK Jr. Day thru Presidents Day 2015, 660 people made the BLgT dream real. People from all over the country, and from as far away as Brazil, England, and Sweden chipped in. By the people, for the people!


PHOTO:  BLgT USA is amplifying organizations like The Attic Youth Center in Philadelphia, PA. The Attic provides career services, family counseling, and hot meals to youth - many of them in between housing, because they have been kicked out of their homes when they come out. Our partnership model provides visibility and funding for organizations like The Attic across the entire country.  PHOTO: Supporters including Edie Windsor (DOMA Plaintiff), Top Chef Contestant Ash Fulk (Hill Country BBQ), Kris Perry + Sandy Stier (Prop 8 Plaintiffs), and Debra Messing (Actress) kicked in BLgT love from the beginning. 

What We Need + What You Get. Yum. 

"Where did the first $150,000 go?" Car Rental, Creative - Design / Website / Production, Fees/Payments Returned, Gas, Event Supplies, Housing, Insurance, Larger/Private Event Costs, Legal, Meals, Postage, Reward Expenses, Stipends

"Where is this $50,000 going?" Event Supplies, Fees, Housing, Meals, Postage, Reward Expenses, Stipends

We need $50,000 to make the second half of the 50 state tour happen.


BLgT Supporter Rewards

NOTE: All supporter names will be on our website after the campaign.

The BLgT Impact

You support = multiplier for impact, this summer and beyond. 

Our partnership model matches one restaurant with one LGBT organization per city. Proceeds from the BLgT go towards the community partner. 100% of this goes to local organizations. BLgT USA does not take a cut of this. We've already engaged over 1,000 people in-person across the country, created over 50 local partnerships, and captured 100+ stories that have been shared on our blog and in our weekly Huffington Post series. This summer is a win-win for everyone. This summer is about sparking relationships made to grow and last:

  • LGBT organizations gain visibility, funding, and access to new supporters.
  • Restaurants gain visibility, increased sales during our events, and access to new customers. 
  • Supporters get connected to organizations and local businesses they want to support.

Current BLgT USA Restaurant Partners: 

Current BLgT USA LGBT Community Partners: 

Current BLgT USA Corporate Sponsors: 

Corporate partners give us wings, while gaining visibility, credibility, and access to the best and brightest in the LGBT and ally space across the country. 

PHOTO: July 9, 2015. Richmond, VA. Owner Michele Jones and her team at Pasture hosted us in Richmond. Their BLgT (fried 'g'reen tomato!) proceeds going to Diversity Richmond all summer long. Local ABC News Anchor Ava-joye Burnett covered the story, showcasing local commitment to LGBT equality.

PHOTO: June 30, 2015. Louisville, KY. We celebrated marriage equality for ALL Americans while in Louisville at Marketplace with Chef Dallas McGarity doing his twist on the BLgT ('g'auc mayo!) for Fairness Kentucky. We even shared BLgT moments with Greg Bourke and Michael DeLeon, the Kentucky Plaintiffs in the Supreme Court Case that changed America. And yes, those truffle fries are EPIC. 

PHOTO: June 13, 2015. Philadelphia, PA. Chopped Champion Georgann Leaming + Top Chef Contestant Jennifer Zavala did their twist on the BLgT ('g'arlic bacon!). Their sandwich at Suppa is supporting The Attic Youth Center, who we marched with during Philly Pride, all summer long.


Your support allows us to catalyze local community partnerships across the United States this summer, getting people out for LGBT community organizations like never before in all 50 states. 

Why this? Why now?

Why did we leave our bubble comforts to travel to ALL 50 states, promoting equality through food? 

  • Marriage is only the beginning. Beyond marriage equality, life for LGBT individuals is not all rainbows and unicorns. Check out our jaw dropping number graphics from our first crowdfunding campaign. You can still be fired in 29 states for being LGBT. Kids are being thrown out of their homes -- 40% of all homeless youth identify as LGBT. Over a quarter of trans people have attempted suicide, with close to 50% considering suicide in their lifetime. Movement backlash is real. There are hundreds of millions of dollars going towards anti-LGBT legislation. We saw first hand an anti-LGBT adoption law pass in Michigan before our event there in June. This is prompting people, like our supporters Rick and Rob, to consider leaving the state.
  • Food brings people together. Everyone needs to eat. Food is universal. We heard from family and friends that they wanted an engaging way to support LGBT rights. Voila. 
  • This is a once in a lifetime summer, baby. We believe that policy action needs a dinner date and dance partner to change the hearts and minds of real people. On June 26th, we experienced living history when marriage equality swept the nation (thanks, SCOTUS!). The confederate flag was voted to come down in South Carolina. We've already met over 1,000 people on the road at our events throughout D.C. and 22 States (in order) - MA, VT, NH, NY, CT, ME, RI, NJ, DE, PA, OH, MI, WI, IA, MO, KY, WV, MD, VA, NC. People are getting out and stepping up, because we've made it delicious. 


Risks + Challenges 

We've already seen road challenges, and faced them head on. Here are a few more that might happen along the way. 

  • Weather // It's summer. El Nino might hit North Dakota. Climate change is FOR REAL, so with the weather... you never know. That said, unless there's an apocalyptic summer snow, the show will go on.
  • Logistics // The plan is to have partner chefs cook BLgTs in their own kitchens when we roll through town and set-up shop in front of their restaurant. If there are any last minute emergencies (i.e. Kitchen Fires), this might set-us back. 
  • Sickness // While we like to believe we have super human health powers, but having our team 100% healthy the whole time is a legit challenge. #vitamins
  • Money // Bling. If something drastic happens, there is always the chance we could run out. 
  • Truck Issues // We're traveling in a Chevy Suburban nicknamed "Ginsburg" (WE <3 YOU, RBG). We have insurance, but mechanical issues might make us adjust the schedule.

PHOTO:  July 1, 2015. Charleston, West Virginia. Keeley Steele, Owner of Bluegrass. Supporters got out with us in Charleston to try not one, but FOUR versions of the BLgT... a taco, salad, sandwich, AND cocktail (Basil, Lemon, 'g'in and Tonic). Proceeds from all BLgTs sold benefit Fairness West Virginia. Niiiice. 


Other Delicious Ways You Can Help

Whether you're in for $5 or $500, there are other ways you can help make BLgT USA happen this summer:  

  • PRESS // If you are, or know someone, in the press / media, hello [wave]: go@getout.io 
  • SPONSORS // Do you know anyone in the hospitality / travel / accommodations space? Or anyone who wants to build their brand with LGBT and ally supporters, specifically those hard to find, sought after millennials? (We got 'em.) Let's make magic together. Email: taryn@getout.io 
  • SHARE IS CARING // You can use the share social media share tools below, and we'll love you even more! 

Together. We got this. Tell your besties. Baby Jameson is in. Yes #shamelessbabypromo  

Thanks again! BLgT love from the road.

-Taryn, Peter, Katie, and Andrew

Logistics // The plan is to have partner chefs cook BLgTs in their own kitchens when we roll through town and set-up shop in front of their restaurant. If there are any last minute emergencies (i.e. Kitchen Fires), this might set-us back. 
Sickness // While we like to believe we have super human health powers, but having our team 100% healthy the whole time is a legit challenge. #vitamins
Money // Bling. If something drastic happens, there is always the chance we could run out. 
Truck Issues // We're traveling in a Chevy Suburban nicknamed "Ginsburg" (WE <3 YOU, RBG). We have insurance, but mechanical issues might make us adjust the schedule.    

PHOTO:  July 1, 2015. Charleston, West Virginia. Keeley Steele, Owner of Bluegrass. Supporters got out with us in Charleston to try not one, but FOUR versions of the BLgT... a taco, salad, sandwich, AND cocktail (Basil, Lemon, 'g'in and Tonic). Proceeds from all BLgTs sold benefit Fairness West Virginia. Niiiice. 


Other Delicious Ways You Can Help
Whether you're in for $5 or $500, there are other ways you can help make BLgT USA happen this summer:  


PRESS // If you are, or know someone, in the press / media, hello [wave]: go@getout.io 
SPONSORS // Do you know anyone in the hospitality / travel / accommodations space? Or anyone who wants to build their brand with LGBT and ally supporters, specifically those hard to find, sought after millennials? (We got 'em.) Let's make magic together. Email: taryn@getout.io  
SHARE IS CARING // You can use the share social media share tools below, and we'll love you even more!    Together. We got this. Tell your besties. Baby Jameson is in. Yes #shamelessbabypromo  Thanks again! BLgT love from the road.-Taryn, Peter, Katie, and Andrew

story:
Here's us now....

Director David Rey at Cannes Film Festival 2015

Actress and Producer Lara Clear at Cannes Film Festival 2015

Actress/Writer/Producer Stacy Ayn Price on set of "Peaches and Tea" 2015

And here we are just 2 years ago!


(Shooting our first episode of "Box of Crayons", 50 Shades of Grey parody web series) (Adorable, yes?)

I, Stacy, have been given the responsibility of telling a bit of our story in writing:

It took time for Lara, David and I to work on a project together. I gave David a "play" of my poetry to direct once: a one-woman show. Nothing happened.  Two years later, I sent  David a message about "Box of Crayons."  I am sure he felt it would yield the same fruitless result when I told him it's subject: "a 50 shades of grey parody." Before that moment in time, it hadn't consciously occurred to me to be a filmmaker. How lucky was I that David was a filmmaker and had been filmmaking the second he got out of school?  David would bring one splendid thing to every single day of shooting regardless the challenge: love of film. That said, to David, he was in for a one day shoot of a book he knew very little about. Lara Clear was the glue. I told her something on the lines of "I need you to help me, this won't happen if you don't." There is a jump of a feeling when you produce your own work for the first time...what if it was just awful?   Lara Clear said "yes" in the best way a person can. She said yes and then she followed up...and then she found a location...and then she communicated...Lara Clear was very much responsible for the Box of Crayons ball rolling. And, I Stacy, needed it too. I have lived in the city for years just waiting for the perfect part to open up, the perfect person to find me, and something snapped within me: I would be waiting forever on a Beckett bench somewhere to no avail. No one knew, not even me that I'd reel them in to 7 more episodes. 7 more episodes means 7 more times of the following procedure: one month of saving up money and planning, one month of editing and then the episode drops! 8 times of fast pace film making; One episode shot in my air-conditionless apt on the hottest day of the year, and another episode took place on the streets and even highways of LIC.

 Gradually, through intensive work together, something basic started to happen; my drafts got stronger, our editing room quips cleaner (David directs and edits in his own studio), Lara and I learned what we wanted on set, and, we all learned how to work together. Episode 1 debuted Valentines Day 2013 . Episode 8 debuted Valentines Day 2014 to this result: we were a new, unknown group and our video opened at 50,000 views and became funnyordie.com's most watched web series that month.

Several months later, we came together again. Lara was traveling all over the world, modeling in England, auditioning in LA, David was working on documentaries and projects, I was finishing a rehearsal/run of a new show, so the fact we all converged again was  kismet.  I had written "Peaches and Tea" having been  frustrated with world politics, depressed about the role of women in society and enamored with period pieces like "Sense and Sensibility." David and Lara were on board with it immediately. And, then, it became producing in this beautifully smooth way.

This is what the room we shot in looked like:

(This photo is a photo of about 10 people you cannot see, although the dogs Einstein and Eddie try to do them justice. It took a village to make this shot happen)

"Peaches and Tea" is the story of two female assassins who must decide on living arrangements.


 A location and costumes were the first most difficult issues, but magically an affordable Inn (with the help of a locations producer, brought in by Lara) presented itself and the rest was a wonderful climax of dedicated, gifted professionals  working together for one foreseeable goal.  With limited funds, post was a rough road, but we: Clear, Price and Rey were able to submit to a few festivals. AND! "Peaches and Tea" was accepted into the 2015 Cannes Film Festival!

So, we need YOU. Oh, we really need you to become part of our team. Help us submit Peaches and help us make more films!

So here's where every last bit of that money will go...

The amounts below added up exceed the $6000 goal. Here's why: wishful thinking! We will likely go in the red, but it's you that can allow us to simply do the work.

We would love to submit to more festivals!
$1000 dollars covers 12-20 additional festival entries

Festivals Fees range from free to 100 dollars. Most festivals fall in the middle mark at 40-75. The more prestigious festivals tend to be more expensive.

$500-1000 Post

Post production can truly make or break a film.  This means color correction, sound mixing, music and special effects. Peaches and Tea could still use some work. The more work accomplished the more competitive the piece and  the more likely it is to do well.

Examples of Special Effects: We were able to get a location that was built in the 1850s but still,of course, had modern light switches, sensors, etc. To correct this, a special effects artist goes in and matches pieces of the houses' wall to areas where the light switches were. These corrections are daunting and must be done frame by fame. The fees can run production companies thousands of dollars.

5000 dollars
Two new short films to be shot October and November 2015 for 2016 festival entries....
This is ambitiously low, but fingers crossed!
Here's where the money goes on a set:
Sound/DP/Makeup/PA.........…1500+(per day)
Equipment, Lighting/Rental.....1500(per day or weekend in the case of rentals)
Location Rental..........................1000(per day, ideally)
Travel.......................................…500(per day)
(For Peaches and Tea, We drove a van with crew and equipment to the location from Union Square, NYC to the Hamptons)
Costumes..................................500
(For a period piece, rental for authenticity becomes especially important, one way to scale costs is to use educational sources and fantastic foundations like TDF, however costumes still can be one of the most expensive items on a limited budget. The more modern a piece we do, however, the less this amount will be )

So many people have been a part of this team for starters Ella Jane New as cofounder with David Rey of Discovery Hill Prod.  With Box of Crayons: Jennifer Isaacson and Patrick Cann. For Peaches and Tea: Chloe Bellande...This list will be added to shortly.

story:
One Story, One Mission Becomes Two

The slogan for this show is "It's All About The Music". However, the team behind New Orleans Live has learned that perhaps the slogan should be modified to say "It's All About The People Behind The Music".

This campaign is being conducted to support a show whose goal is to promote and preserve the music, heritage, and culture of New Orleans and Louisiana. The architect and guiding force behind New Orleans Live is Executive Producer Ernest Collins. He reassembled his old team from years past because they too believed in this mission. However, no one could have predicted the devastating event that would take place the week before show production was to begin.


On July 25, 2015, 22-year-old SPC Caleb Michael Collins, Ernest's only son, tragically lost his life while attempting to save a friend from drowning. Because of this life-altering event, it was suggested that the production of New Orleans Live should be postponed. But Ernest refused. He knew that Caleb had strongly supported the show verbally and financially. He was also a proud former member of the color guard in the mighty St. Augustine High School Marching 100. Caleb loved his hometown, its music, people, heritage, and culture and he knew his father was trying to capture those dynamics to promote them to the world.

Watch Caleb's Story Here on WWL-TV

With Caleb's selfless and heroic spirit in mind, New Orleans Live's production team has vowed to not only highlight the music, musicians, and heritage of the city and state but to create and fund the Caleb Michael Collins Memorial Scholarship. This scholarship will pay the annual cost of tuition for a deserving student to attend St. Augustine High School, Caleb's beloved Alma Mater.

If you support our efforts to preserve and promote the music and culture of New Orleans and if you are touched and inspired by the selfless act of courage and heroism shown by Caleb Collins, please donate to New Orleans Live. Your contribution will go towards both the production of the television show and the Caleb Michael Collins annual scholarship to St. Augustine High School.

Please read further about the New Orleans Live Background below.

Our Background - Our Story - Our Mission

When people all over the world hear the words New Orleans, they think of music. They think Jazz, Blues, Zydeco, Rap, Rhythm & Blues, Funk, Rock, and more. Louisiana is readily acknowledged as one of the world’s richest sources of original musical styles, traditions, and performers and New Orleans is its musical crown jewel. Music from every culture and genre continues to evolve and is an essential part of daily life here.


That's why we're asking you to help fund
New Orleans Live


Everyone on the New Orleans Live team believes that our music and musicians are to be treasured, celebrated, promoted, and preserved. But the fact is, they’re not. Unfortunately, so much of the state’s musical heritage has gone unrecorded and been lost in time.


From 1996 - 2002, there was a critically acclaimed weekly live music television show called Louisiana Jukebox. Jukebox captured the raw energy and feel of live music performed for an audience, creating an intimate experience where television viewers were drawn into the dynamic between the musicians and their fans . It stuck to its motto of “It’s All About The Music”. Running for 335 episodes on television stations all across the south and worldwide via the Internet, it showcased hundreds of Louisiana musicians, giving them opportunities to perform and promote themselves in new ways and to new audiences. The show made a significant difference in their careers and lives. Furthermore, those performances were preserved as a Living Legacy special collection on video at Tulane University.

Now the same team that brought you LA Jukebox is gearing up production of
New Orleans Live, a music television show that we believe will rival Austin City Limits. Set to be produced in High Definition video and High Fidelity audio, it will be distributed worldwide via broadcast, satellite, cable, and the Internet. We believe this show will have a powerful and positive impact on local musicians and on the local economy. New Orleans Live will garner exposure and work for the artists, promote much-needed musical tourism for the city and state, and preserve our unique musical heritage for present and future generations.


You can help us help our beloved city and its musicians by making a contribution to our efforts. With your help, we will celebrate, promote, preserve, and treasure the living musical legacies of today - our musicians.

What We Need From You - What You Can Get

  • We are asking for $10,000 in order to help produce New Orleans Live in a quality manner. All the money we make will go to pay the costs incurred in the making of the show (renting the venue, the television production equipment, audio gear, personnel, etc...) Our fundraising goal will be supplemented by money we are trying to sell in sponsorship to pay for the initial season of 13 one-hour episodes of New Orleans Live.
  • Perks include: New Orleans Live keychains, t-shirts, ink pens, VIP status at show tapings, backstage passes, show announcing privileges, round-trip airfare and hotel accommodations, your very own Second Line Parade, tickets to JazzFest, and tickets to Voodoo Fest! Just select whichever level in which you want to participate.

Our Challenge

Our goal is to expose Louisiana music and musicians to a worldwide audience to help gain recognition for them, our heritage, our city, and our state. We want people to be able to see and HEAR that New Orleans is the REAL live music capital of the world. This might be a tall order but we feel up to the challenge.

  • We know we can do this because this team has already proved their track record with Louisiana Jukebox, the multi-award winning music television show that was produced and broadcast live every week for 7 1/2 years. After the devastation of Katrina and the team members scattering all over the U.S., they are reuniting 13 years later in a labor of love and conviction that Louisiana's music must be promoted and preserved. Only a truly dynamic and loving effort can capture these musicians' creative genius in the way they deserve.

Meet The Team

This is the group whose passion drives New Orleans Live.

 (l to r): Ernest Collins, Creator/Executive Producer; Kathy Goode, Senior Producer; Robin Dallafior, Producer; Cristian Colbert, Creative Director/Producer; Michael Paz, Music Producer; Christopher Roberts, Producer; Katha Fields, Talent/Audience Coordinator; Monique Walker-Blue, Network Development Director

Each of these professionals has worked in the entertainment industry for decades and their combined expertise and devotion to this project is unparalleled. For more detailed information on each of them, click here. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that sometimes you can't afford to give money. But there are other ways you can help us spread the word.

  • Like our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat, Vine, and Tumblr pages. HELP US SPREAD THE WORD!
  • And please, please, please use the Indiegogo share tools. If you can't afford to contribute, maybe you know someone who can. Every little bit helps. Thank You!

story:
Why preserve the military service history of veterans, what have these people accomplished?

Recording video histories make knowing of sacrifices made easier. Videos are
informative, reverential; they say thanks all year long and they preserve the record.

Example: Steve Jager's family arrived the USA Dec. 25th, 1928. During the 1941 attack on Pearl Harbor; Jager's guns were locked as pilots flew low enough to see    smiles. Alyce Massert worked on Japanese code as a Navy WAV; became a realtor     then had a Japanese man among her first clients. Massart and Jager died not long ago; all participants or loved ones receive the edited "release video" at no cost.

Dorothy Rogers speaks of her war to get USMC sergeant's stripes and meeting  Elvis at Graceland while on duty in Tennessee on disk 1; plus Korean era experiences of twin brothers Leo and Leonard Kijowski on disk 1 & 2 respectively.

Walter Kijowski; the last of six Kijowski brothers to leave Ford City for WWII or Korea will be recorded soon in Tarentum. Adrian Cronauer formerly of Penn Hills spoke of writing the screenplay for Good Morning Vietnam weeks before Robin Williams died for disk 2. Mr. Cronauer hit Saigon airwaves in 1965; helped start Pitt's radio station in the late 50's even appearing on Pittsburgh area TV as a child. After law school; Cronauer began his work on Korean era KIA issues for the Pentagon.

 A New Ken pilot completed his B-24 bombing run over Germany even refusing a morphine drip after being shot. Gilpin's William Shipman saw the death camps in the infantry; Harry his son went to Vietnam and daughter Jean was an Army nurse.

Profit is not the goal; finishing the double DVD is.  All financial support no matter the amount will be valued and appreciated. Research, production, travel, materials and service costs must be met. Of the $8,250 budget self funding adds 3k; $600 from others plus promises totaling $150. There is $350 cash on hand as of August 4, 2015. Time spent on fundraising means less time recording frail, ill or old vets. As vets die with their story untold important things are forever lost .   

What do we need to complete another DVD:

$5,000 is required to publish another DVD. Segments cost $750 each; we have 5 already to go but we need 7 more.

Why me, what resources, experience and background?

  1. We have two completed disks available now.
  2. News/ corporate video & television studio production since 1999.
  3. Capitol Hill:  sub committee coverage of  vet/ military affairs 1998 to 2001.        
  4. Commercial radio; Pittsburgh, Orlando, Baltimore/ DC 1975 to 1998.
  5. National Archives/ Library of Congress research 2008 to present.
  6. Relationships with other documentary researchers & producers.


Summary and Conclusion/ Challenge:

Risks or challenges faced in doing this work pales to challenges faced by people in these videos. There are risks in asking people for money for any purpose but:

1. This is not a profit making venture.

2. I have been and will be involved financially in all of these projects.

3. A portion of what is cleared from BBQ events this summer will be added to cash in hand for a second straight year so I am committed to this effort. Getting to the 80% of goal vicinity would be decent; 90% of goal reached and I am buying champagne (not from campaign funds); I am not even fond of the stuff! 

ALL campaign funds are used to complete disk 3. The more we raise the more vets we record from dwindling numbers of WWII to Vietnam era service members from all branches and ranks. We have a series of gifts that we can offer for supporting  our efforts to preserve military history throughout South Western Pennsylvania.

Optional gifts for your support;

Premiums include Honey Baked Ham gift cards, screen credit, posters. Our analog to digital gift is transfer of a single media type to DVD. Send either silent 8 mm film, camcorder video, VHS/ audio tapes, pics, LPs or documents for archiving making them less vulnerable to total loss AND easier to enjoy.

Our BBQ premium features BBQ with delivery in zip code 15068, fees apply  for delivery outside 15068. Orders are filled weekends in Sept. and Oct.

To boost the power of your gift don't redeem your premium, this makes even more dollars available for production. But great food you don't have to cook during football season is tempting. Either way; all support is appreciated; if I left something out; write me; thank you.

John Bailey, producer/DCH vol. 3; email the producer: akvalley.pa@gmail.com

2013 Valley News Dispatch article on Volume 1.  http://triblive.com/neighborhoods/yourallekiskivalley/yourallekiskivalleymore/5032559-74/bailey-valley-kiski#axzz2sePzaUFK

2014 Valley News Dispatch article on Volume 2. http://triblive.com/neighborhoods/yourallekiskivalley/yourallekiskivalleymore/7333670-74/stories-war-bailey#axzz3LR7P9iPV

Video Histories Scrapbook https://www.facebook.com/pages/Military-Veteran-Video-Histories-Page/1627321750845939?sk=photos_stream
story_txt:
Why preserve the military service history of veterans, what have these people accomplished?Recording video histories make knowing of sacrifices made easier. Videos areinformative, reverential; they say thanks all year long and they preserve the record.Example: Steve Jager's family arrived the USA Dec. 25th, 1928. During the 1941 attack on Pearl Harbor; Jager's guns were locked as pilots flew low enough to see    smiles. Alyce Massert worked on Japanese code as a Navy WAV; became a realtor     then had a Japanese man among her first clients. Massart and Jager died not long ago; all participants or loved ones receive the edited "release video" at no cost. Dorothy Rogers speaks of her war to get USMC sergeant's stripes and meeting  Elvis at Graceland while on duty in Tennessee on disk 1; plus Korean era experiences of twin brothers Leo and Leonard Kijowski on disk 1 & 2 respectively.Walter Kijowski; the last of six Kijowski brothers to leave Ford City for WWII or Korea will be recorded soon in Tarentum. Adrian Cronauer formerly of Penn Hills spoke of writing the screenplay for Good Morning Vietnam weeks before Robin Williams died for disk 2. Mr. Cronauer hit Saigon airwaves in 1965; helped start Pitt's radio station in the late 50's even appearing on Pittsburgh area TV as a child. After law school; Cronauer began his work on Korean era KIA issues for the Pentagon. A New Ken pilot completed his B-24 bombing run over Germany even refusing a morphine drip after being shot. Gilpin's William Shipman saw the death camps in the infantry; Harry his son went to Vietnam and daughter Jean was an Army nurse. Profit is not the goal; finishing the double DVD is.  All financial support no matter the amount will be valued and appreciated. Research, production, travel, materials and service costs must be met. Of the $8,250 budget self funding adds 3k; $600 from others plus promises totaling $150. There is $350 cash on 
hand as of August 4, 2015. Time spent on fundraising means less time recording frail, ill or old vets. As vets die with their story untold important things are forever lost .     What do we need to complete another DVD:
$5,000 is required to publish another DVD. Segments cost $750 each; we have 5 already to go but we need 7 more. Why me, what resources, experience and background?
We have two completed disks available now.

News/ corporate video & television studio production since 1999.
Capitol Hill:  sub committee coverage of  vet/ military affairs 1998 to 2001.         

Commercial radio; Pittsburgh, Orlando, Baltimore/ DC 1975 to 1998.
National Archives/ Library of Congress research 2008 to present.

Relationships with other 
documentary researchers & producers.



Summary and Conclusion/ Challenge:
Risks or challenges faced in doing this work pales to challenges faced by people in these videos. There are risks in asking people for money for any purpose but:1. This is not a profit making venture.2. I have been and will be involved financially in all of these projects.3. A portion of what is cleared from BBQ events this summer will be added to cash in hand for a second straight year so I am committed to this effort. Getting to the 80% of goal vicinity would be decent; 90% of goal reached and I am buying champagne (not from campaign funds); I am not even fond of the stuff!  ALL campaign funds are used to complete disk 3. The more we raise the more vets we record from dwindling numbers of WWII to Vietnam era service members from all branches and ranks. We have a series of gifts that we can offer for supporting  our efforts to preserve military history throughout South Western Pennsylvania.Optional gifts for your support; 
 Premiums include Honey Baked Ham gift cards, screen credit, posters. Our analog to digital gift is transfer of a single media type  to DVD. Send either silent 8 mm film, camcorder video, VHS/ audio tapes, pics, LPs or documents for archiving making them less vulnerable to total loss AND easier to enjoy. Our BBQ premium features BBQ with delivery in zip code 15068, fees apply  for delivery outside 15068. Orders are filled weekends in Sept. and Oct. To boost the power of your gift don't redeem your premium, this makes even more dollars available for production. But great food you don't have to cook during football season is tempting. Either way; all support is appreciated; if I left something out; write me; thank you.John Bailey, producer/DCH vol. 3; email the producer: akvalley.pa@gmail.com2013 Valley News Dispatch article on Volume 1.  http://triblive.com/neighborhoods/yourallekiskivalley/yourallekiskivalleymore/5032559-74/bailey-valley-kiski#axzz2sePzaUFK2014 Valley News Dispatch article on Volume 2. http://triblive.com/neighborhoods/yourallekiskivalley/yourallekiskivalleymore/7333670-74/stories-war-bailey#axzz3LR7P9iPVVideo Histories Scrapbook https://www.facebook.com/pages/Military-Veteran-Video-Histories-Page/1627321750845939?sk=photos_stream

story:
This Generation’s “Love Jones”, With a Twist!

“Water” is a multidimensional story of self-discovery that illustrates the complexity of art, love, and sexuality.

It follows the journey of Tonya Mimms, a successful, DC-based, multi-media artist who feels firmly footed in her rise to fame until her ascent is challenged in the most unexpected ways.

While meandering through the throes of a love triangle, with a charismatic man and a stunningly beautiful woman, Tonya takes on an assignment that pushes her completely out of her element. Now, in the midst of total chaos, Tonya is forced to come to terms with herself, as an artist and a woman.

Based on the novel Water In A Broken Glass by Odessa Rose. (Available on Amazon)

Love is fluid... dive in!

WE DC!

We want “Water” to highlight the splendor of Washington DC, and not just the DC you see on House of Cards (cough, only in the credits). That’s why our locations, our artists, the music, and the talent, are all Chocolate City originals!

We want this film to be more than just the Capitol Building and the National Mall. We want this film to be an all out homage to our great city!

We Are Family!

Become a part of our journey by helping us reach our $50,000 goal. Your monetary  support will go toward:

  • Cast, Crew, and Equipment (70% of our budget)

  • All things we must legally do to make this film happen (securing locations, feeding cast and crew)

  • Production Design (wardrobe, set dressing, props)

Here's What You Get!

We won’t leave you hanging! For your contribution, we will definitely hook you up with one or more of the awesome perks on the right!

Receive a signed copy of the book, a signed copy of the screenplay, special access to the very first screening or the wrap party, social media shout outs, thank you notes, and even associate or executive producer credit!

Money isn’t all we need. Five ways you can help!

Aside from reaching our financial goal, we want people to know about “Water” and we need YOU to help us spread the word. Here are five easy ways to help:

  1. Follow us on Twitter @WaterTheFilm and Facebook Water The Film 2016

  2. Share our campaign with your friends on social media.

  3. Share our link via email to your friends at work. Don’t worry, they’ll check it.

  4. Bring “Water” up in your watercooler conversations. See what we did there?

  5. Call your favorite radio station and ask them to give “Water” a shout out.

Meet The Team!

  Jamelle Williams-Thomas (Director/Producer) 

Jamelle is a DC filmmaker and Digital Engagement Specialist. Her production company Lodge Street Films strongly advocates for the representation of all facets of the Black diaspora in film and media, and strives to give those stories a place in the light.

Her previous work includes Transplant and trailers for Odessa Rose’s critically acclaimed novel In The Mirror.

Jamelle’s favorite quote is: “Life isn’t about finding yourself. Life’s about creating yourself.” - George Bernard Shaw

   Danielle S. Mooney (Writer/Producer) 
(Danielle's cousin, herself, and oldest niece)

Leader of her own movement & a true introverted Gemini, Danielle is a quiet dreamer, a lover of music, movies & quotes, an oblivious comedian, and a random adventure creator. Empathic & intuitive by nature, she is a Licensed Master of Social Work Columbia graduate who sees beauty in imperfections, differences, vulnerability, and quiet moments.

In 2012, Danielle started fighting off the fear demons and getting her feet wet in the film world when she joined the hit web series Finding Me The Series as a Production Manager. Since then, she has been taking writing workshops, volunteering at major NYC film festivals, and attending all things film. She aims to create authentic films about Black folks’ journeys of self-discovery, intimacy​, and how they relate to each other and the worlds around them.

Originally from DC, Danielle currently works in the nonprofit sector and as a high school mentor in NYC. She fell in love with Water in a Broken Glass in 2007; and seven reads later, she is grateful to be a part of its adaptation!

One of Danielle’s favorite quotes is: “You must have chaos within you to give birth to a dancing star.” -Friedrich Nietzsche​

story:
What is this MOVIE?

The Grove is a Columbia College Chicago Thesis film shooting in May 2015 in Los Angeles, California. 
Follow our journey on our tumblr page: http://thegrovefilm.tumblr.com

STORY

The story is about Mica, a 19 year old girl, living in the outskirts of Los Angeles in the near future. She is home for the summer after her first year at college. She is in a transitory time, not knowing where she belongs or who she is. For most of the summer she hid in her room, addicted to her wearable computer contact-lenses or “Screens”.

The film starts on a late summer afternoon, Mica is lost in the virtual reality world of her Screens. As Mica attempts to hide in plain sight, a 22 year old stranger, Diana, interrupts Mica’s session. Diana reveals that she doesn’t wear Screens at all and Mica is somewhat embarrassed by her addiction to her Screens yet too stubborn to give them up. However, before Mica can hide again, she is visited by her imaginary friend, Sonic. He takes her back to a place in her mind, a place where she used to have full reign of her imagination, otherwise known as The Grove.

*Some frames from our concept art by Ernesto Sin Alos:

 




The Team

We are a team of students and alumni, not only from Columbia College but from several institutions in different parts of the country, working on this thesis film that plans to go into production late in May. 

This is an ambitious project not only because of the story, but because we want to make this a high quality film. 

We hope to apply all the knowledge we have learned while in college to the different areas of production and come out with a film that we are happy with and that is relevant and meaningful to our audience.

We have the experience, we have the knowledge, we have the passion and we want to make this film happen!


Corinne Marquardt: is the writer&director of The Grove. She was born in the Netherlands as an American expat and has moved around much of her life. She attended Pitzer College for her undergrad and  focused on documentary and experimental film. She went to Columbia College for graduate school and has focused on narrative films, while still incorporating documentary and experimental elements into her stories. Corinne has pursued filmmaking since a teenager, and is excited to finally create this original film, The Grove.

Carmen Garcia Davila is not only the producer of this film, but she has helped produce every film with Corinne while at Columbia College. She is originally from Mexico, but she also speaks a handful of other languages such as Russian and Chinese. She studied producing while at Columbia College Chicago, but she is also knowledgeable about lighting, production design, cinematography and writing. Carmen and Corinne started working on this film in October 2014, and she has been a hardworking, resourceful and amazing partner! 

Kia Herman is a Production Designer and Costume Designer based in Los Angeles. She does film and commercials of all kinds, but her favorite genres are Science Fiction, Fantasy, and Post Apocalypse. She is well known for her work in the Award Winning webseries Player Piano, and she is very excited to be working on The Grove. She has a great positive energy, and her Production Design style is very in synch with the film´s visuals.

Tyler Bailey: graduated from Columbia College Chicago 2014 with emphasis on Cinematography. He has worked in almost every facet of production but has found his calling behind the lens of the camera. Every last detail of the picture is paid special attention with composition, lighting, movement and how that aesthetically helps tell each unique story. Tyler is excited to visit the West Coast for the first time in his life and what a better way than to partake in something he loves the most; filming and storytelling.

Alexis Garcia:  Despite her lifelong passion for film, Alexis first stepped on a professional set at 18, working as an extra for an NBC pilot. After two years working as an background actor, she finally changed her Marketing major and transferred to Columbia College Chicago to study behind the scenes work in film producing: the perfect mix between art and business. While at Columbia, she worked on numerous short films as a producer, line producer, and 2nd assistant director. In her final semester, she packed up everything and moved to Los Angeles to pursue her career in producing. Currently she's working as a production coordinator for AwesomenessTV and beginning an internship with Fandango in June.

Marco Roman studied at Cal State Northridge, in CTVA, with the option in Television Production. Along the way he found his passion to help out his community, and decided to Double Major in Central American Studies. Marco is currently working on multiple projects which include, the Latino Heritage Organization, who are partnered with NBC Universal, to bring awareness of the Latino Culture in Los Angeles through a PSA.  He will continue to work hard and accomplish his future goals. 

Ernesto Sin Alos is our storyboard artist, and currently lives in Mexico. He attended school in New Jersey and has been creating comic books, storyboards and concept art for numerous student and  independent films. Despite our distance, we’ve corresponded via phone/email/social media to bring to life the vision of the script. He has been so incredibly responsive and practically telepathic in creating the concept art for the film. We can’t be happier to have him part of this team.

Timothy Steinman: is the composer for this film. He was born in Evanston, Illinois and has attended school in Toronto and Chicago. While being the manager of a recording studio, he also works on his own experimental photography and sound art. Currently he’s writing the score for another film of Corinne's, and they've collaborated on other projects, such as music videos for his solo band, Arc of the Hunter. We are really excited to have him part of this crew, because we believe his music will bring a unique and complex layer to this film.

Impact

We are all young filmmakers and the only way we can grow is by making movies! 
By contributing to this campaign you are directly helping all of us achieve our dreams by making ambitious films like The Grove!
And even though this is a fictional film, there are many parts of this story that address common concerns about our contemporary society. 

Technological devices, such as smart phones, tablets, apps can definitely help us in our creative endeavors, but when these tools hinder our imaginations and alter our friendships, they need to be re-evaluated. 

We are also very proud of the crew and (now cast!) we are assembling for this film. So often film sets lack diversity and we are a group of people from all kinds of backgrounds, states, countries and our gender ratio is about 50/50. These should not be novel things, however the film industry has a particularly resistant glass cieling which we all hope to help break through!


What We Have & What We Still Need

Through your donation, you are either buying a crew member a meal, paying for the shipping of the camera from Chicago to LA,  adding another scene of fantastic special effects to our film,  or helping bring another crew member to set.

Your donation is extremely important to us! We will make the best of every cent we receive, and we will not only be grateful but will have the commitment to make this film the best it can be with the money you have generously given us.

Locations! So far we have locked down all of our locations. What does this mean? It means that we have scouted and found the perfect locations for this film to take place in. We will be renting a house for a few days, but the rest of our locations are  public parks and exterior locations, from the Los Angeles River to a hiking trail in Pasadena. Although most of these locations don´t have a set price, the film commission here in LA requires us to purchase the permits to allow us to film in parks and public spaces.

Insurance! The number one priority in any film project should be the safety of its crew members, as well as the safety of its locations and equipment. In this case, we are required to cover all of our equipment with additional insurance since we are shooting outside of Chicago, and to guarantee our locations that they will be covered against any alteration to their property. That is the reason why insurance is a  portion of the budget and it is really important and we would not be able to move forward without it.

Food! Our hard working crew can´t work 12 hour days without it´s well deserved meals. In any film project of any size, meals will always be one of the basic expenses. In addition to meals, we spend money on craft food available to the crew all throughout the day: coffee, water, juice, fruits, veggies, sandwiches, nuts, chips, etc. 

Equipment! By equipment, we mean both lighting and grip gear rentals, which we are getting from a local rental company in LA. We want our camera team to be comfortable and well equipped, so we have arranged a good deal for our Cinematographer to have a 3 ton grip truck.  Additionally, we will also need to rent a zoom lens. We are trying to minimize our expenses in the camera equipment area, so we are flying the camera body and gear (provided by our College) out from Chicago. This is cheaper than renting it in Los Angeles, however we still need to budget in those flying fees for the 12 cases of camera equipment. 

Transportation! Transportation costs not only include shipping the camera equipment, but also reimbursing our crew to travel to and from set. We are reimbursing the gas expenses of all of our crew members. They are already donating so much of their time, the least we can do for them, is keep them from making any additional expenditure while working on our set. With this money we are also paying for a car pooling van to take our crew to set when we shoot in Rialto, CA. 

Casting! The casting process also incurred in additional costs that, although minimal, still need to be paid for. The casting studio, suggested by our line producer Marco, in the heart of Los Angeles was amazing, key in facilitating the auditions and allowing us to go through the process in a professional manner, comfortable to us and to the actors.

Art Department! Production Design is KEY for the success of this film in particular. As part of the futuristic setting of the film, costumes will be designed to accompany the tone of the story. We have a great costume designer working in the sketches right now, under the supervision of our experienced Production Designer. Additionally, to achieve the "Screens" effect we need to purchase special contact lenses for our actors and extras to wear. This is an area where we need to spend just the right amount to achieve the look we are going for and make the story and the world not only believable but also engaging.

Sound! On-location sound is extremely important for any production of any level. The way we see it, we want to get the best sound on location so we don´t have to go back to the studio to add ADR because of bad sound. For this, we have brought on board two professionals in the field who will make sure we get the best sound on set. For us, they are charging minimal fees for both their services and the rent of their equipment. We are confident that by having them on the team will add value to the film and save us money in the long run.

Visual Effects! Besides editing the film, we are bringing on board a special effects composer to take the film to that next level of quality. He will be the one in charge of making the "Screens" come to life. His fee is something we need to budget in because it is extremely important to get the right person involved, and therefore assure us that we will get the results we need.

All of us are juggling so many things, whether we're students, working day jobs, or young professionals just starting our careers. Making these independent films together is so important to better ourselves as filmmakers. 

Even though some of us currently live in different states (or countries!) we have made so much progress already, thanks to all of our team member's passion and dedication. 


Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD THE WORD!

Like us on Facebook, follow us in Tumblr, and talk to your friends about us!

http://thegrovefilm.tumblr.com

https://www.facebook.com/thegroveshortfilm

Also, if you are in LA and would like to help out on set while in production, send us a direct message! We are looking for PA´s and any additional hands on set would be more than welcome. If you are interested in helping in any other way, please just let us know!

Thank you so much!!!

What We Have & What We Still Need

Through your donation, you are either buying a crew member a meal, paying for the shipping of the camera from Chicago to LA,  adding another scene of fantastic special effects to our film,  or helping bring another crew member to set.
Your donation is extremely important to us! We will make the best of every cent we receive, and we will not only be grateful but will have the commitment to make this film the best it can be with the money you have generously given us.
Locations! So far we have locked down all of our locations. What does this mean? It means that we have scouted and found the perfect locations for this film to take place in. We will be renting a house for a few days, but the rest of our locations are  public parks and exterior locations, from the Los Angeles River to a hiking trail in Pasadena. Although most of these locations don´t have a set price, the film commission here in LA requires us to purchase the permits to allow us to film in parks and public spaces.
Insurance! The number one priority in any film project should be the safety of its crew members, as well as the safety of its locations and equipment. In this case, we are required to cover all of our equipment with additional insurance since we are shooting outside of Chicago, and to guarantee our locations that they will be covered against any alteration to their property. That is the reason why insurance is a  portion of the budget and it is really important and we would not be able to move forward without it.
Food! Our hard working crew can´t work 12 hour days without it´s well deserved meals. In any film project of any size, meals will always be one of the basic expenses. In addition to meals, we spend money on craft food available to the crew all throughout the day: coffee, water, juice, fruits, veggies, sandwiches, nuts, chips, etc. 
Equipment! By equipment, we mean both lighting and grip gear rentals, which we are getting from a local rental company in LA. We want our camera team to be comfortable and well equipped, so we have arranged a good deal for our Cinematographer to have a 3 ton grip truck.  Additionally, we will also need to rent a zoom lens. We are trying to minimize our expenses in the camera equipment area, so we are flying the camera body and gear (provided by our College) out from Chicago. This is cheaper than renting it in Los Angeles, however we still need to budget in those flying fees for the 12 cases of camera equipment. 
Transportation! Transportation costs not only include shipping the camera equipment, but also reimbursing our crew to travel to and from set. We are reimbursing the gas expenses of all of our crew members. They are already donating so much of their time, the least we can do for them, is keep them from making any additional expenditure while working on our set. With this money we are also paying for a car pooling van to take our crew to set when we shoot in Rialto, CA. 
Casting! The casting process also incurred in additional costs that, although minimal, still need to be paid for. The casting studio, suggested by our line producer Marco, in the heart of Los Angeles was amazing, key in facilitating the auditions and allowing us to go through the process in a professional manner, comfortable to us and to the actors.
Art Department! Production Design is KEY for the success of this film in particular. As part of the futuristic setting of the film, costumes will be designed to accompany the tone of the story. We have a great costume designer working in the sketches right now, under the supervision of our experienced Production Designer. Additionally, to achieve the "Screens" effect we need to purchase special contact lenses for our actors and extras to wear. This is an area where we need to spend just the right amount to achieve the look we are going for and make the story and the world not only believable but also engaging.
Sound! On-location sound is extremely important for any production of any level. The way we see it, we want to get the best sound on location so we don´t have to go back to the studio to add ADR because of bad sound. For this, we have brought on board two professionals in the field who will make sure we get the best sound on set. For us, they are charging minimal fees for both their services and the rent of their equipment. We are confident that by having them on the team will add value to the film and save us money in the long run.
Visual Effects! Besides editing the film, we are bringing on board a special effects composer to take the film to that next level of quality. He will be the one in charge of making the "Screens" come to life. His fee is something we need to budget in because it is extremely important to get the right person involved, and therefore assure us that we will get the results we need.



All of us are juggling so many things, whether we're students, working day jobs, or young professionals just starting our careers. Making these independent films together is so important to better ourselves as filmmakers. 
Even though some of us currently live in different states (or countries!) we have made so much progress already, thanks to all of our team member's passion and dedication. 


Other Ways You Can Help
 SPREAD THE WORD!
Like us on Facebook, follow us in Tumblr, and talk to your friends about us!
http://thegrovefilm.tumblr.com
https://www.facebook.com/thegroveshortfilm
Also, if you are in LA and would like to help out on set while in production, send us a direct message! We are looking for PA´s and any additional hands on set would be more than welcome. If you are interested in helping in any other way, please just let us know!
Thank you so much!!!

story:
What the devil is Ssrids?

Ssrids is about life! Ssrids is about love and heartbreak, about guilt, fear, and friendship. Ssrids is about the times you snap at people you love and you don’t know why. It’s about when you’re falling asleep and you hear a sudden sound like a box-spring falling on a metal sheet. It’s about the times you stand up from an uncomfortable chair and your vision fades, you forget everything and you focus all your will just to stand up, until your cheeks feel cold and your mouth tastes like pennies and you remember who you are. Ssrids is about knowing it’s just a dream but being terrified anyway. It’s about the flowing patterns of triangles that swim through your vision when you close your eyes and look at the sky.

Ssrids will be a short autobiographical animated film about the time I went through sertraline (Zoloft) withdrawal. Ssrids (short for selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor discontinuation syndrome) will be my attempt to show life how it feels. Ssrids is not just about withdrawal; it’s about the simple, specific feelings and sensations that everyone feels, but that seem too inconsequential to talk about. Ssrids will be the kind of film that makes you slap your thigh and tell yourself, oh man I know that feeling!

Most of all, I hope it's a doggone good movie.


So who the devil are you?

My name’s Jude, swell to meet you! I’m just some lost rambler who’s finally found some place he wants to go. Years ago when I was a frustrated teenager struggling with untreated ADHD, I dropped out of college to wander the world and figure out my life. I worked as a carpenter, became a graphic designer for a few years, learned to weld, went to France to be an au pair, and then last year I realized I had never pursued my dream of going to art school to study animation. Back as a teen it seemed so distant and impossible, but with a little time and experience I’ve come to realize the only thing separating me from my dreams is work and persistence.

Since that epiphany I’ve gone and enrolled myself in community college and dedicated myself to art and studies. I have been sketching, doodling, and roughing out little short animations for years now, but I have never felt like I was ready to dedicate myself to something as ambitious as a real short film. So this summer, I’m asking for your support while I jump in and go for it.


Okay enough about you, tell me more about Ssrids. What is it?

Sure! Ssrids will be a short autobiographical cartoon done in hand-drawn 2D. It will be between five and ten minutes long, which will be released online to watch for free. I want to make something that is as exaggerated and cartoony as my favorite shows I watched as a kid, but earnest, emotional, and introspective.

Ssrids, as best I can describe it, is going to be a sort of animated sketch journal. Even though I hope I can make it visually compelling, I want it to feel raw and unrefined. Visually, the style will be eclectic, representing the feelings I experienced at the time as if I were drawing my own life as it happened. Sometimes it will be soft, thoughtful sketches of life. Sometimes it will be wild, disproportionate scribbles. Sometimes it will be vivid and bright like a children's cartoon. The art will be like a sketchbook: fast, thoughtful, and unpolished.

Similarly, the story will be like a diary or a piece of gonzo journalism. I don’t want to gloss over the details of life with vague “universal” generalities. I don’t want to scrub away the unflattering grit off my life. I want the result to be specific and honest, warts (and cliches) and all.

Because of this approach, Ssrids does not have a planned script. I have pieces of storyboards and scraps of dialogue and miscellaneous art scribbled around my studio, but the final film will not be the product of a grand vision. Ssrids will be the collective result of my work and my experience and my emotions. But it won’t be just some psychedelic artsy-fartsy rush of weird images and sounds. My goal with Ssrids is to express my feelings precisely and coherently.

...But there will totally be a dream sequence or two. I had a lot of lucid dreams while I was going through withdrawal, so an autobiography wouldn't be complete without a few weird dreams.


But what’s the point? How will the world be a better place if you make this film?

When I was going through withdrawal, I did not know what was happening or what to expect. I didn’t even know I was going to go through withdrawal at all; it was a complete surprise to me when one day I woke up and promptly slammed my face on a door frame because I was too dizzy to walk to the bathroom.

Lots of people go through withdrawal all the time from all kinds of drugs and illicit substances. It’s difficult. It feels lonely, it feels like no one else can understand the feeling inside your head. I hope that my film will be able to bridge that gap; I hope it will be able to draw people together to understand, and have a good laugh about a time that feels so strange and dark.

Besides withdrawal, I want to share an honest and sympathetic perspective of living with ADHD. For some reason, even though millions of people live with ADHD, the public at large doesn't give a lot of sympathy to a condition whose main symptom seems to be acting annoying.


So what, you want money? What’s in it for me?

There are lots of different perks to contributing! Everyone who contributes will be given a credit in the film, plus get the warm flush of self-satisfaction that comes with helping someone out. That isn’t the kind of feeling you can get spending fifteen bucks on a movie ticket!

More heavy-weight backers will get limited-edition posters, t-shirts, and original art. But all backers at any level will also be tuned in to insider sneak previews on the film’s progress! See the SORDID SECRETS inside my studio, and whisper your opinions right into my ear hole! Backers of this campaign will also be invited to preview the completed film before its formal release later this year.

T-Shirts? What kind of t-shirts?

T-Shirts with a big ugly mug on them!

These are real-live cotton screen printed t-shirts! I used to work at a small-town t-shirt shop for about three years, so you’ll know that whatever I ship to you will be printed with the utmost care and expertise! None of that iron-transfer crap you can get from other places; this ink is high quality ink that will last you decades with proper laundry care! I can tell you from experience.

(Note: Brain zaps don't really feel like that at all, but I thought it looked cool. So sue me for some artistic liberty with my own life experience)

Does that one perk say “erotic newspaper doodles”?

You read astutely! Yes, if you pay at the $100 level and choose that perk, you will get a piece of my collection of immature, grotesque newspaper vandalism! How grotesque you might wonder? Well, take a look for yourself: Note! Artistic nudity ahead!  Don't like any of the drawings you see there? No problem: I will draw massive grotesque erotic scenes on any newspaper you choose (as long as it isn’t some rare vintage thing I can’t get my hands on, I mean come on).


No matter how the project works out, everyone who contributes will still get their perks. Even if Ssrids fails to reach its funding goal and I am not able to dedicate myself full-time to the film, all of the perks are priced so that there is plenty  of capital left to print all the shirts and t-shirts and postcards. No matter what happens, I want you to know I appreciate your support.

Okay, so what do you want?

My funding goal is $2500 which is just enough for me to buy one of those fancy Wacom Cintiq Companions you see the rich kids at expensive art schools scribbling on. My old computer is on its very last legs, and I want to be ready to take it to pasture before it falls apart out from under me. I would be prepared to finish Ssrids on my trusty old laptop, but if this old fellow dies out on me, it will be months before I can afford a new one. While $2500 is a little extravagant for a computer, the particular computer I want to buy is specially designed for art and will make it much faster and easier to animate!

If you all are extra generous, it would not go to waste! It would really help me feel secure and help me work on Ssrids. What can I say, up to this point I made a real mixed bag of life choices, and I'm trying to turn things around right now! Extra money would make my life that much secure in case something happens (personal injury, hardware failure, home fire), and that really is a tremendous difference that goes unappreciated by a lot of folk.

After I am comfortable and stable, most of the money will just go to improving my standard of living (no more Busch! I’ll be living a Miller High Life from here on out!), but if I have enough money I might be able to afford:

  • A proper art desk where I don’t hurt my neck working

  • A studio to myself WITHOUT DISTRACTING INTERNET

  • To commission an ORIGINAL SOUNDTRACK and PROFESSIONAL SOUND EFFECTS!

  • To hire VOICE ACTING TALENT and maybe a golden-throated NARRATOR!

  • To drink NOTHING but PERRIER and CHAMPAGNE

  • Sacrificial goats to maintain my youthful complexion

Also, if my campaign is a big success it will encourage me to continue working! Any funds going past what I need to support myself this summer will not only help this project, but will go forward to let me work on my next animation!

Yes, Mom, I’m going to get a “real” job too. Yes I am grateful for everything you’ve done to support me. I’m trying to follow my life’s dream, Mom. I love you too. I’m about to put away the dishes let me finish writing my proposal.


So, what if it doesn’t work out?

The good news is, I intend to make this film and release it online for everyone to watch for free with or without your help! Your contribution will help me make it faster and better, but most importantly it will let me know that there is someone out there who believes in what I'm trying to do. Moral support goes a long way.

The bad news is, it’s totally possible that I will completely fail and not make Ssrids at all. If I don’t reach my funding goal, or if I run into unforeseen problems, I might not have the time to finish. And that’s a real bummer! I really don’t want to disappoint y’all; not only would I be failing you but I would discredit all my dreams of being a proper animator and of making another successful fundraiser in the future. In honesty, even if you only contribute one dollar, that dollar puts a lot of pressure on me to maintain your trust. If I fail, I might keep your dollar, but I will probably never see another dollar from you again.

In order to keep myself on track, I am keeping the scope of my film limited, and the style is very deliberately loose and unrefined. As a backer, you will be able to see behind-the-scenes updates on my daily progress, and I hope that my transparency will keep me accountable and on-task. I don’t have experience making this kind of film before, so it’s completely possible it might take much longer than I intended. Even if production on Ssrids takes six months, or twelve months, instead of three, I hope that that extra time goes into making the kind of film you expect from me.


How else can I help?

If this project is interesting to you, absolutely share this page! You can use the social media sharing buttons on the upper-left corner of this campaign to spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, Google+, or share the link directly! If you want to be old-school, print out and drop off flyers at your local art center, school, and coffee shops! The more eyes that see this campaign (or the more of those neato braille computer keyboards that tap out my name), the more I can raise and the more I can rest easy and spend my days working instead of worrying about reaching my funding goal.

If this project rings with you and you want to contribute your own work, let me know! I’m not planning on managing a whole team, but if I reach a comfortable funding level, I might hire you out for help on backgrounds, sound, music, and so on.

If nothing else, feel free to talk to me! Even if you can't contribute financially, your thoughts and suggestions are valuable. Hot tips, earnest feelings, and good vibes are always welcome!

THANK YOU for reading! Until next time,

Jude
