Our film follows a group of female lawyers, activists, MP's and survivors as they tackle this violence head-on; fighting to change the law and to bring violent husbands to justice.  It will explore both sides of these stories and hear the perpetrators own reflections on their actions. 


FILM HAKKINDA

Dying to Divorce" sayfasına hoşgeldiniz! "Dying to Divorce" Türkiye'de kadına karşı şiddet ve kadın cinayetlerine karşı mücadele veren kadınlar hakkında yeni bir gözlemci belgeseldir. Geçen yıl Türkiye'de, çoğu eşlerinden boşanmak isteyen 300'ün üzerinde kadın öldürüldü. Ve katiller eşlerinin onları "tahrik ettiğini" öne sürüp yasadaki boşluklardan yararlanmayı başardılar. Belgeselimiz bir grup kadın avukat, aktivist, milletvekeli ve eşlerinin şiddetine uğramalarına rağmen hayatta kalmayı başaran kadınları şiddete son vermeye, yasaları değiştirmeye ve adaleti sağlamaya çalışırken takip ediyor. Aynı zamanda, hikayenin diğer tarafına da bakarak faillere de yaptıkları üzerine konuşma imkanı veriyor. Bu,Türkiye'deki kadınlar için tarihi bir zaman - sizin de bu yolculukta bize katılacağınızı umuyoruz. Şimdi bağışta bulunun




AN INTERNATIONAL COLLABORATION


The film is a collaboration between emerging director Chloe Fairweather, producer Sinead Kirwan, Tigerlily Productions and The Fuller Project For International Reporting in Istanbul. By supporting this story you are not only supporting women in Turkey but a strong group of female film-makers and journalists with an international reputation and the experience to create a fantastic film. 
HOW YOU CAN HELP?
We have already shot some footage for the film but we still have a lot to do. Over the summer, Chloe Fairweather, the director has been filming in Turkey with survivors of violence and following some extraordinary stories but to follow these stories to completion, we need your help.
DONATE/SHARE/WRITE
DONATE: Your donation will help us pay for:
- A Turkish field producer to work with on the ground in Turkey full-time. Their role will be to follow the complex legal elements of the story and make sure we are granted access to the important  legal and political institutions in Turkey that are crucial to understanding the struggle women face.
- The costs of flights and insurance for Chloe to go back and finish capturing the story. At this moment in time Turkey is quite unstable and we need finances to ensure our team can carry on filming safely and respond quickly to changing events. 
- Translations and research. Your donation will allow us to get all the material we have already shot translated and ready for editing.
- Wages for the team in general. We believe that people should be paid for their work and passion is not enough to live on. Your donation will support the team to give this project the time it deserves, while simultaneously being able to live and support themselves.  This is really important if we want to nurture new talent from a broad range of social backgrounds. 
SHARE: 
- Sharing this campaign on Facebook and Twitter helps to create a much bigger audience for our campaign then we can reach on our own. Every Like or Share, opens up hundreds of new possibilities for support. Follow us @dyingtodivorce or www.facebook.com/dyingtodivorce
- The more Likes and Retweets we get, the more attention the film gets from other funding bodies and organisations and more likely we are to hit our target.  What can seem like a small action, can make a huge difference.
WRITE: 
-Think about who might be interested in our campaign and write them a personal email with the link encouraging them to donate. Personal recommendations and endorsements are the number one way to build support for this project and help us raise the funds needed to continue. 
- If you are journalist, why not see if you can pitch a piece about the campaign or profile this fantastic all-female team?
OUR CONTRIBUTORS
At the film’s heart will be two very different survivors: Arzu, a rural mother of six living on a remote farm, who was shot by her husband and Kubra, a glamorous Bloomberg newsreader, who has been left with a brain injury after alledgedly being attacked by her husband, a claim he is denying. We will follow their journey of recovery and as they struggle to bring violent husbands to justice in a court system that feels stacked against them. The film will also question whether real change can be achieved by changing the law alone.
WHY MAKE THIS FILM?
On average two women a week are killed by their partners or ex-partners in the UK. A third of all women in the US are murdered by their partners or ex-partners. Over 150 women have been killed in Turkey this year. This is an emergency situation, an epidemic that needs to end now. Violence against women is a pervasive, global problem and  we want to make this film to show that women can fight back and create positive change.
By using contrasting stories that cut across Turkish society we hope to  break some of the stereotypes about women affected by domestic violence and show the great strength it takes to break free.  We want to make a film that brings the viewer right to the heart of these cases and spark a global conversation about what we can all do to stop violence against women.  Most importantly, we want to give a platform to women to tell their own story.

WHY NOW?
Turkey is a country in flux. In June, 97 female MP’s were elected to parliament. However, another election has been called for November that could undo that victory. We believe this is a key moment in history for women in Turkey and the stakes are very high.  Following this story now will allow us to give a voice to people on the ground, capture a dramatic piece of social history and will allow us to create a tool that can be used by campaigners and activists going forward. This story is unfolding as we speak and if we fail to capture it now, the opportunity will be lost, along with the individual lessons and experiences of the survivors on the frontline of this fight.

THE TEAM 




 
DIRECTOR: CHLOE FAIRWEATHER

Chloe Fairweather is a BBC trained documentary filmmaker and video journalist specialising in social documentaries about sensitive and important stories. She produced and directed the critically acclaimed BAFTA and Grierson Shortlisted MR ALZHEIMERS AND ME for CBBC, filming from the point of children whose grandparents have dementia. She spent a year in Birmingham as a DV Director with NHS and Social Services making the Grierson and Royal Television Society nominated BBC 2 series PROTECTING OUR PARENTS. She  co-produced BBC 2’s MY CHILD THE RIOTER with BAFTA and Emmy award winning Director Olly Lambert. 



PRODUCER: SINEAD KIRWAN
Sinead Kirwan, the film’s producer, previously worked on STILL THE ENEMY WITHIN, a critically acclaimed crowdfunded documentary examining the impact of the 1984-85 UK miners’ strike on ordinary people.  The film won the 2014 Sheffield Documentary Audience Award, a nomination for a Focal Award, was selected for Hotdocs in Toronto & shortlisted for a Grierson award. It was screened in independent cinemas across the UK becoming one of the top-grossing documentaries of 2014. 


EXECUTIVE PRODUCER: CHRISTINA ASQUITH
Christina Asquith is an independent journalist based out of Istanbul, Turkey, with a focus on investigative reporting of women's lives, with articles published in New York Times, ELLE Magazine, The Guardian, Washington Post and others.Christina is co-director of The Fuller Project For International Reporting, a multi-media team of journalists dedicated to in-depth reporting on the traditionally overlooked and underrepresented role of women in foreign policy.  Recently, she executively produced two short documentaries on Syrian and Turkish women, shown in the NYTimes and ELLE.com. Prior to Istanbul, Christina covered the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan as a freelancer for 10 years, writing, "Sisters in War", published by Random House in 2009. Christina started her career at The New York Times Boston Bureau, and was a staffer at The Philadelphia Inquirer.


EXECUTIVE PRODUCER: NATASHA DACK OJUMU
Natasha Dack-Ojumu is co-managing director of
Tigerlily Productions, a UK based company producing consistently innovative work in
documentary, drama and feature films. Natasha has produced several successful films
includin SHE, A CHINESE, the BAFTA and RTS award winning feature length drama,
PLEASURELAND (C4), the critically acclaimed documentaries BLACK POWER SALUTE
(BBC), AFTER THE APOCALYPSE (C4), PLUS TUBULAR BELLS (BBC4)and Caligari Film
Prize (Berlin), Best International Documentary (HotDocs) and Best British
Feature Documentary (BritDoc) winner 37 USES FOR A DEAD SHEEP. Natasha also
executive produced the BAFTA nominated MCCULLIN and TRANSGENDER AND OVER 60 (Newsnight).  
WHAT NEXT?

We already have two major broadcasters
that are interested in screening this film. We aim to have several others
lined-up by the time the film is finished. At the same time, we are developing a large community screening plan, to make sure the film has maximum impact in the areas it is needed most.   We are already in discussions with universities and
colleges across Turkey about screening this film, as part of their curriculum's.  We are also developing a program to get the film seen in places with high-levels of
domestic violence.  We would like to replicate this in the UK.
We want this film to be a real tool for change and education on the issue of domestic violence and women’s rights both in and outside Turkey. Both director Chloe Fairweather and producer Sinead Kirwan have an extensive backgrounds in creating films that have strong educational and social benefit. Alongside this, the Fuller Project For International Reporting gives this film a connection to audiences of influential and important people across the world, who can increase pressure on the the Turkish government to try and tackle this issue. 
With your support, we can support women in Turkey, share their stories globally, and create a positive change.  Please donate to this project.

story:
Delivery Girl is a short dark comedy film. It revolves around the events that occur just after a pizza delivery girl is struck by a car. We are first introduced to siblings, Theo and Jayne, Theo being the driver of the car is having to come to terms with the fact that he's hit someone, that worry very quickly fades away when he realises that the girl he hit mistakes him for someone else. He takes this as a perfect opportunity to confess his love to an unconscious and possibly dead girl.

Meanwhile, Best friends Pip and Charlie and struggling to ease their boredom. Slightly drunk and very hungry, they decide to call up the Pizza company ready to complain about how long their order is taking. Once notified that the girl has been hit, Charlie takes it especially hard, he believes that he is the reason for this girl's demise and things spiral out of hand from there.

Delivery Girl takes a look at how people react to situations and scenarios in different way, it is often the case that comedy can stem from tragedy and this is what we would like to bring to the silver screen. These two separate scenarios come together in a comical yet dark way and we aim to bring out the characters and the unconventional forms of dealing with these situations to life.

(Logo Art for the Pizza Brand)


Theo

Is a typical teenage boy. He's starting to get more and more respect as an adult by his parents so he is starting to become a more of a dominant character, especially when it comes to being with his sister, though he still has some of the insecurities about girls that teenage boys usually do.

Jayne

Jayne is a few years older than her brother Theo, she has always been able to have her way with her brother but is now starting to realise that as he's gotten older, he's caught on to her tricks.

Bridget

Bridget is the unfortunate girl at the center of all of this panic. She is the delivery girl who has been struck by Theo. Brigit, is very pretty and quite confident, however she doesn't let her looks dictate how she treats people.

Charlie

Charlie is the smarter one when it comes to him and Pip. He lacks confidence, however and is not good at dealing with unexpected situations. When finding out that the Delivery Girl has been hit he takes it to heart and believes that he is the reason for her death.

Pip

Pip is Charlie's best friend, he is the complete opposite. Pip is a strong, dominant alpha male type character. Instead of reassuring Charlie that it's not his fault, he allows him to keep panicking and overreact.


We're a very big team spanning a total of 30 cast & crew members when shooting. Here's a selection of some of our Heads of Department.

Director

Gerald is a very confident individual who has experience in the different roles involved in film-making. Coming from a background of acting, he didn’t realize his love for being the camera till his mid teens. “Directing wasn’t something i’d considered until late in my studying when I tried it for the first. From that experience, I started to read more and into it and start practicing the art. I found that it came naturally for me when I loved the story to then direct it which is the case with Delivery Girl.”

Writer

Ryan is a talented comedic writer with multiple genres in his locker, he has developed online content previously and now looks to develop his writing talents on screen. “Half the time I hate writing, then during the other half I hate writing more."

Producer

Ryan is an internationally traversed filmmaker, broadening his horizons in film genres as he aims to create a wide variety, of films. “Film-making is a mode of visual storytelling, stories are what make memories, history, experiences and emotions, without stories to tell, the World wouldn’t be what it is today”  

Director of Photography

A student in cinematography, Matt has developed a range of technical skills of which he is most passionate about, his passion has stemmed from watching countless behind the scenes footage of some of his favourite films. His inspiration comes from the image on screen and how real life can be manipulated through the lens. “The best part of film-making is you get to really work your imagination and then after all the hard work you get to sit back and enjoy what you’ve made”

Editor

Every good comedy works because of a whole range of elements, however, without having a good edit, the comedy that on paper had you in stitches could end up as 'Just another student film'. Diego has taken up the challenge of editing this film because not only does he believe in the story, he can see how much of an impact it will have on the audience. "I am striving to be able to edit a film which will have the audiences crying with laughter for a long time to come."

Production Designer

Edison, filmmaker and actor, has always had an interest for the Arts and for Film. For Edison is all about expressing himself creatively, and he is determined to make the visuals for "Delivery Girl" as efficient and creative as they can be, supporting the script and the story. "Film is like one of the ultimate forms of Art because it combines so many Art elements many people are not even aware of".


Making a short film of quality and high standard can drive up a budget. Our film will involve multiple Vehicles some of which will be on fire as well as an Ambulance. With a Cast and Crew reaching almost 30 members we’ll be in need of transport, supplies and catering to help the filming process exceed our creative vision and make sure it goes smoothly. We are in need of £6500, in order to propel us on our filming adventure!

 In return for you generous contribution we have a great deal of perks for your investment! That pizza logo you just saw could be yours on your own personalized mug along with fridge magnets and special deliveries! Our one of kind Canvas Prints for the film will offer the ultimate fan the ultimate perk of all!  

Here’s a breakdown of where the money will go:



We will be shooting with the very versatile Canon C300. This camera will be in the hands of our talented DOP & camera team, we will be using a selection of vintage lenses with it for the look our director wants. 

Other Equipment involved will include numerous lighting equipment along with a MoVI M5 rig, jib, slider and a specialized tripod head to name a few. These items will be needed to capture the artistic shots we have pre-visualized and planned. 


Locations, Pyrotechnics and Expensive Cars are just a few of the challenges that we are faced with. Our location setting requires us to have the Location 1 (Country Lane) within a close distance of Location 2 (Pip and Charlie's House). Finding an owner of a house suitable for the script and letting us use it for a period of 7 days is more difficult than it sounds. Ambulance hire may be an expensive cost for filming but it is a necessary part of our story a long with two similar looking cars, one that will be torched and lit on fire. We are more than confident we can secure these props and locations with your contribution.


(Minamilist Concept Art)

If you can’t make a financial investment to our project, don't worry about it! There’s so many ways you can further our project, check out our social media pages, like subscribe and follow and most importantly share our project with everyone! Word of mouth is a great way to tell others! We’ll love you so much for it!

facebook.com/OfficialDeliveryGirl

www.instagram.com/official_deliverygirl

www.twitter.com/DeliveryGirlGo?lang=en-gb

deliverygirl007@gmail.com



Many thanks from the Delivery Girl Team!

story:
Résumé - Pitch

Le bonheur d'un jeune couple, Tobie et Isa, est chamboulé par l'arrivée du cancer dans la vie de celle-ci. Film basé sur une histoire vraie, Rôle de soutien est une exploration à la fois réaliste et poétique de l'impuissance que vivent ceux qui accompagnent les gens malades, ainsi qu'un testament du pouvoir et de l'importance du positivisme face aux grandes épreuves de la vie. Filmé de manière réaliste et en lumière naturelle, proche du cinéma-vérité, Rôle de soutien sera un drame poignant et inspirant. Le récit s'échelonne sur plusieurs années et se concentre sur les hauts et les bas d'un couple qui traverse la maladie. Ne sombrant jamais dans le misérabilisme, ce court métrage offrira au public une variété d'émotions qui le feront passer du rire aux larmes. Rôle de soutien, un film d'amour moderne proche de la réalité qui se tient à distance des clichés et des stéréotypes. 

The happiness of a young couple, consisting of Tobie and Isa, is shaken up with the arrival of cancer in her life. Based on a true story, Supporting Role is a poetic and realistic exploration about the powerless experience of accompanying a patient. It's also a testament to the power of positivity when facing some of the greatest challenges of life. Filmed in a realistic way under natural light, close to cinema-verite, Supporting Role will be a heartbreaking and inspiring drama. The story is told over the course of a few years and is focusing on the ups and the downs of a couple going through the battle against cancer. Never wanting to fall into misery, this short film will have the audience experience a mix of emotions, from laughter to tears, but never leaving sight of its goal: to be a modern love story, close to real life, far from all the clichés and stereotypes.
  
Les deux acteurs - The two actors:

Bryan Morneau


Diplômé de l’École Supérieure de théâtre de l’UQAM, Bryan collabore avec Omnibus dans L’amour est un opéra muet, Burlesque, Jabbarnack!, Fatal et dans Rue Fable en 2014. Il a aussi joué le rôle marquant de Jean dans Mademoiselle Julie de Strindberg. Il a collaboré au spectacle Sous les toxiques du théâtre Parminou et avec le Théâtre de la Vieille 17 à Ottawa dans Sahel. En théâtre jeune publique il a joué dans les spectacles du théâtre de l’Avant-Pays Une forêt dans la tête et La lune est à moi. À la télévision, il était le Prince d’Argent dans Kaboum, a joué dans Apparences et Les Rescapés et dans un épisode de Toute la Vérité. Acteur d'une grande intensité, il saura capturer les tourments et les paradoxes du personnage complexe qu'est Tobie.

Bryan studied and graduated from the superior school of theatre at UQUAM university in Montreal. He collaborated with Omnibus with various theatre productions such as L'amour est un opéra muet, Burlesque, Jabbarnak!, Fatal and Rue Fable in 2014. On television, he played ''Le prince d'argent'' in Kaboum and also played in various popular French-Canadian tv-series such as Apparences, Les Rescapés and Toute la vérité. As a really deep and intense actor, he will be perfect to capture the complexities of the character of Tobie.

Sabrina Gagné Lussier


Diplômée du Cégep de St-Hyacinthe, exploration théâtrale, Sabrina a aussi suivie plusieurs ''coachings'' d'acting avec entre autres Charlotte Laurier, Louise Boisvert et Mélanie Pilon. Elle a participée à plusieurs défis kino et jouée une troisième rôle dans le film Qu'est-ce qu'on fait ici ? réalisé par Julie Hivon. Elle est également mannequin professionnelle pour de nombreuses campagnes publicitaires pour le Marché des possibles et la compagnie de bijoux Crazy Lily. Comédienne d'un très grand naturel, elle insuffle intensité, charisme et authenticité à chacun de ses rôles, ce qui sera parfait pour le personnage inspirant d'Isa. 

Sabrina graduated from the Cegep of Saint-Hyacinthe in the theatre departement. She studied in numerous acting classes under great acting coaches such as Charlotte Laurier and Louise Boisvert. She had a third role in the feature film ''Qu'est-ce qu'on fait ici?'' from director Julie Hivon. She is also a professional model who worked with various compagnies such as Marché des possibles and Crazy Lily. A young actress with tremendous potentiel, she gives authenticity, charisma and intensity to every performances that she gives. That why she is the perfect candidate to portray a character as beautiful and inspiring as Isa. 


L'impact et l'utilisation des fonds amassés - The impact and the monetary reason for the campaign

Au-delà du fait de vouloir créer une oeuvre d'art qui touchera les gens, nous désirons réaliser un film inspirant. Beaucoup de personnes ont vécu le drame du cancer dans leur entourage et notre but est d'offrir une réflexion honnête et sentie sur l'impact que celui-ci peut avoir sur les proches du patient. Le film présentera un personnage atteint par la maladie fort et positif tout en démontrant que l’optimisme, la détermination et le courage peuvent être des atout déterminants dans ce combat. Rôle de soutien s'annonce également comme un exutoire pour le réalisateur Tobie Garceau, qui a vécu cette épreuve en compagnie de son ex-copine, qui a survécue. Il s'agit d'une occasion en or pour enfin clore ce chapitre de sa vie avec grâce, coeur et sensibilité.

More than just the desire of creating a work of art that will move and affect everyone, we have the will to make an inspiring movie. A large number of us know someone or have experienced the challenge that is cancer, and we wish to deliver an honest reflection on the impact that it can have on the relatives and friends of the victim. The movie will show a character who is sick, yet strong and positive. It will demonstrate that optimism, determination and courage can be the strongest of all assets in people suffering from this illness. Supporting Role will also be an outlet for the Director, Tobie Garceau, who went through this great challenge alongside his ex-girlfriend, who is now a survivor. This is a golden opportunity for him to turn the page of this part of his life with grace, heart and sensitivity.


Budget  (20% des fonds amassés seront versés directement à la Société Canadienne du Cancer)

Nous demandons 10 000 $ pour l'ensemble du tournage. Ce montant sera divisé de la manière suivante.

  • 3500 $ seront utilisés pour payer tous les acteurs du film qui donneront de leur temps jusqu'en mai prochain. Ils seront sollicités pendant plusieurs jours et avec les exigences de ces rôles, il me semble impératif de les payer convenablement. 
  • 1500 $ seront utilisés pour payer la location des lieux, dont une salle d'hôpital, un appartement et plusieurs accessoires de tournage nécessaires à la direction artistique du film. Notre but est de faire un film très réaliste, donc l'attention portée aux détails sera très présente. 
  • 2500 $ seront utilisés pour les besoins techniques. L'achat de matériel de caméra, de son et d'éclairage, ainsi que le tarif des techniciens seront inclus dans le prix final. Nous désirons obtenir un résultat professionnel et c'est le montant qu'il nous faut pour y arriver. 
  • 1500 $ seront utilisés pour payer la musique originale du film. Nous allons enregistrer des compositions en studio avec des musiciens professionnels, dont un pianiste, un quatuor de cordes, un guitariste et une chanteuse. 
  • 1000 $  seront utilisés pour fournir la nourriture et permettre les déplacements de l'équipe durant la totalité du tournage.

Budget  (20% of the money received will be donated to the Canadien Cancer Institute)  

We ask for 10 000 $ for the whole shoot. This is how it's gonna be used:

  • 3500 $ is gonna be used to pay all the actors for the few months of the shoot. I really want to pay them well because of the emotional intensity of the job required. 
  • 1500 $ is gonna be used to rent difference locations, such as an hospital room and different props.
  • 2500 $ is gonna be used to buy or rent equipments, as well as to pay the technicians. We want the movie to look professional, and this is the amount of money that we need to achieve that look.  
  • 1500 $ is gonna be used to record professional music for the film. We're gonna hire musicians for the studio recording sessions, such as an a pianist, a singer, a guitar player and a quartet.
  • 1000 $  is gonna be used to pay food and gaz for the cast and crew for a year. 

Merci et tentons d'inspirer et de toucher nos futurs spectateurs! :)
Thank you and let's try to inspire and touch our future viewers ! :)
Love,
Tobie Garceau
story_txt:
Résumé - Pitch

Le bonheur d'un jeune couple, Tobie et Isa, est chamboulé par l'arrivée du cancer dans la vie de celle-ci. Film basé sur une histoire vraie, Rôle de soutien est une exploration à la fois réaliste et poétique de l'impuissance que vivent ceux qui accompagnent les gens malades, ainsi qu'un testament du pouvoir et de l'importance du positivisme face aux grandes épreuves de la vie. Filmé de manière réaliste et en lumière naturelle, proche du cinéma-vérité, Rôle de soutien sera un drame poignant et inspirant. Le récit s'échelonne sur plusieurs années et se concentre sur les hauts et les bas d'un couple qui traverse la maladie. Ne sombrant jamais dans le misérabilisme, ce court métrage offrira au public une variété d'émotions qui le feront passer du rire aux larmes. Rôle de soutien, un film d'amour moderne proche de la réalité qui se tient à distance des clichés et des stéréotypes. 
The happiness of a young couple, consisting of Tobie and Isa, is shaken up with the arrival of cancer in her life. Based on a true story, Supporting Role is a poetic and realistic exploration about the powerless experience of accompanying a patient. It's also a testament to the power of positivity when facing some of the greatest challenges of life. Filmed in a realistic way under natural light, close to cinema-verite, Supporting Role will be a heartbreaking and inspiring drama. The story is told over the course of a few years and is focusing on the ups and the downs of a couple going through the battle against cancer. Never wanting to fall into misery, this short film will have the audience experience a mix of emotions, from laughter to tears, but never leaving sight of its goal: to be a modern love story, close to real life, far from all the clichés and stereotypes.  

Les deux acteurs - The two actors:

Bryan Morneau

Diplômé de l’École Supérieure de théâtre de l’UQAM, Bryan collabore avec Omnibus dans L’amour est un opéra muet, Burlesque, Jabbarnack!, Fatal et dans Rue Fable en 2014. Il a aussi joué le rôle marquant de Jean dans Mademoiselle Julie de Strindberg. Il a collaboré au spectacle Sous les toxiques du théâtre Parminou et avec le Théâtre de la Vieille 17 à Ottawa dans Sahel. En théâtre jeune publique il a joué dans les spectacles du théâtre de l’Avant-Pays Une forêt dans la tête et La lune est à moi. À la télévision, il était le Prince d’Argent dans Kaboum, a joué dans Apparences et Les Rescapés et dans un épisode de Toute la Vérité. Acteur d'une grande intensité, il saura capturer les tourments et les paradoxes du personnage complexe qu'est Tobie.

Bryan studied and graduated from the superior school of theatre at UQUAM university in Montreal. He collaborated with Omnibus with various theatre productions such as L'amour est un opéra muet, Burlesque, Jabbarnak!, Fatal and Rue Fable in 2014. On television, he played ''Le prince d'argent'' in Kaboum and also played in various popular French-Canadian tv-series such as Apparences, Les Rescapés and Toute la vérité. As a really deep and intense actor, he will be perfect to capture the complexities of the character of Tobie.

Sabrina Gagné Lussier


Diplômée du Cégep de St-Hyacinthe, exploration théâtrale, Sabrina a aussi suivie plusieurs ''coachings'' d'acting avec entre autres Charlotte Laurier, Louise Boisvert et Mélanie Pilon. Elle a participée à plusieurs défis kino et jouée une troisième rôle dans le film Qu'est-ce qu'on fait ici ? réalisé par Julie Hivon. Elle est également mannequin professionnelle pour de nombreuses campagnes publicitaires pour le Marché des possibles et la compagnie de bijoux Crazy Lily. Comédienne d'un très grand naturel, elle insuffle intensité, charisme et authenticité à chacun de ses rôles, ce qui sera parfait pour le personnage inspirant d'Isa. 

Sabrina graduated from the Cegep of Saint-Hyacinthe in the theatre departement. She studied in numerous acting classes under great acting coaches such as Charlotte Laurier and Louise Boisvert. She had a third role in the feature film ''Qu'est-ce qu'on fait ici?'' from director Julie Hivon. She is also a professional model who worked with various compagnies such as Marché des possibles and Crazy Lily. A young actress with tremendous potentiel, she gives authenticity, charisma and intensity to every performances that she gives. That why she is the perfect candidate to portray a character as beautiful and inspiring as Isa. 



L'impact et l'utilisation des fonds amassés - The impact and the monetary reason for the campaign
Au-delà du fait de vouloir créer une oeuvre d'art qui touchera les gens, nous désirons réaliser un film inspirant. Beaucoup de personnes ont vécu le drame du cancer dans leur entourage et notre but est d'offrir une réflexion honnête et sentie sur l'impact que celui-ci peut avoir sur les proches du patient. Le film présentera un personnage atteint par la maladie fort et positif tout en démontrant que l’optimisme, la détermination et le courage peuvent être des atout déterminants dans ce combat. Rôle de soutien s'annonce également comme un exutoire pour le réalisateur Tobie Garceau, qui a vécu cette épreuve en compagnie de son ex-copine, qui a survécue. Il s'agit d'une occasion en or pour enfin clore ce chapitre de sa vie avec grâce, coeur et sensibilité.

More than just the desire of creating a work of art that will move and affect everyone, we have the will to make an inspiring movie. A large number of us know someone or have experienced the challenge that is cancer, and we wish to deliver an honest reflection on the impact that it can have on the relatives and friends of the victim. The movie will show a character who is sick, yet strong and positive. It will demonstrate that optimism, determination and courage can be the strongest of all assets in people suffering from this illness. Supporting Role will also be an outlet for the Director, Tobie Garceau, who went through this great challenge alongside his ex-girlfriend, who is now a survivor. This is a golden opportunity for him to turn the page of this part of his life with grace, heart and sensitivity.



Budget  (20% des fonds amassés seront versés directement à la Société Canadienne du Cancer)
Nous demandons 10 000 $ pour l'ensemble du tournage. Ce montant sera divisé de la manière suivante.


3500 $ seront utilisés pour payer tous les acteurs du film qui donneront de leur temps jusqu'en mai prochain. Ils seront sollicités pendant plusieurs jours et avec les exigences de ces rôles, il me semble impératif de les payer convenablement. 

1500 $ seront utilisés pour payer la location des lieux, dont une salle d'hôpital, un appartement et plusieurs accessoires de tournage nécessaires à la direction artistique du film. Notre but est de faire un film très réaliste, donc l'attention portée aux détails sera très présente. 

2500 $ seront utilisés pour les besoins techniques. L'achat de matériel de caméra, de son et d'éclairage, ainsi que le tarif des techniciens seront inclus dans le prix final. Nous désirons obtenir un résultat professionnel et c'est le montant qu'il nous faut pour y arriver. 

1500 $ seront utilisés pour payer la musique originale du film. Nous allons enregistrer des compositions en studio avec des musiciens professionnels, dont un pianiste, un quatuor de cordes, un guitariste et une chanteuse. 

1000 $  seront utilisés pour fournir la nourriture et permettre les déplacements de l'équipe durant la totalité du tournage.


Budget  (20% of the money received will be donated to the Canadien Cancer Institute)  



We ask for 10 000 $ for the whole shoot. This is how it's gonna be used:



3500 $ is gonna be used to pay all the actors for the few months of the shoot. I really want to pay them well because of the emotional intensity of the job required. 


1500 $ is gonna be used to rent difference locations, such as an hospital room and different props.


2500 $ is gonna be used to buy or rent equipments, as well as to pay the technicians. We want the movie to look professional, and this is the amount of money that we need to achieve that look.  


1500 $ is gonna be used to record professional music for the film. We're gonna hire musicians for the studio recording sessions, such as an a pianist, a singer, a guitar player and a quartet.


1000 $  is gonna be used to pay food and gaz for the cast and crew for a year. 


Merci et tentons d'inspirer et de toucher nos futurs spectateurs! :)
Thank you and let's try to inspire and touch our future viewers ! :)
Love,
Tobie Garceau

story:
Over 7,000 refugees in Calais are living in flimsy tents, which are often just sheets of plastic thrown over boxes.



The Challenge

With the mounting humanitarian crisis in Calais, our aim was to design a building that could provide safe and secure shelter for the refugees over the winter period.

The key areas we identified that needed addressing with any design were:

    • Good thermal capacity - To keep users warm in winter, and cool in the summer
    • Watertight – To keep users dry and prevent damage to the structure or the user’s possessions
    • Lifespan – To ensure that ongoing costs are not incurred for the repair or replacement of the shelters
    • Transport – The shelters must be easily transportable to the point of need, and where access to the site is not clear
    • Installation – The shelters would need to be easy and quick to install to meet demand and keep any labour costs low
    • Cost – The price of the shelters needs to be as low as possible to ensure more units can be provided for those in need
    • Secure – The shelters will need to offer security for vulnerable people and their possessions
    • Modular – Any designs would need to be done in a modular form so varying sizes of buildings can be provided to meet requirements
    • Environmentally friendly – It is important that designs should not aim to avert one crisis whilst adding to another
    • Dignity – Often overlooked, we feel it is important to offer the users dignity to raise moral and hope. More importantly to be treated like a human being not an animal


Our Solution


The new refugee shelters we have designed addresses all the criteria raised, and offer a clever and more robust solution to the crisis.

We quickly came to the conclusion that the best method for construction of shelters is a closed panel timber frame structure. This will enable us to offer shelters that not only have a lifespan similar to any new build brick building, but also conform to current UK building regulations for thermal performance.

There are 2 main ways of making timber frame panels. The first is a SIP (self-insulated panel). This system has great thermal properties but is very costly to produce. Due to this we have opted for a traditional timber frame panel which will be closed and heavily insulated.

The shelters will be made in a very similar format to any traditional building which includes:

Floor & Roof– A fully insulated and structurally sound floor and roof cassette. This will be heavily insulated and allow air flow under the building keep it separated from the ground.

Walls – These will be closed panel insulated walls. Made from a 90mm CSL treated timber stud frame, they will be fully insulated and finished with OSB internally and Tricoya (water resistant wood) externally.

Door – An entrance door will be made in the same manner as the wall panels to offer better thermal properties. Locks and handles can be placed on these doors.

Windows – Toughened plastic will be used to allow natural light into the building, with fully insulated shutters provided.

To answer how the design meets the needs of the refugees we will go back to the main criteria raised for the shelters:

    • Watertight – The use of Tricoya on the external elevations and roof will stop water entering the buildings.
    •  Lifespan – The lifespan of the buildings will be 20yrs however we expect them to last longer than this.
    • Transport – The shelters can be flat packed in panels the same size as sheet materials of 1.2m x 2.4m. This means they can be easily placed on a pallet for delivery.
    • Installation – The shelters can be quickly installed via a tongue and groove panel system. Panels can be lifted by 2 people into place and held together with a few screws. We estimate a 6 person shelter could be constructed by 2 people in circa 3 hours.
    • Cost – The price of housing 1 person will be under £250 thanks to our trade partners, and by getting labour supplied by Preston College. This means the cost of housing one person in a habitable structure would be circa £12.50 per year over the lifetime of the shelter.
    • Secure – The shelters will as robust as any traditional building, and have lockable entrances.
    • Modular – As the design works via interlocking panels of 1.2m x 2.4m, we are able to create varying sizes of buildings to meet demand. The buildings could also be taken down after their usage and shipped to other locations.
    • Environmentally friendly – All materials used in construction are either from sustainable sources, or recycled. This ranges from FSC wood to recycled plastic bottles for the insulation. The building will also be 100% recyclable at the end of its life.
    • Dignity – By offering a building that is fit for purpose, and meets the basic requirements that we ourselves would expect, we offer the refuges the dignity of their own home. This will raise moral levels and keep the hope of a better life alive. As we have made the design modular we are also able to construct larger communal buildings to be used for religious practises and education. These larger buildings can also double up as shelter when not in use.


The Impact

You will be helping people who, through no fault of their own, find themselves without safe warm shelters this winter.

Every contribution no matter how small will help someone stay safe and warm this winter.

The situation in Calais is heart-breaking and shocking, especially that it is happening in the middle of Europe.  This is a real crisis that requires real action and you can help make this a reality through your support.



Risks & Challenges

The team including colleagues from The Halimah Trust, Pod Living Ltd and Proddio are carrying out a reconnaissance visit to Calais this month, where they will meet with L’Augerge des Migrant (Calais based charity) to work out the logistics.

This is a not for profit project. None of the partners involved will be making a profit. In fact a lot of the materials and resources have been donated to bring down the cost of the shelters.

There will be challenges such as:

  • The ground in the Calais camp is uneven and difficult to build on. There are many trees and shrubs and wind from the sea, as it is very close to the shoreline.
  • We will work closely with L’Auberge des Migrant to identify the most vulnerable in the camp and try our best to provide shelters according to priority needs. The Halimah Trust has worked with L’Auberge des Migrant over the summer to deliver food aid to the refugees. So they have a good understanding of the needs.
  • The biggest challenge is that time is against us and the weather is already becoming very cold. The refugees are from much warmer climates so they will find it especially difficult to cope in freezing temperatures as they have never experienced this before.
  • In addition to the shelters, we also hope to build a Mosque and Multi-faith facilities for the refugees, because for many, their only hope is through prayer.

However small your donation, it will make a difference.  But even if you can’t help to pay for the shelters, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Ask everyone you know to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools and post the campaign on your Facebook, twitter and Linkedin profiles!

On behalf of us on the Winter shelters for Refugees project, THANK YOU!



The Beds we are hoping to also supply

story:
ABOUT THE FILM

Having no place to go and no one to turn to, Paul wanders around with his backpack, living off food he takes from trash cans. From time to time, Paul breaks into the houses of strangers for temporary comfort and a souvenir. 

He was a man without purpose, and lost his way until he finds himself on a mysterious path. Arriving at a lonesome house deep in the woods, Paul witnesses the suicide of Aiden, a man who seems to live in the house. Paul takes Aiden’s identity and stays inside the luxurious refuge with Aiden’s body as his companion. 

A revolutionary conversation with a dead man begins. 

As Paul learns more about Aiden, he starts to discover things about himself: What set him on this path, and how to escape it.


PROJECT INSPIRATION

Yesterday Was the Day We Died is a psychological drama about a discovery of one-self. It is a self-exploration story that digs deep into the oppressed personalities of  the human condition, and the frustration it carries. 
In order to express ourselves, we go through a long journey towards our becoming in both life and art. Finding and losing our identities could lead us onto many paths. 
This film takes us through the journey of a one man's personal transformation.


WHY THIS FILM MATTERS

At some point in everyone’s life, we’re not sure where we’re heading. Some struggle more than others to move forward.

This story explores a journey of what being human is all about. Searching for the answer to who we are, and who we want to be is a frustration each one of us faces in our lives. We either become what is expected of us or we embrace our true selves. 

Through this film, we share our thoughts and feelings about what scares and enlightens humanity, that is “Who am I really?”. With the surreal visuals and storytelling that we cherish, it is our goal to bring this unique genre back to filmmaking.


HOW YOU CAN HELP

Every contribution helps - whether it be through donation to our campaign, a share on social media, or sponsorships. Our cast and crew will be forever thankful for your support towards the creation of this story. 

Pepperman Productions proudly supports the local film community. 

The money raised will be used to complete this production, and promote the film on an international festival circuit. We take pride in hiring cast, crew, and production services that are local. With your help, we hope to be able to promote our homegrown talent by showcasing their work in our productions.

As a thank you for supporting us, we offer limited edition, customized gifts dependent on the amount of the donation. Here is an example of the art work you could receive as a contributor! Be sure to check out our perks page for more info.

In addition to receiving customized artwork, we are also offering our supporters the original soundtrack from this short, with an exclusive theme song produced by artist Velveta. Visit her SoundCloud and her Fanpage to hear a sample of her amazing work.


MEET THE CAST

BLAIR PENNER as PAUL

Blair is a Vancouver, British Columbia based actor. He is known for his work on the hit TV shows Supernatural, iZombie, Cedar Cove and Falling Skies. 

KRISTOPHER NIELSEN as AIDEN

Kris is a Vancouver, British Columbia based Actor and Producer, who is known for his work on hit TV shows Arrow, The Talent and Intruders. 

Kris also produced and star in a short film, The Character Study, which won Honorable Mention at the Slamdance Film Festival this year. Also, another short, Eye for an Eye, which premiered at the Cannes Film Festival earlier this spring.  He is currently in preproduction to direct and act in an upcoming short, Fall of Night.

YVONNE CHAPMAN as LYDIA

Yvonne Chapman is an Actress, Model and Producer based out of Vancouver, British Columbia. She has recently worked on projects for Nickelodeon, 20th Century FOX, and Julius R. Nasso Productions. She also loves to work on independent productions, and has been cast in several shorts in the past year, and has also recently been cast as a recurring on a local, hit web series in Vancouver. 

For more about Yvonne's projects and current updates, check out her actors page at www.ychapman.com .


MEET THE CREW

KRIT KOMKRICHWARAKOOL, WRITER & DIRECTOR

(Writer, Director and Editor)

Originally from Bangkok, Thailand, Krit is a graduate in communication design and has moved to Vancouver to pursue a film career in 2014. He has worked on many student short films as director and editor, and graduated in the Digital Film & Video program in 2015. His first notable works are Soulitude, Reminiscence, and Lynn's Lips.

“What we see in films is only what has been shown on the screen, but filmmaking is much more than just putting an image on a blank canvas. As a filmmaker, I am fascinated by the perfection of imperfection and the process of finding one-self through this medium. I am intrigued by the darkness of cinema and how images are constructed"

Check out his demo reel at: https://vimeo.com/131266532 .

ANDRES TORO, CO-DIRECTOR

(Co-Director)

Andres Toro is a passionate director and filmmaker. Currently based out of Vancouver, he is originally from Cali, Colombia. After studying and working in Graphic Design, Andres saved up enough money to pursue his dream of becoming a filmmaker. In 2014, he boarded a plane for Vancouver, Canada to complete a year of study at film school. During his education he developed the skills required to become a more complete director and filmmaker.

For Andres, his time studying and developing these projects has done nothing but strengthen the desire to build his career as a director.

Check out his demo reel at: https://vimeo.com/131726093 .


     

      Yvonne Chapman (Producer)                David Yao (Cinematographer)

     

Samuel Kim (Composer)                  Adriana Comsa (1st Assistant Director)

      

Elliott Goodier (Assistant Camera)           Yamil Salgado (Sound Designer)

Paul breaks into the houses of strangers for temporary comfort and a souvenir. 
He was a man without purpose, and lost his way until he finds himself on a
mysterious path. Arriving at a lonesome house deep in the woods, Paul

As Paul learns more about Aiden, he starts to discover things
about himself: What set him on this path, and how to escape it.






PROJECT INSPIRATION









Yesterday Was the Day We Died is a psychological drama about a discovery of one-self. It
is a self-exploration story that digs deep into the oppressed personalities
of  the human condition, and the frustration it carries. 
In order to express
ourselves, we go through a long journey towards our becoming in both life and art. Finding and losing our identities could lead us onto many paths. 
This film takes us through the journey of a one man's personal transformation. 

WHY THIS FILM MATTERS


At some point in everyone’s life, we’re not sure where we’re heading. Some struggle more than others to move forward.
This story explores a journey of what being human is all about. Searching for the answer to who we are, and who we want to be is a frustration each one of us faces in our lives. We either become what is expected of us or we embrace our true selves. 
Through this film, we share our thoughts and feelings about what scares and enlightens humanity, that is “Who am I really?”. With the surreal visuals and storytelling that we cherish, it is our goal to bring this unique genre back to filmmaking.

HOW YOU CAN HELP







Every contribution helps - whether it be through donation to our campaign, a share on social media, or sponsorships. Our cast and crew will be forever thankful for your support towards the creation of this story. 
Pepperman Productions proudly supports the local film community. 
The money raised will be used to complete this production, and promote the film on an international festival circuit. We take pride in hiring cast, crew, and production services that are local. With your help, we hope to be able to promote our homegrown talent by showcasing their work in our productions. 



As a thank you for supporting us, we offer limited edition, customized gifts dependent on the amount of the donation. Here is an example of the art work you could receive as a contributor! Be sure to check out our perks page for more info.



In addition to receiving customized artwork, we are also offering our supporters the original soundtrack from this short, with an exclusive theme song produced by artist Velveta. Visit her SoundCloud and her Fanpage to hear a sample of her amazing work.






MEET THE CAST   BLAIR PENNER as PAUL

Blair is a Vancouver, British Columbia based actor. He is known for his work on the hit TV shows Supernatural, iZombie, Cedar Cove and Falling Skies. 
   
KRISTOPHER NIELSEN as AIDEN

Kris is a Vancouver, British Columbia based Actor and Producer, who is known for his work on hit TV shows Arrow, The Talent and Intruders. 
Kris also produced and star in a short
film, The Character Study, which won
Honorable Mention at the Slamdance Film
Festival this year. Also, another short, Eye for an Eye, which premiered at the Cannes Film Festival earlier this spring.  He is currently in
preproduction to direct and act in an upcoming short, Fall of Night.
 
YVONNE CHAPMAN as LYDIA


Yvonne Chapman is an Actress, Model and Producer based out of Vancouver, British Columbia. She has recently worked on projects for Nickelodeon, 20th Century FOX, and Julius R. Nasso Productions. She also loves to work on independent productions, and has been cast in several shorts in the past year, and has also recently been cast as a recurring on a local, hit web series in Vancouver. 

For more about Yvonne's projects and current updates, check out her actors page at www.ychapman.com .
  
MEET THE CREW

KRIT KOMKRICHWARAKOOL, WRITER & DIRECTOR




(Writer, Director and Editor)
Originally from Bangkok, Thailand, Krit is
 a graduate in communication design and has moved to Vancouver to pursue
 a film career in 2014. He has worked on many student short films as 
director and editor, and graduated in the Digital Film & Video 
program in 2015. His first notable works are Soulitude, Reminiscence, 
and Lynn's Lips. 
“What we see in films is only what has 
been shown on the screen, but filmmaking is much more than just putting 
an image on a blank canvas. As a filmmaker, I am fascinated by the 
perfection of imperfection and the process of finding one-self through 
this medium. I am intrigued by the darkness of cinema and how images are
 constructed"
Check out his demo reel at: https://vimeo.com/131266532 . 
ANDRES TORO, CO-DIRECTOR


(Co-Director)
Andres Toro is a passionate director and filmmaker. Currently based out of Vancouver, he is originally from Cali, Colombia. After studying and working in Graphic Design, Andres saved up enough money to pursue his dream of becoming a filmmaker. In 2014, he boarded a plane for Vancouver, Canada to complete a year of study at film school. During his education he developed the skills required to become a more complete director and filmmaker.
For Andres, his time studying and developing these projects has done nothing but strengthen the desire to build his career as a director.
Check out his demo reel at: https://vimeo.com/131726093 .


            Yvonne Chapman (Producer)                David Yao (Cinematographer)
      Samuel Kim (Composer)                  Adriana Comsa (1st Assistant Director)
       Elliott Goodier (Assistant Camera)           Yamil Salgado (Sound Designer)

story:
About: Great Spaces is an architecture entertainment tv series that focuses on modern architectural design all over the world. We cover modern libraries, hotels, offices, houses, landmarks, schools, pretty much a majority of public spaces even as much as bridges. Full of stunts, challenges, celebrity appearances and features, "Great Spaces" is far more than a design show; you'll find no boring talk about Doric columns or impenetrable conversations about blueprints here. It's the passion of hosts that make it more than just a design program.

Plot Summary: 8  is an episodic film for the first season of Great Spaces. The bowtie-shaped 8 House 61,000 sqm mixed-use building of three different types of residential housing and 10,000 sqm of retail and offices comprises Denmark’s largest private development ever undertaken. The 8 House sits on the outer edge of the city as the southernmost outpost of Orestad. Rather than a traditional block, the 8 House stacks all ingredients of a lively urban neighborhood into horizontal layers of typologies connected by a continuous promenade and cycling path up to the 10th floor creating a three-dimensional urban neighborhood where suburban life merges with the energy of a city, where business and housing co-exist.

The Videographer: Julie Malmstrøm a creative video producer and photographer from Denmark. Mostly producing videos with cultural content: music videos, concerts, events, festivals, interviews, performances etc. She create videos and articles about sustainability, minimalism and the environment. She filmed and edited 8.

The Host: Delaine Isaac is the founder of Great Spaces, as well as a designer based in the New York Area. He created Great Spaces in the Spring of 2008 as a way to catalog his search for new ways to show spaces to the world through entertainment, humor, and intellectually conscious content. Educated at Rutgers University and NYIT. With office experience from Dattner Architects,Tronic Studio and on site experience with Isaac/ Associates, Jimmy Dumas Architecture, and UAI, he loves everything about design. He is currently pursuing a design practice with the interests of social media, video and film. Being taught by professors from Columbia GSAPP, Harvard GSD and esteemed architects such as Elizabeth Terragini which so far has been good for his obsession with traveling to various countries to share spaces you. 

Status: We shot the film in Copenhagen, Denmark in August and are currently in postproduction right now, about to begin the sound design, sound mix and score. The film will be complete by February 1st to start submitting to film festivals, TV networks and potential sponsors. But in order for us to finish it and get it seen by the widest audience possible, we really need your support!

Film Festival Submission Fees: A large amount of the postproduction budget will be used to submit to film festivals all over the world. These submission costs can range from $10 to $90 depending on the festival. When making a film the end goal is obviously to get it seen by as many people and audiences as possible. And with a low-budget independent film like this, screening at film festivals is the best way to do that. The reason film festivals are important because independent filmmakers might remain forever in obscurity were it not for film festivals. These annual events, where films are screened and professionally judged, are held around the world. At film festivals, cinema fans can see the new -- and sometimes daring - films they would never be able to find in their local movie theaters.

The Soundtrack: Filming would be nothing without music and 8 is no different. With your support we’ll be able to hire a talented artist to create the scores for the film. 

Sound Design & Sound Mix: In addition to music, 8 would not be complete without the necessary sound effects and proper mixing. Whether it’s a cool sound effects or the subtle whirring noise of the context, the sound of the film will really bring the story and building to life.

And if more than 500$ is achieved, the money will go towards producing future Great Spaces episodes.

No matter what the amount is, anything you can donate would be incredible. And if you’re unable to donate, you can also spread the word about our film by sharing this page and visiting the website http://www.greatspacestv.com/. Furthermore, you can like us on Facebook and follow us on  Twitter as well as Instagram. 

Thank you!


Sincerely,

Delaine Isaac, Creator of 8

story:
Hi! I'm Bryan, New York indie filmmaker and MFA candidate.

Please take a look at our project and support our campaign!


About the Film

My MFA thesis film, Time is the Longest Distance  is my most sophisticated and most personal production to date. The film touches upon two topics that have had a lasting impact on my life -- gay rights and acceptance, and Alzheimer's disease.  At the heart of the film, however, are the universal themes of a child longing for a parent’s approval, and the importance of family bonds. 


The Story

When an estranged son visits his Alzheimer’s-stricken father in a nursing home to tell him of a major change in his life, he crosses paths with a teenage boy who may help him discover his father’s acceptance in an unexpected way.


Why This Film is Important

As a gay man whose father suffered from Alzheimer’s before passing away four years ago, I feel compelled to tell this story.  According to the Alzheimer’s Association, an estimated 5.3 million Americans of all ages have been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease today.  Alzheimer’s is the most common cause of dementia, and it will affect many more people in the future.  Chances are that you already know somebody who is affected by the disease.  Often, dealing with the cognitive degeneration of Alzheimer’s is as hard on the family and caregivers as it is on the patient. 

With recent progress in gay rights and changes in attitudes towards homosexuality in America, coming out to one’s parents may now be easier for those of a younger generation.  However, for those like myself, who came out at a time when there was less societal acceptance of homosexuals, a distance may have developed between them and their parents. While the parents might have accepted their child’s sexuality, they were never comfortable talking about it, and the child pulled away. This is the situation that precedes the events of Time is the Longest Distance.  In my film, Adam must reconnect with his father before Alzheimer’s robs his father of his awareness -- while there is still time for Adam’s revelation to penetrate his father’s consciousness.

Despite this growing prevalence of Alzheimer's, very few films are being made about the stories of those affected by this traumatic disease. I hope that my film will help raise awareness about Alzheimer’s, the need to accept homosexuality and the importance of family love for all of us – no matter whether gay or straight.

My dad and me.


Meet Our Wonderful Cast

With shooting scheduled for early October in New York, we have already cast several accomplished professional actors.

   Lucy McMichael as Linda

Lucy McMichael's Film/TV credits include:  Who She Was, Dare, Knife Point, The Christening of William Trumbull, La Playa, Law & Order, Law & Order:  Criminal Intent, Oz, Louie.  Theatre credits include:  March Madness at the Abingdon Theatre Company; Ascension at the Lion Theatre; Aurora Leigh at Ensemble Studio Theatre; and The Secret Sits in the Middle at Primary Stages. Upcoming Film:  Dustin Waldman's The Terrible One and Daniella  Marrese's The Castle.  Upcoming theater:  The Savannah Disputation at the cell late November/December 2015.

   Philip Levy as Jack

Philip Levy a versatile,  veteran actor has appeared on stage in, The Exonerated, Extremities, One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest, The Beauty Part, The Connection, Getting Out, The Love Museum, to name a few. In movies he has worked with the likes of Robert Redford, Woody Allen, Nora Ephron, Rob Reiner, Boaz Yakim and David Wain; the films being, Quiz Show, Manhattan Murder Mystery, Sleepless in Seattle, North, Choking Man, and The Ten.

   Paul Hickert as Xander's Dad

Paul dreamed of playing professional sports as a child.  But, many years after his brief stint in the NFL and Arena Football was over, coincidence introduced Paul to acting, which led him to create new dreams and goals.  Now, after several years of training and working as a professional actor in New York City, Paul is gaining momentum and starting to get recognition in the industry.  He has appeared in Tower Heist, One Life To Live, Royal Pains, Do No Harm and Rockstar Games' “Max Payne 3, and has shot 4 independent feature films scheduled for release in late 2015 and 2016, including the main role (Jack) in When The Moon Was Twice As Big.  He is very grateful to have had the opportunity to help bring this story to life. 

   Monica Wyche as Sarah

Monica's TV/Film credits include Law & Order: SVU, Army Wives, and the soon-to-be-released shorts, Vacation Face and Bears Discover Fire. A native South Carolinian, Monica holds an MFA from the University of South Carolina, and worked as a middle and high school drama teacher for many years prior to moving to NYC where she lives with her husband, playwright Dean Poynor, and their 3 year old son.

    Zachary Seekins as Xander

Born and raised in Dallas, Texas, Zach moved to New York five years ago to pursue his acting career. Studying at NYCDA, he has been working consistently since graduating the program. Zach has appeared in many short films,  including Ghetto Nerd Girl (winner of the People's Choice Award at Miami Web Fest), Fun and Games (Brooklyn College), and Like a Brother (Brooklyn College). Zach is very excited to be a part of this film's cast and can't wait to make to something special. Special thanks to my family and friends for always being there for me.


The Creative Team

We have assembled an enormously talented, diverse, and dedicated crew to help make this beautiful film.

   Bryan Powers Writer/Director

Bryan’s informal film education started early as the son of a cinema manager and film critic. He first pursued acting and trained at a performing arts high school. Bryan graduated Summa Cum Laude with a BA in Film from Hunter College where he received a scholarship from BAFTA (British Academy of Film and Television Arts) and was nominated for Marshall and Fulbright Scholarships. In addition to being the writer/director of several shorts, and the editor on many others, Bryan has worked in Post-Production at DCTV and on the Content Team at Tribeca Film Institute. While he is currently pursuing his MFA at City College of New York, Bryan is employed by Cineflix on their popular History Channel show, American Pickers.

   Claudia Murdoch Producer

A native of Germany, Claudia obtained a BBA in Marketing with a concentration in Advertising from Pace University New York, where she graduated Summa Cum Laude.  Claudia is a Film Production Certificate student at The New School, and has written and directed several of her own 16-mm short films.  For the past two years, she has worked as a production assistant on feature films and filled various positions as assistant director, script supervisor and producer on short-film shoots.  The short film “Intervention,” which Claudia produced, was nominated in the “Best Short Film” categories at the Rome International Film Festival, the Harlem International Film Festival, the Silent River Film Festival and the Sedona International Film Festival in 2014.

   Yvonne Ng Director of Photography

Yvonne is a commercial photographer and graduate of the prestigious Brooks Institute of Photography. Her work has appeared in many international editorials and catalogs such as Vogue, Glamour, People, Conde Nast Travel, Steve Madden, Betsy Johnson, and others. Yvonne has won numerous international photography awards such as PX3, IPA and Photo Forum. Her work has been showcased all over the world in places like Paris, San Francisco, Los Angles, Singapore and New York. Advancing her career into cinematography and directing, Yvonne has worked as DP on several shorts and written/directed others as well. She is currently pursuing her MFA in Film at City College of New York.

   Melisande Bliss Assistant Director

Melisande has written, directed and produced several short films since completing her undergraduate study at SUNY New Paltz. She has worked in a variety of media from documentary film to experimental avant-garde. As a passionate street photographer and videographer, she enjoys collaborating on projects which raise social issues and explore different aspects of human nature. Her background in Sociology and Human Services informs the work she does in film, and offers a fresh perspective and approach to making movies. She is currently working on several independent and collaborative projects, while pursuing her Master’s degree in Media Arts Production, at the City College of New York.

   Jamaal Happens Production Designer

Jamaal is a young and up and coming, African American writer and director. A graduate of The University of Texas at Austin, he is currently working on his MFA in writing & directing fiction. Jamaal is a dedicated filmmaker with more than three independently produced short films under his belt. He is currently in pre- production for his next film, The Rise of Antonious Matthews, which he describes as being the film that will kickstart his career as a professional Writer & Director.

   Wigner Duarte Sound Designer 

At a very young age Wigner fell in love with cinema, but it wasn’t until age eleven when he migrated to United States from the Dominican Republic that he saw the possibility of becoming a filmmaker. Wigner earned his Bachelors of Fine Arts in Film production from The City College of New York. There he would make his first short films such as Life On Wheels and The Man In The Black Suit. Currently, Wigner is entering the second year of his Masters degree in Film and Video production with a concentration in directing.

   Jeff Huston Production Manager

Jeff graduated with his bachelors in film from Rochester Institute of Technology, after which he moved to New York City.  Over the next 8 years he worked as an assistant director in independent feature films, and spent the next 12 years working as a post production producer for Postworks & Technicolor New York.  He is also a working filmmaker, directing his first feature film in 2007, and is currently in development on his 2nd feature.


How You Can Get Involved in the Production

Making a film is a complex process, which consists of three main stages: pre-production, production, and post-production.  With the help of an amazing cast and crew, we are now heading from pre-production into production.  I am certain that Time is the Longest Distance has the potential to be a beautiful and emotionally touching film with a lasting impact on audiences. 

Your contribution to my campaign will go a long way in making this film a reality, not only helping spread our film’s message but also helping me fulfill the requirements of my MFA degree.  As a student film, this project is dependent on enthusiastic and generous people donating their time and skills.  Without the contribution of family, friends, talent, and fellow students, this film could not be made. Just as every hand makes a difference on set, every single dollar you donate is important in order for me to make this film!

To cover all of our film’s expenses, we will need at least $7,000. The cost of film production may come as a surprise to you but this pie chart shows exactly where the money will go:

Your Rewards

Please, consider making a contribution and become a member of our filmmaking team.  You will receive updates on our journey to finishing Time is the Longest Distance.  Every cent you donate goes towards creating this film!  We offer a variety of unique perks: T-shirts, tote bags, water bottles, digital copies of the film, special thank-you credits in the film, and even an Executive Producer screen credit, or an invite to the film's premiere at the Cityvisions film festival at the Directors Guild of America Theatre in New York City in late May 2016.


Please note:

*Invites to premiere do not include cost of travel to or accommodation in New York. *Images of products are only initial designs. The finished items may vary slightly.               


Another Way to Participate

Monetary contribution or not, we encourage you to share the news of our campaign by mentioning our project to your friends or by liking our Facebook page and inviting others to do the same.  

https://www.facebook.com/TimeistheLongestDistance/timeline


Thank you! 

- Bryan
