Her work has appeared in many international editorials and catalogs such as Vogue, Glamour, People, Conde Nast Travel, Steve Madden, Betsy Johnson, and others. Yvonne has won numerous international photography awards such as PX3, IPA and Photo Forum. Her work has been showcased all over the world in places like Paris, San Francisco, Los Angles, Singapore and New York. Advancing her career into cinematography and directing, Yvonne has worked as DP on several shorts and written/directed others as well. She is currently pursuing her MFA in Film at City College of New York.

   Melisande Bliss Assistant Director
Melisande has written, directed and produced several short films since completing her undergraduate study at SUNY New Paltz. She has worked in a variety of media from documentary film to experimental avant-garde. As a passionate street photographer and videographer, she enjoys collaborating on projects which raise social issues and explore different aspects of human nature. Her background in Sociology and Human Services informs the work she does in film, and offers a fresh perspective and approach to making movies. She is currently working on several independent and collaborative projects, while pursuing her Master’s degree in Media Arts Production, at the City College of New York.
   Jamaal Happens Production Designer
Jamaal is a young and up and coming, African American writer and director. A graduate of The University of Texas at Austin, he is currently working on his MFA in writing & directing fiction. Jamaal is a dedicated filmmaker with more than three independently produced short films under his belt. He is currently in pre- production for his next film, The Rise of Antonious Matthews, which he describes as being the film that will kickstart his career as a professional Writer & Director.
   Wigner Duarte Sound Designer 
At a very young age Wigner fell in love with cinema, but it wasn’t until age eleven when he migrated to United States from the Dominican Republic that he saw the possibility of becoming a filmmaker. Wigner earned his Bachelors of Fine Arts in Film production from The City College of New York. There he would make his first short films such as Life On Wheels and The Man In The Black Suit. Currently, Wigner is entering the second year of his Masters degree in Film and Video production with a concentration in directing.
   Jeff Huston Production Manager
Jeff graduated with his bachelors in film from Rochester Institute of Technology, after which he moved to New York City.  Over the next 8 years he worked as an assistant director in independent feature films, and spent the next 12 years working as a post production producer for Postworks & Technicolor New York.  He is also a working filmmaker, directing his first feature film in 2007, and is currently in development on his 2nd feature.


How You Can Get
Involved in the Production




Making a film is a complex process, which consists of three main stages: pre-production, production, and post-production.  With the help of an amazing cast and crew, we are now heading from pre-production into production.  I am certain that Time is the Longest Distance has the potential to be a beautiful and emotionally touching film with a lasting impact on audiences. 
Your contribution to my campaign will go a long way in making this film a reality, not only helping spread our film’s message but also helping me fulfill the requirements of my MFA degree.  As a student film, this project is dependent on enthusiastic and generous people donating their time and skills.  Without the contribution of family, friends, talent, and fellow students, this film could not be made. Just as every hand makes a difference on set, every single dollar you donate is important in order for me to make this film!To cover all of our film’s
expenses, we will need at least $7,000. The cost of film production
may come as a surprise to you but this pie chart shows exactly where the money
will go:

Your Rewards

Please,
consider making a contribution and become a member of our
filmmaking team.  You will receive
updates on our journey to finishing Time
is the Longest Distance.  Every
cent you donate goes towards creating this film!  We offer a variety of unique perks: T-shirts, tote bags,
water bottles, digital copies of the film, special thank-you credits in the
film, and even an Executive Producer screen credit, or an invite to the film's
premiere at the Cityvisions film festival at the Directors
Guild of America Theatre in New York City in late May 2016.


Please note:
*Invites to
premiere do not include cost of travel to or accommodation in New York. *Images of products are only initial designs. The finished items may vary slightly.               







Another Way to Participate
Monetary contribution or not, we encourage
you to share the news of our campaign by mentioning our project to your
friends or by liking our Facebook page and inviting others to do the same.   
https://www.facebook.com/TimeistheLongestDistance/timeline

Thank you! - Bryan

story:
Short Summary

Based on real Shocking events, Some Asylum Seekers have already took their lives and some lost their lives during crossing border illegally, and some are fighting for their lives as Asylum Seekers. Hidden Shocking Stories of Asylum Seekers, their lifestyle. This is an awareness to WorldWide Audience, We need your help to send this message to those who are planning to seek Asylum without knowledge about the place they are heading to. 

Currently this version is 40 minutes, additional Scenes are required to combine with Short version to make it 90 minutes full length film. 

  • INTRODUCTION: 

    This Current Asylum Short Film Version Has Won The Best Documentary Feature film of the year 2015 Award at LA Film & Script Festival in Hollywood recently.

  • BACKGROUND/REASONS WHY WE PRODUCED THIS FILM:  

    October 2012 when a man came to my friend’s restaurant asking for job, We asked him to come back later in few days, he never appeared but we came to know, he committed Suicide and hung himself in public park early in the morning, and in same week another person committed Suicide and they were both Asylum Seekers. They were never published in NewsMedia.

    This was the point i wanted to know more about these Asylum Seekers and after some research and knowing very strange facts, rules by the Govt for them, i decided to produce an awareness in a way of warning for the World Wide Audience to save lives. 

    In current times, there are political and financial issues everywhere which are pushing many to leave their motherland and find shelter at some other places.

    Many of them, cross borders illegally, Some successfully Cross and some lose their lives on this process. 

    Due to lack of knowledge about countries rules and regulations for asylum seekers, most of them stuck and hold their lives for years and some start to face much worst condition then in their own country. 

    Idrees Was about 24 years young man who gave up his life and hung himself with a tree.

    Strange rules do not allow them to work, provide them enough support and shelter which leads them to unhealthy activities like selling drugs, forming gangs etc. if they are being caught during work, they could be imprisoned for 22 months, and if they are being caught while selling drugs, they could be imprisoned for few months which leads them to find short cuts to make their better living. This Documentary uncovers the shocking lifestyle of these Asylum Seekers.

    In this Documentary we involved prominent Hong Kong figures like, Consulate General of Pakistan in Hong Kong, Legislative council members, prominent business community and local community to put their views about Asylum Seekers and what possible solutions they feel that can put them among humanitarian manors. 

    At this stage, to save lives by giving awareness to the World Wide Audience who are planning to seek asylum in Hong Kong, we need to send this message to them, Many Asylum Seekers have held their lives for more than 15 years, they can not move with their lives.

  • WHY AND WHAT WE NEED HELP FROM YOU: 

    During the Pre-Production process we were robbed and lost all equipments, even mobile phones, pads, except the hard drives that we saved our film raw footage, I struggled for one restless year to complete this film by doing labours and small jobs and did post on a single laptop. We have all police Reports with actual dates and will be posting here and rest of the material which will show our restless effort and mission why we need to showcase to its target audience to save lives.  

    Since Film has successfully won the best award this year 2015, We are lack of funds to do premiere in USA and Hong Kong and put on broadcast worldwide. It is a mission which i sincerely hope should not stop and there are still good people with hearts who think each individual life is very unique and important and we should do our best to save at our best. We need to raise about USD50,000 to raise funds to do World Premieres in different countries to finally send this awareness. It is at this point looks not possible anymore without miracles and without your support. we are counting each and single support to complete our mission. Please help.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to do World Premieres in different countries to send the awareness through their local broadcasts and media platforms.

  • We need to raise USD50,000 for the World Premieres.  .

The Impact

Your each small or big contribution can make a big difference:

  • Many have committed suicide and many have held their lives for more than 15 years, some more than 17 years. by your support, some one will watch on national broadcast, will definitely think twice before he/she take any step to leave their country to seek asylum else where without knowledge.

Risks & Challenges

Biggest Challenge was to produce this movie and showcase where we targeted it. 

We face our Studio Robbery during the pre-Production process and lost everything, I as Director, stood alone to complete this film by doing labour, and small different jobs. and finally i submitted film and this Won the Best Award of the year. 

The only biggest Challenge left is, to Showcase to the WorldWide Audience. we have no more funds, we need to do World Premiers and put on different International and local Broadcast Channels to give this awareness. and this is only possible by a Miracle or your Small and big Support, we are counting on each single contribution to make this possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help.

Please help us in any possible way. if you have better way that we can do premiers around the World, please let us know, help us to put it on National ,International Broadcast, News Media, Social Media, Theatres etc.

story:
My name is Jamal Lewis and I am the writer and director of No Fats, No Femmes, a feature-length documentary about desire. I’m a cultural worker, performance artist, and freedom fighter living in Bed-Stuy, Brooklyn, hailing from Atlanta. My work examines identity formation, uglinesss, desire(ability), race, class, gender, and sexuality through a Black, queer, feminist, and abolitionist lens.

No Fats, No Femmes interrogates and explores desire and the ways in which it is deeply informed by media, pop culture, and capitalism through interviews, archival research, and performance. The film critically engages the phrase “no fats, no femmes,” which is popularly used on queer social networking/dating sites to describe one’s dating preferences, through the personal narrative(s) of 5 Black and Brown gender-non-conforming, queer, trans, fat, femme, and disabled people.

No Fats, No Femmes is critically important because it offers a profound perspective regarding issues of race, fatness, and desirability that has been deliberately silenced. The film is in the early stages of development and pre-production and desperately need funding and resources for equipment, crew, travel, and personnel costs and expenses. 

  1. 50% of funding will cover production: camera equipment, sound, lighting 
  2. 25% will cover crew: directors of photography and audio 
  3. 15% will cover travel costs for producer, director of photography and audio
  4. 10% will cover personnel expenses 

Below is the intro for the film -- a performance piece using Mark Aguhar’s “A Litany for My Heavenly Brown Body." It sets the tone, through performance, and is a taste of what to expect when the film is finished.

story:
Thank you to everyone who supported this campaign! We are continuing to accept donations for Heart of the Matter here: http://notmylife.org/donate


About the Film

Heart of the Matter is a short (20 – 25 minute) film that will serve as a companion piece to Not My Life, the universally acclaimed Worldwide Documentaries film about the horrors and ubiquity of global human trafficking. Heart of the Matter has been conceived in response to the current refugee crisis in Europe, where hundreds of thousands of refugees, especially children, are at risk of being trafficked in the months and years ahead.

A Disaster in the Making

Don't look at the numbers, look at the faces.  --Pope Francis 

In the EU, the intense, daily preoccupation with the consequences of massive immigration has created a huge awareness gap with respect to the most dangerous consequence of all: human trafficking, and the creation of a perfect storm of vulnerability that will allow organized crime to prey on children and their families for months and years to come.

“The traffickers have already begun their feast,” asserts one Italian police official. “Last year alone, 5,000 children disappeared from reception centers here in Italy, and we have no idea where they are.”

Working with, or within, the mafia and other criminal networks, EU traffickers are particularly ruthless and powerful.

Numbering over 30,000 facilitators, agents, and middlemen, traffickers are kidnapping children for labor, sex, begging, and other forms of servitude. Many of these refugee children are stateless and denied basic rights, leaving them particularly vulnerable to exploitation. Add to this the forcing of women into prostitution rings, and the coercion of men into menial jobs without pay, and one sees a continent increasingly populated with slaves-- most of them young-- and the flourishing and entrenchment of a crime business whose profits are in the billions of Euros. It is a recipe for a human disaster.

Who, What and Where 

Led by Oscar® nominee and Not My Life producer Robert Bilheimer, a small team of filmmakers will crisscross the European continent to depict narratives such as the following:

-- Sweden.  How the country is responding to the hundreds of unaccompanied children arriving each week. 

-- A refugee camp such as Tatinghem in Nord Pas-de-Calais in France, otherwise known as “the jungle.” Already swollen beyond capacity, Tatinghem has led to the proliferation of smaller, poorly protected camps across the north, whose locations are well-known to trafficking gangs.  

-- The immensely discouraging struggle of law enforcement throughout the EU who are out numbered and virtually powerless against the well-organized trafficking gangs. 

These and other narratives will form the matrix of Heart of the Matter, a clarion call that must be heard immediately if an already bad situation is not to get much worse. 


Why a Film?

The Power and Importance of Storytelling           

            The task of the storyteller is not to solve the problem, but to state the         problem correctly.  -- Anton Chekov

Given the overwhelming immediate needs of hundreds of thousands of EU refugees as winter approaches-- food, shelter, and health care among them-- why invest in the pre-production of a film?

What difference will a film make, and what will it accomplish?

There are two basic answers:

1. Public awareness and public discourse are essential ingredients in any struggle against oppression and injustice. Fighting modern slavery without an informed and engaged general public is like fighting a war without an army: it’s a losing battle.  

2. In the 21st century, the genre of film has become one of the most effective and powerful vehicles we have to create awareness of human rights issues on a global scale. More and more,the language of film—images, music, narrative-- is becoming the language of the world, spoken and understood by billions. We only need to recall the photograph of 3 year-old Aylan Kurdi, washed up on a Turkish beach, to understand how a even a single image has the power to shake the conscience of the world.

Given the importance of awareness on the one hand, and the power of film on the other, we have two choices:

-- Do nothing on the awareness front, allow the ignorance and denial to continue, and give the traffickers free rein.

-- Make a film such as Heart of the Matter, raise an army, and fight back. 

If we do nothing, then all of the problems already facing the refugees will only get worse if large numbers of them are trafficked. More health problems including HIV/AIDS. More violence against women and children. More loss of human dignity and life.
 

If, on the other hand, we accept that broad awareness is key to the success of any human rights struggle; accept the fact that the status quo—free rein to the traffickers—is unacceptable by any moral, ethical, or humanitarian standard; then Heart of the Matter makes perfect sense, because it will trigger dialogue, create solidarity, encourage action, and demand solutions that will save human lives.


The Impact: Our Global Audience and Partners

Reaching the Audience & the Power of Partnership

Worldwide Documentaries is widely recognized as a pioneer in global awareness and distribution strategies that enable films such as Not My Life and Heart of the Matter to be powerful and sustainable agents for social change.

We have reached over a billion people with our films over the past 30 years, and have done so with a global network of partners that includes NGOs, multiple UN agencies, corporations, international development and law enforcement agencies, faith-based communities and organizations, student groups, service providers including national call-in hotlines, and colleagues throughout the international artistic community including the fields of filmmaking, music, and the visual arts.

The basis of these partnerships has always been a shared commitment to the human rights issues addressed in Worldwide’s films.

Working with partners ranging from the UN Office on Drugs and Crime; to country-based anti trafficking NGOs such as As-ce in France; to law enforcement agencies throughout the EU; to individuals in countries like Serbia working in university and community settings; our goal is to saturate public opinion in the EU and globally using every dissemination outlet at our disposal, including theatres and television, the internet and social media, and the communication structures that our partners already have in place. 


About Our Campaign 

Why We Need Pre-production Funding

Pre-production may not be the most exciting aspect of documentary filmmaking, but in many ways it is the most important. Research, salaries, location scouting, travel, and scripting are a few of the essential elements that go into the documentary storytelling process. You can’t get to the production phase without it! 

After months of research and hundreds of conversations with colleagues throughout the international human rights community, we have laid a solid foundation for the pre-production phase of the project and are ready to begin immediately. 

Our $30,000 goal for this campaign represents the minimum we need to get started.  If we raise additional funds during this campaign, they will allow us to keep the project moving forward toward the production phase and completion, which is slated for May, 2016. 

If we fall short of our goal, funds raised will still be valuable and important, as they will support our overall fundraising effort for Heart of the Matter, as well as our ability to sustain global human trafficking awareness initiatives we are working on in other parts of the world as well.  

Challenges

Identifying and securing funding for our documentary film projects remains the biggest challenge our team-- or any team doing this kind of work-- faces. We have been making influential and highly regarded documentaries on global human rights issues for 30 years and we know from experience how challenging the fundraising process can be. 

We feel the urgency to begin work on Heart of the Matter is too great to rely on any single sector of the international funding community, and that is why this campaign is so important to us,  we very much need your help! 

The bottom line is that the EU refugee crisis is getting worse by the day. We feel a huge sense of responsibility here because we know that our film can make a difference and even save lives. 


Our Team

Director Robert Bilheimer and President of the non-profit organization Worldwide Documentaries, is one of the most influential documentary filmmakers working in the world today. In 1989, Robert was nominated for an Academy Award for Cry of Reason, a feature-length documentary that profiles the South African anti-apartheid leader Beyers Naude. Since that time, he has made carefully crafted documentary films on a wide range of social, cultural, and humanitarian concern. Read more.....

Gerardo Puglia is an international cinematographer who has worked as Director of Photography for myriad film and television entities, including: BBC, PBS, CBS, National Geographic, RAI (Italian Television), Imagine Entertainment, and Warner Brothers. He has recently completed cinematography on two feature length documentary films “God Knows where I am” and “To the Edge of the Sky”. Puglia is the recipient of two Emmys and a Peabody, along with two qualified Academy Award entries.

Craig Braden is a national Emmy nominated Director of Photography with over 20 yrs of experience. His work on films, national spots and music videos has taken him to 6 continents, and over 40 countries; shooting on every format from 35 millimeter to the Canon 5D. But it’s probably his work on Documentary features that showcase his true diversity. His work spans many genres including the entertainment industry, sports and historical pieces. He is proud to have been a part of Worldwide Documentaries feature films A Closer Walk and Not My Life, and considers his continuing collaboration with this team a privilege and an honor.

Senior Producer Heidi Ostertag's career with Worldwide Documentaries began at its inception in 1985. Thirty years later, Heidi is Worldwide Documentaries' Senior Producer, with a wide range of responsibilities including production planning and supervision; day-to-day management of the company's global operations; and oversight of a small cadre of staff, consultants, and volunteers. Heidi’s most important contribution is the one she has made towards creating, and sustaining, Worldwide’s invaluable reputation for integrity, reliability, transparency, and commitment to the highest professional standards in every aspect of the company’s endeavors.

Co-Producer and Distribution Manager, Amy Detweiler, has been a member of the Worldwide Documentaries team since February 2010. Amy’s importance to Worldwide Documentaries lies in her multiple skill sets: on the creative side, she has developed editing and storytelling skills that are enabling Worldwide to respond to an ever-increasing demand for various iterations of Worldwide footage, especially from the current project, Not My Life. Amy also manages Worldwide's websites, social media and film distribution.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can make a monetary contribution, but there are other ways you can help us! Please SHARE this page, FOLLOW us on Twitter, and help SPREAD THE WORD  about this film and the work that we do. We believe this film can prevent thousands of innocent, vulnerable refugees from being trafficked, and it begins with awareness that this danger exists.


Photo Credits:

"Syrian Refugee" Bengin Ahmad
"Bouchara" NRC / Sam Tarling

if large numbers of them are trafficked. More health problems including HIV/AIDS.
More violence against women and children. More loss of human dignity and life.
  
If, on the other hand, we accept that broad awareness is key to
the success of any human rights struggle; accept the fact that the status
quo—free rein to the traffickers—is unacceptable by any moral, ethical, or
humanitarian standard; then Heart of the Matter makes perfect sense, because
it will trigger dialogue, create solidarity, encourage action, and demand
solutions that will save human lives. 

The Impact: Our Global Audience and Partners




Reaching the Audience & the
Power of Partnership
Worldwide Documentaries is widely recognized as a pioneer in global awareness and
distribution strategies that enable films such as Not My Life and Heart
of the Matter to be powerful and sustainable agents for social change.
We have reached over a billion people with our films over the past 30 years, and
have done so with a global network of partners that includes NGOs, multiple UN agencies, corporations,
international development and law enforcement agencies, faith-based communities
and organizations, student groups, service providers including national call-in
hotlines, and colleagues throughout the international artistic community
including the fields of filmmaking, music, and the visual arts.
The basis of these partnerships has
always been a shared commitment to the human rights issues addressed in
Worldwide’s films. Working with partners ranging from
the UN Office on Drugs and Crime; to country-based anti trafficking NGOs such
as As-ce in France; to law enforcement agencies throughout the EU; to
individuals in countries like Serbia working in university and community
settings; our goal is to saturate public
opinion in the EU and globally using every dissemination outlet at our
disposal, including theatres and television, the internet and social media, and
the communication structures that our partners already have in place. 

About Our Campaign 




Why We Need Pre-production Funding 



Pre-production may not be the most exciting aspect of documentary filmmaking, but in many ways it is the most important. Research, salaries, location scouting, travel, and scripting are a few of the essential elements that go into the documentary storytelling process. You can’t get to the production phase without it! 
After months of research and hundreds of conversations with colleagues throughout the international human rights community, we have laid a solid foundation for the pre-production phase of the project and are ready to begin immediately. 
Our $30,000 goal for this campaign represents the minimum we need to get started.  If we raise additional funds during this campaign, they will allow us to keep the project moving forward toward the production phase and completion, which is slated for May, 2016. 
If we fall short of our goal, funds raised will still be valuable and important, as they will support our overall fundraising effort for Heart of the Matter, as well as our ability to sustain global human trafficking awareness initiatives we are working on in other parts of the world as well.  
 

Challenges


Identifying and securing funding for
our documentary film projects remains the biggest challenge our team-- or any
team doing this kind of work-- faces. We have been making influential and highly
regarded documentaries on global human rights issues for 30 years and
we know from experience how challenging the fundraising process can be. 
We feel the urgency to begin work on Heart of the Matter is too great to rely on any single sector of the international funding community, and that is why this campaign is so important to us,  we very much need your help! 
The bottom line is that the EU refugee crisis is getting worse by the day. We feel a huge sense of responsibility here
because we know that our film can
make a difference and even save lives. 

 



Our Team




Director Robert Bilheimer and President of the non-profit organization Worldwide 
Documentaries, is one of the most influential documentary filmmakers 
working in the world today. In 1989, Robert was nominated for an Academy
 Award for Cry of Reason,
 a feature-length documentary that profiles the South African 
anti-apartheid leader Beyers Naude. Since that time, he has made 
carefully crafted documentary films on a wide range of social, cultural,
 and humanitarian concern. Read more.....



Gerardo Puglia 
is an international
cinematographer who has worked as Director of Photography for myriad film and television
entities, including: BBC, PBS, CBS, National Geographic, RAI (Italian
Television), Imagine Entertainment, and Warner Brothers. He has recently
completed cinematography on two feature length documentary films “God Knows
where I am” and “To the Edge of the Sky”.


Puglia is the recipient of
two Emmys and a Peabody, along with two qualified Academy Award entries. 


Craig Braden is a national Emmy nominated Director of Photography with over 20 yrs of experience. His work on films, national spots and music videos has taken him to 6 continents, and over 40 countries; shooting on every format from 35 millimeter to the Canon 5D. But it’s probably his work on Documentary features that showcase his true diversity. His work spans many genres including the entertainment industry, sports and historical pieces. He is proud to have been a part of Worldwide Documentaries feature films A Closer Walk and Not My Life, and considers his continuing collaboration with this team a privilege and an honor.



Senior Producer Heidi Ostertag's career with Worldwide Documentaries began at its inception in 1985. Thirty years later, Heidi is Worldwide Documentaries' Senior Producer, with a wide range of 
responsibilities including production planning and supervision; 
day-to-day management of the company's global operations; and oversight 
of a small cadre of staff, consultants, and volunteers. Heidi’s most important contribution is the one she has made 
towards creating, and sustaining, Worldwide’s invaluable reputation for 
integrity, reliability, transparency, and commitment to the highest 
professional standards in every aspect of the company’s endeavors.

Co-Producer and Distribution Manager, Amy Detweiler, has been a member of the Worldwide Documentaries team since February 
2010. Amy’s importance to Worldwide Documentaries lies in her multiple skill 
sets: on the creative side, she has developed editing and storytelling 
skills that are enabling Worldwide to respond to an ever-increasing 
demand for various iterations of Worldwide footage, especially from the 
current project, Not My Life. Amy also manages Worldwide's websites, social media and film distribution.

Other Ways You Can Help 


We understand that not everyone can make a monetary contribution, but there are other ways you can help us! Please SHARE this page, FOLLOW us on Twitter, and help SPREAD THE WORD 
 about this film and the work that we do. We believe this film can 
prevent thousands of innocent, vulnerable refugees from being 
trafficked, and it begins with awareness that this danger exists.

Photo Credits:
"Syrian Refugee" Bengin Ahmad"Bouchara" NRC / Sam Tarling

story:
Hi. I’m KALiiN. I was born from the creative minds at VaranIDEA - The Idea Conversion Factory. I want to tell you about them, and how I can become your new best friend...Your Super Bot!

VaranIDEA is the place where innovation meets execution. Our team comes from four continents, and we believe in the principle that everyone can be successful, regardless of their background or location in the world.

This team of people from around the world came up with a unique Artificial Intelligence process that helps you simplify your life, hence I was born. My IQ grows with your help. The more we interact, the better I become at helping you make the most of your life and time, always making sure your privacy is protected.

My goal is to help you coordinate your life...Your Super Bot!  I am your Life Concierge, allowing you to focus on the important things in your life.

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET:

I need your support to grow. My next growth spurt requires $99K to complete.

Features include: Perks, Enhanced Life Dashboard, Groups, Family Calendar, my IQ, Theme Builder, API integration, Native Behavioral Advertising, Privacy Controls, and much more.

I can change your world by helping you organize your life, offering good suggestions for things to do, and finding time so you can focus on the things that matter the most!  So help me become the most outstanding mobile AI app EVER!

My initial release (1.1.21) will be in English, and it’s scheduled to be available for Android and iOS devices on September 15, 2016. You’ll get a lot of the cool features in this first release, but I’ll need your support to reach my full potential.

Most of my budget goes to development, but in exchange for your support you will receive the following Perks.

PERK ONE: KALiiN will offer an Advertising Opt Out feature.

This Opt-Out Feature is normally $1.99 per month.  This Opt-Out feature removes Advertising from KALiiN, but still allows you to increase KALiiN's IQ.

By contributing $10.00, you will get this feature for 50% off the monthly price.

Release 2 has an option to allow specific advertisers to contact you if you are interested in their products & services – You decide.

PERK TWO: KALiiN Personalization Theme Tool.

By contributing $10.00, you will receive unlimited access to the KALiiN Personalized Theme Tool, when it is released. 

The KALiiN Personalization Theme Tool lets you design your own Theme(s) for KALiiN.

Trade them, Sell them...just have fun!

You create KALiiN in your own image.  Make your KALiiN reflect you... your Brand!

NOTE: If you contribute $20.00 or more, you will receive both Perks!!

THE IMPACT:

I have big goals. I want to change your world by simplifying your life. Thanks to my unique AI process, I’ll be able to help you prioritize activities, find relevant opportunities, and achieve a more balanced life.

I am also very social. Your family and your friends can benefit from my abilities, so take me for a test drive: schedule dinner party, find a movie, have coffee or arrange any other event…it will be super easy!

I invite you and your friends and family to download me from the App Store or Google Play Store, and try me out. I will be available by September 15, 2016, but if you sign up for early access on my website you might get me sooner.

One very important thing for you and me, is your privacy. I am designed to keep your anonymity in place. I will not share your personal contact or other information that would identify you to a third party.  YOU alone decide who to share that information with, whether it’s a friend, family, or a business. YOU are in total control.

RISK AND CHALLENGES:

Competition:

I am different from other solutions, because I use Artificial Intelligence in a completely new way from traditional and current applications.  Plus, I keep your privacy intact.  This allows me to help you in ways you cannot imagine … nor can our competition. 

Ability to execute:

The team at VaranIDEA is focused on results. Our diverse talents, cultures, backgrounds and successes equip us to deliver a new mobile app experience that has people and your needs in mind. I am confident I will make my goal, but if I do not, I will just grow a little slower.  

So PLEASE help me become the most useful app in your life.

I want to be your Life Concierge, and your new best friend!   I am not just any bot...I am Your Super Bot!

story:
Short Summary

We are TheLowFlyingGeese, independent film makers from Manchester. We currently have our debut feature film in post production entitled 'Strange-Days in Strange-Ways' AKA 'Rum Bastards'. The film is about a punk band that formed in Strangeways prison in the 1980's and it features some of Manchester and Salford's most famous sons from the Happy Mondays to John Cooper Clarke. It also features some of the city's rising stars such as poet JB Barrington and rock and roll outfit, The Backhanders. 

This particular project is our first ever documentary film which takes us to the streets of Manchester, following the highs and lows of the city's most infamous buskers, 'The Piccadilly Rats',  founded by the main man himself, Gaz Stanley.      We really hope you can help us with this campaign and be a part of a great project.

Below: TheLowFlyingGeese present Gaz Stanley and 'The Piccadilly Rats' in brief 2015


We plan to follow the band around for five days capturing their every move as they prepare for a gig in memory of their ex-band mate  'Dave the Rave' who passed away last year. Sadly when Dave died he had no existing family to declare his body and was set for a paupers grave so the band, along with some friends, managed to intervene and raise enough money for a proper send off and have him buried next to his mother and father. Unfortunately not enough money was raised to have his head stone engraved  so the band have organised this gig hoping to raise funds to make this happen. Our film is hoping to capture their journey to achieving that goal. 

Below: Dave the Rave

Below: 'The Piccadilly Rats' at Dave the Rave's funeral

This group of colourful, rock and roll, mad heads play anything from the Beatles to Oasis but it's their rather unique performances which include their two dancers, Ray and Tommy (Bez, eat yer heart out mate), that has won over the hearts of the people of Manchester. 'The Piccadilly Rats' represent the very essence of the importance of being yourself and expressing yourself without fear of judgement by those who look down their noses.  I'm sure this very essence will be portrayed through our film in a humorous and heart warming fashion…their story has to be told.

Coming from very humble beginnings, growing up in a gritty little city, their back story is not only littered with stories that will have you in stitches but it also deals with serious hardships, homelessness, crime, borstal, prison and (believe it or not) Simon f*****g Cowell!! But how did this very unique blend of characters come together to perform and entertain on the streets of Manchester under the guise, 'THE PICCADILLY RATS'?  Please help us tell that story!

Below: Ray - Dancer.

Below: Tommy - Dancer.

As you will see in the clip below, things haven't always been harmonious within the band as they found themselves battling it out with each other in court in front of the whole nation (Judge Rinder ITV) over an incident that took place during a talent competition involving some kind of mankini malfunction. Take a look:

    As you can imagine, with such natural characters as these, our film would definitely make for great viewing. Salt of the earth.                                 Contributors to this fantastic project would not only be a part of an entertaining, funny, heart warming documentary about some of the maddest and most eccentric characters on the streets of Manchester today but they would be playing a big part in keeping Dave the Rave's memory alive.  
    Below far left: 'Dave the Rave' with the band.

     What We Need & What You Get

  • We need at least £2,000  to tell the bands story and give it justice through the right production. The money would cover the cost of crew, cameras & camera equipment, sound tech, food and drink for the crew and the band over the five day shoot. It would also help towards the cost of Dave the Rave's tribute gig and post production activity (editing etc)
  • There will be many perks for all contributors including, posters, T-shirts, tickets  to the screening and custom copies of the film with a personal message of thanks to the contributor and their name in the credits.
  • What if we don't hit our £2,000 target?  The money we do make will be banked and put towards further campaigns involving this project. 

"GOD KNOW'S IT'S ONLY ROCK N' ROLL BUT I LIKE IT"

The Impact

  • Our project is important to the contributor and its audience because in a world of negativity it's far too easy to overlook real people trying to make a difference, real people whose only goal is to entertain and put a smile on peoples faces. The salt of the earth singing and dancing no matter what with two fingers firmly in the air.
  • We are all super excited for the release of our debut film next year about the fictional punk band 'The Rum Bastards' (see trailer below) so to have this fantastic side line project about 'The Piccadilly Rats' it's really exciting for us as an independent production company.  Please get involved.

Risks & Challenges

Our risks and challenges come in the form of doing the band justice in telling their story to the best it can be. This will take an extensive five day shoot leading to Dave's tribute gig. It will also take us getting up close and personal with the band and respectfully portraying who they are in an honest fashion.  Getting the right equipment and crew onboard is crucial as we want this piece of art to look good enough to grace anyone's screen.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to this project financially but are interested in helping us out, please spread the word and share the link to this campaign, it would be most appreciated.

You can also follow our progress on twitter:

Nathan Cunningham (Director) @LowGeese

Mr Peeps (Producer) @MrPeepsSays

Thank you for taking the time to read about our campaign, we hope you can help.

TheLowFlyingGeese.

story:
PLEASE SHARE ON FACEBOOK!


* Important note about this film _ the opinions and views expressed by individuals featured in this documentary do NOT reflect the views of any other person in the film. Each person speaks for his or herself, we are exploring a variety of both challenges and solutions and must therefore, by necessity, look to varied people and leaders in their own fields.

About The Film

We are two people, an ex-cop and a peace activist, who walked over 400 miles for 9/11 truth and for many of the grave issues we face today, in order to explore the SOLUTIONS to these national and world challenges. We've interview many people on the world stage today, as well as people like you whom we met along the way - you'll be astonished to find that many have viable faith in our power to change things. PLEASE help us complete the making of Truth Walk: The Movie, and be the change you wish to see in the world - DONATE NOW!

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Editing software
  • Photoshop software
  • Graphics software 
  • Other filmmaking software
  • Green Screen
  • Lighting
  • Other filmmaking accessories
  • Travel expenses for further filming and interviews
  • We have numerous quantum physicists we want to interview
  • We have numerous experts we want to interview
  • We have numerous whistle blowers we want to interview
  • We are open to YOUR suggestions for people to interview
  • We want to build bridges between movements
  • We offer numerous perks for donations PLEASE check out or "Perk Page"
  • Every donor will be listed in the film credits! 
  • THANK YOU!

The Impact

 

This film is intended to cross lines so that leaders in various movements can begin to work together rather than operate in separate camps.

We want to create a film wherein people from all walks of life and from varied and diverse motivations can begin to join forces to heal our world and change the current paradigm which is being designed by the power elite...let's make our own world, TOGETHER!

 

Risks & Challenges

 We intend to make a great film regardless, but your donation can bring our film to film festival quality. We know that a good film on YouTube can make a difference, but the higher the quality, the better the chance of creating an award winning film that can really awaken people, and draw the attention of leaders in the world's various movements which essentially oppose the NWO.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

We need your help in any way possible so whether or not you can donate, please share our Indiegogo campaign far and wide (check out the "Tools" section) on FB, Twitter, to your email contacts and tell all of your friends.

 

THANK YOU!

story:
A SILENT HILL STORY YOU'VE BEEN WAITING FOR A LONG TIME

Silent hill: The Promise is a fan-fueled web series based on the lore of the Silent Hill video games. The project has been in the planning phase for a couple of years and has already gained international attention and gathered a crew of over 20 people and collaborative partners from around the world. The series bridges the gap between Silent Hill 2 and 4 with an original storyline, characters and monsters as well as direct events, locations and characters from the games


Red Stage Films?

Red Stage Films is an independent production team from Finland specialized in visual effects, creative storytelling and horror. We promise to bring impossible thoughts into hundreds and hundreds of hours of renders. We promise to bring you dedication and attitude. We promise to bring you entertainment.

The Story

John Garland's peaceful life in Silent Hill ends with the mysterious chain of murders committed by his former schoolmate, Walter Sullivan. After his arrest, Sullivan commits suicide in his Prison Cell but the feeling of uneasiness still surrounds Silent Hill. John and his girlfriend Melissa Fitch soon leave the town behind.

Years later John suddenly finds himself back in Silent Hill. The town has filled up with nightmarish delusions and eerie fog. A weird shadowy figure seems to follow him everywhere. While running away, John finds Melissa who seems distressed. Her sister, Katherine Fitch, has disappeared somewhere in the town. A local priest starts helping the couple in their search but nothing seems to be right, no encounter feels natural and no one is acting normally. John believes the right thing to do is to find Katherine and a way out of the hell they're trapped in.

The thick fog covers the rural northeastern town, as if to hide its secrets. An enigmatic religious cult seems to be involved but in Silent Hill the truth is hard to find and mostly just an interpretation. Somethings are better left unseen and some promises left unfulfilled.

The Crew and Talent

Pekka Sorri – Creative Director / Writer / VFX Artist / Producer
Sahin Cengiz - Director / Writer / Producer
Nikke Kuki - Sound Designer / Composer
Jenna-Miia Kaivosoja - Singer
Hiro Yokochi - Visual Designer
llari Gröhn - Concept Artist
Mikael Seidler - Animations
Khalid Imran - Cinematographer
Jerina Kivistö - Actor / Melissa Fitch
Waltteri Lahti - Actor / Walter Sullivan
Kim Kupiainen - Actor / Toby Archbolt
Tomi Säily - Actor / ???????

Why Silent Hill?

Silent Hill isn't about big cinematic spectacles, it's about quiet moments, attention to detail and thought-provoking exploration of the human mind and soul. It's about telling multi-leveled stories through secrets, confusion and atmosphere rather than cheap scares and easy answers. Silent Hill is about mixing faith and psychology with extreme conditions and a meaningful context.

For most of us Silent Hill has been a passion since childhood. It has taught us a truly elegant form of horror that lingers in the mind for years. We feel that the last few games and film adaptations have not met the standards of the original 4 games. At the moment we have the blueprints for the best Silent Hill story in years. Your support is appreciated.

Do you want to stay in the history of Silent Hill forever?

By donating 10 € or more you get your name and picture in the series in various creative ways!

All the perks starting from creeper include this!

Rough Budget Estimate

Filming will be done in autumn 2016 during the course of a month.

Achieving professional quality with minimum resources is our specialty. We will still utilize our DIY-skills and professional connections to create the best possible quality while keeping the costs low. As a tribute web series, the crew will not be making a profit during the production but nevertheless, we're not selling ourselves short in terms of equipment, production design and monster costumes.


Camera & Lighting Equipment
-Black Magic Cinema Camera & Lenses
-Portable LED Floods
12 000€

Make-up FX
-Monsters and gore, organic environments
7000€

VFX & SFX Libraries
2000€

Production Design & Costumes
-Props, weapons, blood and guts
-Costumes
6000€

Transportation and catering
-Fuel, car rentals
-Food
2000€

Editing Peripherals
-A custom build computer for editing
1000€

Budget: 30 000€


STRETCH GOAL!

"Taking Silent Hill back to its roots" is a catch phrase heard every time a new Silent Hill related product is released, but it hardly ever delivers. We want to finally make it happen and capture the essence of Silent Hill physically as well as mentally. In the best case scenario, we will film the series in Osaka, Japan, in select deserted locations. Filming in Japan will be done with a minimal crew and only the essential actors with a price-range of 1200€ / person.

Stretch goal budget:
42 000€


Act now, the stage is yours!
-Red Stage Films

A
SILENT HILL STORY YOU'VE BEEN WAITING FOR A LONG TIMESilent
hill: The Promise is a fan-fueled web series based on the lore of the
Silent Hill video games. The project has been in the planning phase
for a couple of years and has already gained international attention
and gathered a crew of over 20 people and collaborative partners from
around the world. The series bridges the gap between Silent
Hill 2 and 4 with an original storyline, characters and monsters as
well as direct events, locations and characters from the games

Red
Stage Films?
Red Stage
Films is an independent production team from Finland specialized in
visual effects, creative storytelling and horror. We promise to bring
impossible thoughts into hundreds and hundreds of hours of renders.
We promise to bring you dedication and attitude. We promise to bring
you entertainment.

story:
Hello

My name is Abby Whisenant, and I'm a teaching artist, storyteller & civic engagement leader living in Nashville, TN. I've been teaching community art classes for more than a decade, and I share stories of the human experience through my documentary photography. These two passions have led me to my current position at the Underground Art Studio at Oasis, an art studio I founded for high-risk youth.

Throughout my first two years in the studio, I have led multiple community-based art projects with youth and local artists. I have also trained other community artists on how to authentically engage non-artists as co-creators in their projects. Now, I'm looking for ways to learn more about social practice art and to challenge and inspire myself professionally.

A dear friend recently shared an opportunity with me through ArtCorps - Culture and Arts for Social Change in Cuba. This people-to-people journey will focus on Cuba's dynamic culture and arts scene through the lens of ArtCorps' framework and experiential methodology of individual empowerment, community development, and systemic change. Throughout the 9-day immersive experience, I will have the opportunity to practice my own art of photography and writing while also learning from individual artists and visiting community art projects to witness how art and culture are used to effect systemic change, develop positive solutions to community challenges, and revitalize neighborhoods.

It has always been a dream of mine to visit Cuba - a place rich with music, arts and culture. To be able to visit this beautiful country and explore the good work these social practice artists are doing in their communities is more than a dream come true - and it will remain just a dream without your support.

Let Me Break It Down

I have diligently explored funding options through my employer, our local and state arts agencies, and grants from various national funders, but any funding I would have qualified for has already closed for the fiscal year. So, I turn to you: my friends, my family, perfect strangers around the world.

The cost of this learning journey is $4,250, which includes:

  • round trip airfare from Miami to Havana
  • lodging & transportation for nine days
  • most meals & water
  • program activities & fees
  • Cuban Tourist Visa
  • honoraria to speakers
  • donations to NGO hosts
I added an additional $250 to this project budget to cover my round trip airfare from Nashville to Miami, which brings the total project budget to $4,500. I have not included extra meals or activities, photo film & development, or souvenirs in this budget.

With your support, I know I will reach my goal - but if for some reason I do not, I will still receive the funds I have raised. If there is an unmanageable amount of funds yet to be raised, I will request refunds for contributors. However, if I can arrange a payment plan with the trip organizers for the remaining amount, I will move forward with the project as planned.

The Payoff

Your contribution to this project will have a meaningful impact beyond my own professional and artistic development. Not only will there will be many opportunities for me to interact with social practice artists in Havana, but I will also be joined my more than 20 artists from around the world. I will certainly be learning from all of those around me, but I believe there will also be opportunities for me to share with my peers on the trip the great work I'm familiar with in my hometown of Nashville.

Similarly, I plan to incorporate my experiences on this journey and the new knowledge I gain into the free workshops I lead for community artists in Nashville. I aim to document as much as possible to share with my peers in the art community as well as my youth development colleagues at Oasis.

Any time I grow as a person, it only positively impacts the youth I interact with on a weekly basis. It is also my intention to share this experience with them and to model for them an attitude of motivation and resourcefulness, an unending curiosity for learning, and a great appreciation for the expertise and culture of others.

Lastly, you'll get cool stuff! I'm an artist, duh! Here are some of the fantastic perks I've created to celebrate your contribution and to share in this journey with you:

  • a personal, handwritten postcard mailed from Havana
  • several photo print options (framed & unframed)
  • fancy custom photo books with linen covers
  • special invitation-only reception for proposed exhibition
  • small group photo workshop with yours truly

It's (Not) All About The Benjamins

I get it. This isn't for everyone - for many reasons. So, if you're unable to make a financial contribution to this project, please consider helping me spread the word.

Forward an email I shared with you or simply repost my plea on Instagram (@abbywanders). You can also use the share tools right here on Indiegogo to choose your own social media poison.

No matter what, I appreciate that you've taken the time to read this far into my story. I will be an excellent steward of whatever you choose to gift me - your time or money - and I look forward to sharing this experience with you!

story:
Help us kick off our 3rd Year with a bang!

Can you believe that this February 21 will mark our 2nd Anniversary since opening our doors?  That we've made it this far is a testament to the incredible reception we've been given by you, our film and arts-loving community, and by the various partnering filmmakers, artists, poets, musicians, distributors, and community organizations who have made The Frida Cinema their home.
 
As we close out our second year, we are proud to celebrate:

     
  • Screenings of over 200 independent, foreign, documentary, classic, and short and feature films.

  • Fundraisers and awareness-building events for over twenty community non-profit and mission-driven organizations including the Jaqueline Bogue Foundation for Suicide Prevention, the Orange County Gay and Lesbian Center, Orange County Children's Therapeutic Arts Center, Rock and Roll Girl's Camp OC, Breath of Fire Latina Health Ensemble, the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, Orange Coast College Film Club, Henninger Elementary School, The Bicycle Tree, Media Arts Santa Ana, Sexual Assault Victims Services of Orange County, Santa Ana Public Library, and AmericCorps of Santa Ana.

  • Presentations of over a dozen art shows, curated by and featuring over 100 works from talented local artists, including an all-female artistas show curated by local artist Alicia Rojas in celebration of Women's History Month, and a collection of astonishing black-and-white Blading photographs curated by Jon Julio of Valo.

  • Being presented with the OC Weekly Reader's Choice Award for Best Indie Theatre in 2014, followed by the same award AND the Editor's Choice Award in 2015!

  • And of course, having the distinction of being Orange County's only independent, non-profit, Art House Cinema!
In 2016, we look forward to complementing our continually expanding programming by making long-overdue upgrades to our home on 4th Street, including both technical enhancements to our sound and projection systems, and a much-needed marquee sign to let people know they've arrived at Orange County's most buzzed-about indie art house.  Please joins us in this exciting next wave, and be an active part of our continued efforts in establishing The Frida Cinema as the premiere destination for cinephiles across Orange County and beyond.

Our perks make great stocking stuffers!  

...though we won't hold it against you if you keep them to yourself!

We've put together a ton of great perks for our donors!!  And we've partnered with Indiegogo so that we can get your free tickets and Memberships and punch cards and other goodies out to you as soon as you donate for you to package up and get them to your lucky film-loving friends and family in time for the Holidays!

The Impact

It's amazing how far the "Little Art House That Could" has come - but we've got a long way to go.  With movie theaters big and small closing in record numbers (including two in Orange County in the last three months alone...), staying ahead of indie cinema trends and releases; positioning ourselves as a major player in the independent cinema community so that we can have first access to more new releases our audiences want to see; connecting to more community organizations so that we can further serve our community; and providing a dynamic venue for live events and speaking engagements, are just some of our goals for 2016 and beyond that your support will help to ensure.

Two Screens, 700 Seats, Tall Building = $$$

We don't like the experience of sitting for two hours watching a film in a stuffy un-ventilated room, and we don't wish the experiences on our audiences either.  We are generous with our air-conditioning - the promise of good A/C is part of the experience of going to the movies! - but that comes at a considerable expense.  We don't mind telling you that The Frida Cinema is an incredibly expensive place to keep open. Beyond the expected expenses of rent and compensation for our hard-working managers, our electricity bill that runs at an average of $2,400 a month. Then there's studio licensing, insurance, maintenance - and yes, those two digital projectors that a major shift in film exhibition forced virtually all cinemas to have to acquire and install.  Beyond helping us bring to life many of the dreams we have for The Frida Cinema, your support will also help us continue to carry our day-to-day burden as we stick to our commitment to open our doors daily, bringing quality cinema and culturally enriching events to our audiences seven days a week. 

Help Us Spread the Word!

After you lend your support, brag about it!  Let people know you took an active role in keeping community art house cinema alive!  Inspire them to follow your lead, and to lend their support in ensuring The Frida Cinema continues to meet its mission daily: to Enrich, Connect, and Educate Communities through the Art of Cinema!

Thank you! LONG LIVE THE FRIDA CINEMA!

Thank you! LONG LIVE THE FRIDA CINEMA!

story:
CAST 

Morten Holst as David

Morten Holst - danish actor from movies like "Brotherhood", "A Royal Affair" has taken the lead part “Dust”. Morten Holst on IMDB

STORY 

David’s girlfriend MUMTAZ has died. She was a photographer by profession, working in the heartlands of central India. David is a German diplomat working in India since four years.

Still reeling from the loss, he travels to the city of her birth, a city that he has never visited before. Here, he seeks out DR. SHARDA, a cynical old man who could lead him to the place, buried in the interiors of the country, where Mumtaz last was.

A journey into the heart of the country leads David simultaneously into its past. A past, it turns out, that binds the Doctor and Mumtaz. Dr. Sharda is revealed to be the commander of a camp, training young boys in combat against the State. Mumtaz, documenting the Doctor's camp, had captured the brutalization of one of its young inmates KRISHNA, at the hands of his own peers.

Mumtaz's searching spirit is reflected in another female character, RADHA, a young nurse working as a surrogate mother, whose longing to be independent is a quietly cherished dream. Radha's appearance in the film is independent of the other stories.That is, until we realise that she too had once existed within the structures of violence, of which the Doctor and his army were an integral part.

Drawing together these narratives, the film creates a multificated picture of present day India, a society in the throes of change, struggling to break the shackles of its past and emerge into the future.

DIRECTOR'S STATEMENT 

DUST is as much a story about a place as it is about its characters. Both place and character are moulded by the process of transformation underway in Indian society today. Indore, the city of my birth, has changed rapidly over the last decade and its transformation is not unlike that of other small cities in India. Indore therefore provides an ideal setting for DUST.

In order to capture aspects of this ongoing transformation in its most authentic form, DUST will be shot on real locations in and around Indore, using minimal lighting and production design. The documentary style of shooting will also enable us to improvise scenes with actors and the inhabitants of the city.


Any story about transformation must necessarily grapple with the concept of time.

And a story about transformation in India must grapple with an even more complex experience of time. As one of the characters in the film points out:
... in our language (Hindi), both the past and the future go by the same name - Kal...

What kind of transformation is possible in a culture in which conceptions of past and future might be inextricably linked?

This is a question that excited me from the beginning. This conception of time informs the narrative structure of DUST. The past and future are intervowen seamlessly into the present, touching each other in their progress. As with life, where one cannot hold apart the present, the past, dream and memory from each other, so too is the movement between the different time layers of the film­they flow into each other, connecting naturally during the course of the film.

Doing so, the reality of the film provides room for the “contradictions” that surround us in India everyday: a highly modern society, yet never far away from its past, a country of many histories, existences, cultures, languages and constrasts, a land that exists simultaneously in different eras. 

INSPIRATION

The transformation in our society is being driven to a large extent by women. In my immediate environment, I am surrounded by strong women, whose ideas have not only influenced me to write DUST, but have also made me aware of a need to explore narrative structures that reflect women's experiences and perceptions.

One such effort is DUST. Although beginning with a traditional narrative (man seeking his lost love), DUST cracks open this conventional and exhausted narrative, enabling its female characters to emerge, not as heroines or goddesses or larger (or lesser) than life figures, but a as individuals steering through a complex and ever changing society. And like the world they inhabit, they too are ever changing, adaptable figures.

At the end of the film, Mumtaz, Radha and the other women characters in the film set off on a journey, their path stretching out into the unknown but illuminated by their desire for freedom. It is this movement of the female characters in my film that is the triumphant spirit of DUST.

Thus David's encounter with an ageing partriachal world turns into a narrative embodying a fresh hope: the hope that in these times of change, a new path forged by women in our society may present an alternative to the structures of violence perpetuated throughout times.

WHY CROWD-FUNDING?

DUST is a low budget film, but it is 80% financed. However, we're missing the last critical stretch which will allow us to produce this independent film, fully shot in India.

We've received money through a German Film Fund and the Film University Babelsberg will be supporting us with equipment and postproduction resources. Still, we need the 16.000$ to be able to get a professional crew and cast together, pay, feed and accomodate them during the month of our shoot! A happy team makes a great film! So this is exactly where your money will go to.

We will be ever so thankful!

THE TEAM

 

Udita Bhargava  DIRECTOR 

After studying Literature and Mass Communication in New Delhi, Udita worked as an assistant on numerous film productions and commercials including Slumdog Millionaire by Danny Boyle, Antichrist by Lars von Trier, The Migration by Mira Nair. Her short films have shown successfully at film festivals around the world. Imraan C/o Carrom Club won the 3Sat Award at the 60th Oberhausen Film Festival and was broadcast by 3SAT/ZDF, one of Germany's largest public broadcasters.

 

Titus Kreyenberg  PRODUCER

Titus Kreyenberg is the owner and head of unafilm. In 2014 unafilm was part of the Cannes official selection with its coproduction The Bridges of Sarajevo. In 2013 Heli by Amat Escalante was awarded the Best Director at the Cannes official competition. Its coproduction Our Grand Despair by Seyfi Teoman premiered in competition at the Berlinale 2011. Unafilm is an active member of ACE (Atelier du Cinema Européen), EAVE, AG DOK, the German and the European Film Academy.

 

Kishor Sawant  LINE PRODUCER 

Kishor Sawant was the Line Producer for Zoo Entertainment Pvt Ltd's multilingual film Court, which has won 18 International Film Awards including the Best Film in the Horizons category and the Lion Of The Future award at the 71st Venice International Film Festival and the 'Golden Lotus' at the National Film Awards of India 2015. Having begun with Marathi experimental theatre, he has a long history of working with independent film makers and has specialized in unearthing rare locations for film shoots. 

 

Sophie Ahrens STUDENT PRODUCER

Sophie Ahrens has completed several internships in film production companies, specializing in art house films and documentaries. Currently she is doing an M.A. in Film Production at the Film University Babelsberg KONRAD WOLF. Sophie's portfolio includes Nomaden (30 min, 2015) which was nominated for the German Short Film Award 2015 and the feature film Meteorstrasse ( 84 min, 2016) by Aline Fischer, which will open the Perspective Deutsches Kino section at the Berlinale 2016. 

 

Philipp Meise DOP

Philipp Meise is a Berlin-based cinematographer. He is interested in socially conscious and unusual films that are looking for a specific relation to a cinematic theme. Currently he is working on a five-part documentary about the Fusion Festival, one of the most important festivals of electronic music in Germany. He met Udita Bhargava at the HFF Konrad Wolf and together they have made their several short films. 

 

Olaf Voigtländer EDITOR

Editor Olaf Voigtländer studied media design and worked as an assistant editor before joining the Filmschool in Potsdam Babelsberg. He edited Udita’s short Documentary Imraan C/o Carrom Club for which he was nominated for the Filmplus Festival in Cologne in 2014. Now he is working for a documentary that features Joesph Beuys Life. The Film is directed by one of the most renowned German Directors Andres Veiel.

 

Alexandra Barkovskaya FILMMUSIC COMPOSER

Alexandra Barkovskaya has studied piano and composition at the Belarusian State Academy of Musik in Minsk and at the University of Arts in Berlin. Afterwards, she joined the Film and Television University KONRAD WOLF in Potsdam-Babelsberg to continue her studies in film composition. She currently works as a composer for film and stage as well as a pianist. Her arrangement of the Mascagni's Opera "Iris" will be performed in 2016 at the Neukoellner Oper in Berlin.


PERKS FOR OUR FUNDERS

We are very grateful for your support. We are confident that the film that we will make will move you, inspire you and maybe even show you India as you've never seen it before. We will do our best to make you feel proud of having been part of the campaign.

To thank you for your contributions, we've set up a list of rewards and incentives.


 


*Disclaimer- similar to actual product

PREVIOUS WORK 

IMRAAN, C / O Carrom Club 

Short Documentary, 14 min, 2014

Imraan, an 11 year old, looks after a 'Carrom Club' in Mumbai, where men of all ages gather to play carrom. A tiny glimpse into Imraan's life in the club.

Statement of the Jury, 3SAT Prize at the 60. International Short Film Festival Oberhausen:
Director Udita Bhargava reveals confidently framed insights into the environment of a Carrom Club in Mumbai. In this gambling den in a predominantly Muslim slum we meet men with diverse backgrounds as petty criminals who at first sight seem equally childlike and macho. This sub-culture, whose members behave like perpetrators as well as objects, revolves around its precocious operator Imraan. The stylistic confidence and sensual imagery of Barghava’s camera are equally inspiring.

A MOOD REEL OF DUST

                  
CONTACT 
dust.film.project@gmail.com
story_txt:
CAST 


Morten Holst as David

Morten Holst - danish actor from movies like "Brotherhood", "A Royal Affair" has taken the lead part  “Dust”. Morten Holst on IMDB







STORY 
David’s girlfriend MUMTAZ has died. She was a photographer by profession, working in the

heartlands of central India. David is a German diplomat working in India since four years.
Still reeling from the loss, he travels to the city of her birth, a city that he has never visited before.
  
  Here, he seeks out DR. SHARDA, a cynical old man who could lead him to the place, buried in the
  
  interiors of the country, where Mumtaz last was.  
A journey into the heart of the country leads David simultaneously into its past. A past, it turns out,
  
  that binds the Doctor and Mumtaz. Dr. Sharda is revealed to be the commander of a camp, training
  
  young boys in combat against the State. Mumtaz, documenting the Doctor's camp, had captured
  
  the brutalization of one of its young inmates KRISHNA, at the hands of his own peers.

Mumtaz's searching spirit is reflected in another female character, RADHA, a young nurse working as a surrogate mother, whose longing to be independent is a quietly cherished dream. Radha's appearance in the film is independent of the other stories.That is, until we realise that she too had once existed within the structures of violence, of which the Doctor and his army were an integral part.
Drawing together these narratives, the film creates a multificated picture of present day India, a society in the throes of change, struggling to break the shackles of its past and emerge into the future. 





 DIRECTOR'S STATEMENT  
DUST is as much a story about a place as it is about its characters. Both place and character are

moulded by the process of transformation underway in Indian society today. Indore, the city of my

birth, has changed rapidly over the last decade and its transformation is not unlike that of other

small cities in India. Indore therefore provides an ideal setting for DUST.
In order to capture aspects of this ongoing transformation in its most authentic form, DUST will be

shot on real locations in and around Indore, using minimal lighting and production design. The

documentary style of shooting will also enable us to improvise scenes with actors and the

inhabitants of the city.



Any story about transformation must necessarily grapple with the concept of time.

And a story about transformation in India must grapple with an even more complex experience of

time. As one of the characters in the film points out: 
... in our language (Hindi), both the past and the future go by the same name - Kal...
What kind of transformation is possible in a culture in which conceptions of past and future might be inextricably linked?
This is a question that excited me from the beginning. This conception of time informs the

narrative structure of DUST. The past and future are intervowen seamlessly into the present,

touching each other in their progress. As with life, where one cannot hold apart the present, the

past, dream and memory from each other, so too is the movement between the different time layers

of the film­they flow into each other, connecting naturally during the course of the film.

  Doing so, the reality of the film provides room for the “contradictions” that surround us in India

everyday: a highly modern society, yet never far away from its past, a country of many histories,

existences, cultures, languages and constrasts, a land that exists simultaneously in different eras. 








INSPIRATION
The transformation in our society is being driven to a large extent by women. In my immediate

environment, I am surrounded by strong women, whose ideas have not only influenced me to write

DUST, but have also made me aware of a need to explore narrative structures that reflect women's

experiences and perceptions.
One such effort is DUST. Although beginning with a traditional narrative (man seeking his lost

love), DUST cracks open this conventional and exhausted narrative, enabling its female

characters to emerge, not as heroines or goddesses or larger (or lesser) than life figures, but a as

individuals steering through a complex and ever changing society. And like the world they

inhabit, they too are ever changing, adaptable figures.
 At the end of the film, Mumtaz, Radha and the other women characters in the film set off on a

journey, their path stretching out into the unknown but illuminated by their desire for freedom. It is

this movement of the female characters in my film that is the triumphant spirit of DUST.
 Thus David's encounter with an ageing partriachal world turns into a narrative embodying a fresh

hope: the hope that in these times of change, a new path forged by women in our society may

present an alternative to the structures of violence perpetuated throughout times.





WHY CROWD-FUNDING?
DUST is a low budget film, but it is 80% financed. However, we're missing the last critical stretch which will allow us to produce this independent film, fully shot in India. 
We've received money through a German Film Fund and the Film University Babelsberg will be supporting us with equipment and postproduction resources.
  Still, we need the 16.000$ to be able to get a professional crew and cast together, pay, feed and accomodate them during the month of our shoot! A happy team makes a great film! So this is exactly where your money will go to.  
We will be ever so thankful!




THE TEAM

After studying Literature and Mass Communication in New Delhi, Udita worked as an assistant on numerous film productions and commercials including Slumdog Millionaire by Danny Boyle, Antichrist by Lars von Trier, The Migration by Mira Nair.
