Barbara, Bacara Resort & Spa, Canary Hotel, Montecito Inn, and San 
Ysidro Ranch.
ASHLEE WELLS JACKSON and LAURA WEETZIE WILSON. Known for their 
transformative photography for "The 4th Trimester Bodies Project," these
 two soulful gals are an inspiring addition to the MDW team! 
Risks and challenges
Our team includes professional, working filmmakers who have produced 
feature-length, award-winning films. We are aware of the unexpected 
challenges that can come up in movie-making and are taking every 
precaution to minimize potential roadblocks. 
Like all filmmakers, our ultimate goal is for the documentary to gain
 an audience, and for that one depends on finding a distribution 
partner. While our team has secured DVD and VOD distribution for other 
feature films, there is never any guarantee we will earn distribution 
for MDW. However, our passion for MDW is contagious. The stories of our 
Moms and Dads featured in MDW are inspiring, and we believe this project
 will attract a fabulous distribution partner. 
If after making the rounds on the festival circuit we do not find a 
distribution partner, we will self-distribute. Throughout the duration 
of this project, we will always maintain our true mission: to improve 
the lives of Mothers in the United States. We will never compromise our 
mission and always choose to collaborate with people and organizations 
that are as passionate about Moms as we are.

story:
Welcome, everyone and thank you for visiting out crowdfunding page for "The Intruder". A thrilling story about Joanna, a former soldier, lost in the darkest recesses of her own mind.

Let me tell you a little bit about the project, it's purpose and us!


Synopsis: A routine trip to the shop turns into a hellish nightmare for Joanna, as she is forced to battle the demons  occupying the darkest recesses of her mind.

"The Intruder" is a visual tale depicting the harrowing effects of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). Our goal is to shine a light on this serious issue that many people go through and are still scared to talk about. This is an issue present around us on a daily basis, living in the darkness. We believe that more awareness  should be made around PTSD and help those afflicted to speak about their experiences.

The film specifically explores the thought of being trapped inside your own mind.... and the consequences when that is a reality. We hope that you believe in our project as much as we do!

First things first....Meet the team....

We are privileged to have on board the creative talents of Peter Kane in the directors chair & Carly Street on writing and producing duties.

"I was drawn to the serious nature of the story and it's a subject matter that should be told on screen."    Peter Kane, Director

Peter is an award winning film director whose feature film "The Gamekeeper" won best film at the Madhouse Film Festival. The film also won the Audience award at the London Digital Film Festival as well as being official selection at several other festivals.

The script was written by award winning screenwriter Carly Street whose last short script, "Fragile Storm" starring Lance Henricksen (Aliens, Millennium) has won numerous awards on its festival run.

"It's an important topic which people need to understand is ok to talk about. There are too many people suffering in silence and it's disgusting that society continues to ignore the cries of help from the families of those affected.Hopefully we can shine a light on it and create a discussion to highlight support out there"  Carly Street, Screenwriter

We share the same passion for exploring delicate topics and real struggles and through the use of storytelling, we want to have a positive impact on society with this endearing short film.  


What's so different about this?


There are a lot of people trying to raise the profile of this topic currently, so what makes this project stand out? What's its unique selling point? 
PTSD sufferers in the media are generally depicted as male former servicemen. The reason for this is because finally, a dialogue about PTSD affecting soldiers due to the horrors they are forced to endure as part of their service, has been gaining voices. Whilst this is very true and what most people are rightly trying to bring awareness too, we want to shift our focus ever so slightly to highlight the effects of PTSD on the everyday men, women and children who are also affected, as well as our service man and women. 
They could be doctors, soldiers, police officers, teachers, parents. 
Every day ordinary people doing every day and ordinary things. 
This short will snapshot the ongoing cycle of PTSD for ALL of those people.

What's the money for?


We want to be as transparent as possible so you can see exactly where your donation is going. 


- Location fees - This will be filmed in an around the local area (UK)  It costs money to procure a location so we have included this in our budget.

- Actors' expenses -  As with any profession, the talent are going to get paid their fair rate and we've included an estimate for that in  our budget.

- Music composer - We want to hire a music composer to set the tone with music that helps tell the story.

- Colourist - We plan to be at as many festivals as possible so we need to ensure good post-production team members. This person helps to ensure the colour of each frame is perfect to help enhance the story and we've included this in our budget.

- Props & set design - This cost ensure our sets match the story tone including wardrobe, make up and props. 

- Film festivals (fees/etc) - Upon completion we will be entering the film festival market. Costs for this include fees for the festival, lodging, transportation and other expenses.

Each cost factored in is pivotal to accurately depicting the conflict within Joanna's mind and therefore exploring her story.

   Below is a chart depicting of the £4000 where the funds will be going.




As you can see, post production is a smaller colour. This is because we are dedicating this initial campaign  towards the filming to ensure we have the highest possible quality.

This is a phase one campaign. Once we have the footage, we will launch a secondary campaign which will be dedicated to festival entry and showing as well as post production essentials. This is an inDemand campaign because the more we raise, the more chance we don't have to launch a secondary campaign!


It's not just about donating though!


Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean that you can't help.

The main goal behind this film is to raise awareness about the subject matter. We want this film to create a discussion, to be a talking point. 


               So if you can't donate, please, please, please SHARE this page! 

                Share our facebook page and make some noise about PTSD! 

                                 www.facebook.com/TheIntruderShort


We will be providing links and working with charities to assist anyone who is affected by PTSD. It can happen to anyone at any time and is a silent killer. 

We need to give those affected a voice and a place to seek help and support so it's so important that we get the message out and the discussion started.

Any questions?

We believe in building a genuine film community so if you want to ask any questions or talk about the project please feel free to get in touch! 

Just scan the messenger code below or mosey on down to Facebook!

We are all so passionate about this subject matter, we will not go quietly into the night!

story:
Hey Given Circumstances fans, far and near! At last, there are some super exciting developments surrounding GIVEN CIRCUMSTANCES....

First, let me introduce myself, as well as some of the team members who've  been working tirelessly (since early 2015) to turn this screenplay into a film. I'm Patrice Logan, a professional photographer from JPCML Photography LLC.

As Executive Producer of GIVEN CIRCUMSTANCES, written by Reid Martin Basso of Three Doves Media, LLC, I'm so excited to be bringing this awesome drama to the screen.

With such a large crew, I can’t introduce everyone at this time, but the film's key executives are set...

Directing GIVEN CIRCUMSTANCES is Nicole 'Nic' Simmons from Eleven21 Media. The California shooting/editing power duo of Raoul Torresi (Cinematographer) & Raul Perez (Editor) will handle visuals on both the front and back ends of production.

 The cast is set and ready to put on their best act.

Additionally, electronic music composer Sidney Maestre, Jr. and lyricist Reid Martin Basso, the 1990s California underground duo known as DETSKY MIR, 90s underground new wavers, are reuniting to provide some of the sound tracking!

We will be sure to keep the social media buzz up! Thank you Facebook fans for hanging tight amidst all of the... GIVEN CIRCUMSTANCES

Onward!

Patrice

PLOT

Reluctant husband Lance and childless wife Laura have been unsuccessful in starting a family. They eventually take on fertility specialist, Dr. Jun, to unravel the mystery. Laura embraces extreme measures to try to become pregnant, but Lance is revealed as having secretly embraced extremes of his own.

Your Investment & Return 

Our goals are to enter into film festivals and distribute to network channels exclusively for short films.  But in order for us to reach that goal, we need to raise money to pay for everything. We have a budget of $6,000 that helps with equipment rental fees, props, production travel expenses and much more.

Onto the perks for becoming a supporter. There are many different tiers to fit the supporter you would like to become.  Mug and T-shirt designs are still in the works, but we will surely keep you posted every step of the way.

The Impact

Given Circumstances is an unconventional story that impedes on an unspoken topic.  Not only does it spark a conversation, some of our cast members have a deeper connection and understand why it's a story that needs to be told.

"The storyline hit close to home for me because I have an aunt and uncle who struggled with infertility. Eventually they separated because there was a lot of pain in their relationship, caused in part by the lack of being able to have children. I think this project is special because it's very real and possible in lives today."

Risks & Challenges

Independent films are made possible by supporters like you! Low budget films deal with many more challenges than high budget films.  We have shorter schedules which in return gives us less time for production days and a smaller crew which means people wear more hats. The majority of low budget films run on contributions and supporters. So if we are not able to achieve certain goals it means we have to scale back in certain departments. HOWEVER, we will stay optimistic that we will achieve our goals.

SHARE! SHARE! And SHARE some more!

It's okay if you can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help in another way:

  • Ask friends and family to help get the word out to keep the buzz going about this awesome film.
  • Indiegogo even has share tools to make it easier!

 Start a conversation with us! If you have questions, ask. We'll be here!

story:
The Awakening

  Thanks for checking out my campaign!  My name is Tom and I'm the owner of T Mac Imaging.  I have been a photographer and videographer in the metro Detroit area for about 6 years.  I've done mostly lifestyle, landscape, and local band pictures along with a few music and lyric videos.  I've also done camera work for some local short films.

  Recently, I had an idea for my first short film.  After writing a rough draft of the screenplay I shared it with a few friends of mine that are involved in filmmaking.  They all said it would be a great festival entry and asked if they could have a role.  That settled it for me!

  As a child I used to take my father's 8mm movie camera and direct my friends through made up scenes without any film.  Many stories have come and gone over the years, but none have moved me to the point of needing to shoot it until now.  The Awakening is actually the first project I've written that's made it beyond my word processor.

Let's Cut to the Chase

  We both know why I'm here. I'm asking you to donate funds to help me make this short film.  Being self employed in a highly over saturated market makes it tough to make ends meet.  I rarely have “spare” cash, let alone enough to make a movie without help.  Don't think you won't get anything for your donations though, I've got some special perks planned to make it fun and worthwhile for everyone involved!

  To bring my vision of this movie to life, I've set a goal of $2000.  Quite an amount for a short, but I have a vision that I want to stay true to.  The funds will go towards location scouting, rental of locations (if needed), shooting permits where required, rental of lighting and effects equipment, an original score, some of the perks, and of course to pay for the feeding and care of the cast and crew.

  Now before I ask you to hand over your hard earned dough, I'm going to give you a little more insight into the meat of my project.  The Awakening is a short film that falls into the horror/thriller genre, similar to an episode of The Twilight Zone.  In its 5 minute running time, I hope it will shock and entertain the audience as well as make a poignant comment on modern society.

  Now for what you get if you donate!  Feel free to donate any amount and I'll give you a personal thanks both on this page and the facebook page I plan on creating for this project.  Let me break down the “perks” for you.

•  $10 Social Media Blitz: a shout out on ALL the social media sites for the project

•  $20 Download: a digital download of the finished project plus the SMB

•  $50 DVD: disk copy of the movie plus SMB

•  $75 Extra: be an extra in the movie and get a special surprise!

•  $100 Limited Edition: a limited edition poster signed by the cast plus the DVD perk

•  $200 Producer: a producer credit plus the Limited Edition

•  $500 Executive Producer: an executive producer credit plus the Limited Edition

•  $1000 Savior: Executive Producer plus Red Carpet treatment at the premiere

  The more money we collect, the better we can make the finished product look and sound.  Even if we don't reach the goal, we'll make the movie and the perks that have been earned will go out, but the quality of the project and the perks won't be as high.  If we surpass the goal, extra perks may be added to each level depending on how much over we go, as well as ensuring the best quality movie we can make.  Also, the more money we raise, the more festivals we can enter it in and more people will see it.

  I originally wanted to make this short for myself, just to be able to look at my 10 year old self and say, “Look at what we did!”  After having other, more experienced filmmakers review the script, I have since been convinced to make it a festival film.  Entry of a short film into a festival isn't costly, but you have to be there to represent your film, or any awards will be forfeit.  That means ticket(s) to the festival, transportation, lodging, food, and other expenses. 

  I'm hoping this movie, short as it is, will have quite an impact on people and make them reconsider how their lives are being lived.  We all see the problem I'm trying to bring to light.  Heck, many of us are even guilty of behaving like this.  I know I am.

  Once you see the final movie, I hope it'll awaken in you an awareness of the world you didn't have before.

  Even if you can't donate, you can still help!  Share the campaign on all of your social media accounts.  Then do it again.  The more people we reach, the more donors we reach!  Go talk us up everywhere you can.  Help us reach our goal and beyond!

story:
Since the question came up plenty of times:

Here you can find a Dollar => Euro Converter.


What is About Wings?

I’m Robin, a tea addict, travelling through Europe in my van, Hermes. Well, recently my boyfriend has joined in in Spain.

We document our journey with the video series “About Wings” and aim to inspire others to go on their own adventures.

And so far, we have been successful: Besides the amazing emails from fans, we also got attention from well known Youtubers and even BBC World.


Why do we need Your Help?

But now we ran into a new challenge:

Hermes doesn’t have proper ventilation, which leads to mould. Also, he is simply too small for TWO people and you can’t cook inside. I'm afraid it is soon time to give Hermes some rest from all the travelling and get a new, bigger van.

Working hard, I now have more money on my account than ever before. But we are still far from reaching what we need for our new van-home... And proper vans are not cheap in Europe.

I started this crowdfunding campaign in hope for your wish for About Wings not to end, just as it has started.



What's in for You?

I have produced the series for - let’s be fair, pretty much for free - and I want to keep it this way. After all, I can see how much it benefits my audience. Season ONE is completely filmed and I am currently releasing Episodes on a weekly basis.

If you would enjoy to see Season TWO, we will need a new van.


And You can Help!

Whether it is 500€ or as simple as 10€, your donation makes our next adventure possible and brings it right to your homely screen!

I know we aren't too big of a crowd yet, but I also know that every single one of you can make one hell of a difference in your’s, as well as in other people's lives!



So, please share this message, give some money and we will finally move on towards North, by May!


Thank you all so much!
Robin

I started this crowdfunding campaign in hope for your wish for About Wings not to end, just as it has started.What's in for You?

I have produced the series for - let’s be fair, pretty much for free - and I want to keep it this way. After all, I can see how much it benefits my audience. Season ONE is completely filmed and I am currently releasing Episodes on a weekly basis.

If you would enjoy to see Season TWO, we will need a new van. And You can Help!Whether it is 500€ or as simple as 10€, your donation makes our next adventure possible and brings it right to your homely screen!

I know we aren't too big of a crowd yet, but I also know that every single one of you can make one hell of a difference in your’s, as well as in other people's lives!


So, please share this message, give some money and we will finally move on towards North, by May!Thank you all so much!Robin

story:
Hello,
My name is Anna Engel, and along with my partner, Macyn Elquist,we are trying to start a film production studio, E2 Productions. We recently just started our first project, but we have already encountered our first obstacle. We have absolutely no equipment for filming. Since we are a new business, it is cheaper for us to purchase our own equipment.

Some of the equipment we would be buying includes a camera, audio equipment, lighting equipment, and camera supports. We do have a couple months before production begins, but we do need this equipment by the end of March so we can begin to shoot some preliminary scenes of our first film.

We are about to head into pre-production of our very first film, Calling All Dakota's. This film, centered around a writer who is the victim of relentless bullying, demonstrates the hardships of high school that people face, and all the help you can provide us will not only jump start our business, but also our newest film that will bring awareness to a serious problem in high schools around the world. As part of our campaign, we are using some of the money for this project as well. 

Calling All Dakotas is a film, as previously stated, that highlights the impacts of bullying in all different forms. this movie, which provides a powerful message to all generations, has been selected to be shown at select high school as part of the anti-bullying campaign. Focusing on the characters of Dakota Bridgman and Britton Palma, this film traces how they respond to bullying in different ways.

I would like to say that this project and company mean so much to both myself and Macyn because both of us support the cause of anti-bullying and acceptance, which I feel needs to be spread throughout the world. If you choose to help us, we would be immensely grateful because not only would you be helping a growing company, but you would be helping in spreading the message of kindness. If you want to help us, but can't financially, spread the message of our campaign so we can get out message out into the world.

Thank you,

Anna Engel

story:
I am Joey Ashbridge and I filmed a documentary called "Who Am I?" about adoption and adoptee rights.
Together, with Eric Thompson, we would like to shed some light on handicapped accessibility as well as follow Eric's story as he tries to get back on the river.  We will create a documentary that follows Eric's story.
Eric was a professional raft guide and adventure sports athlete before his injury. He guided one of the top 10 rivers in the world!
Then in 2012 his vehicle slid on ice and off of the road leaving him paralyzed.
Even without the use of his legs and 2/3 of his body, he can ski and mountain bike using special equipment.
Unfortunately he can no longer guide a boat on big whitewater because he cannot flip a raft back over if it capsizes.
This year Eric has renewed hope because of the team at Creature Craft!! A Creature Craft is a special raft that cannot capsize, but it can end up on it's side. If Eric can right the craft using his upper body strength he can get back on the river again!!!
This is a powerful story that will show disabled and able-bodied people alike that nothing is impossible!!
Eric has also started WVOnTheGo, which is a campaign to promote ADA accessibility and adaptive adventure sports in West Virginia and around the world.
By helping this film get made you will be helping to show the need for handicap accessibility and show others that, in Eric's words..."It doesn't mean you can't do things...it means you just have to find other ways to do them."

What We Need & What You Get

In order to capture Eric and his attempt to do everything he needs to do to guide a creature craft we will need several GoPro Hero 3 or Hero 4 video cameras and at least two cameramen on shore. Right now our equipment is minimal. We would also like to compensate the cameramen and safety boaters we will need.

If you donate $15 or more you will get your name in the end credits of the film and a ticket to the premiere of the film! There will be two locations. One in WV and one in Ohio.

If you donate $30 or more you will get your name in the end credits of the film. a ticket to the premiere of the film, and a WVonthego T shirt!

If you donate $50 or more you will get your name in the end credits of the film. 2 tickets to the premiere of the film, and a WVonthego T shirt, and dinner with Eric and the filmmakers.

If you donate $150 or more you will get your name in the end credits of the film. a ticket to the premiere of the film, and a WVonthego T shirt, dinner with Eric and the filmmakers, and one seat in a raft on the same trip with Eric when he makes his first attempt at guiding a Creature Craft!!

Even if our goal is not reached the funds will go toward the needed equipment and we will find ways to make up the rest!

    The Impact

    I believe Eric's story must be told because I have taken handicapped people down the river personally, including a woman whose legs were removed below the knees.

    At first I was really worried because it took so much effort to get her down to the raft. Accessibility even at the National Parks is sketchy.
    My apprehension soon disappeared when my guest asked if she could get out of the raft and swim. Suddenly she was no longer handicapped!!! She could swim freely just like anyone else. She swam with her family and had no need for the chair!

    There are so many people out there like her. Eric's cause is to make it easier for them to enjoy the things we love.

    When I look at some of the facilities and attractions in the adventure sports industry I see the need for improvement.

    I also see the need in Eric to get back on the waters he loves!! He is a role model for the disabled and non-disabled alike. When he pulls this off he will be a legend in the whitewater world and in the disabled world.

      Risks & Challenges

      The biggest challenge in this project is whether Eric can right the Creature Craft when it is on it's side.

      I have faith in Eric and his abilities and determination! You should too!

        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you cannot help with a donation please share this campaign via Facebook, Twitter, Google+, and any other way you can!

story:
Hi, Everyone!

We're the team of Inside The Woods, a new sitcom pilot produced entirely by Northwestern students and generously supported by Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Brad Hall. 

Inside the Woods is the story of two porn star parents, lovable icon Rick Wood and award-winning actress Natasha Wood, who move their youngest children Alfie and Valeria to the idyllic suburb of Greenfield, Illinois to begin new lives outside of the adult film industry. Despite their best efforts, this family can't seem to shake the chaos of their old lives. In fact, they pack it all in boxes and bring it with them to their new house.  Alfie, our story's protagonist, is a teenage boy who just wants something a little more stable. The family's move also interrupts the pristine life of their politically ambitious, eldest son, Wilson, an established resident of Greenfield who is ashamed of the life and family he left behind some years ago. 

Here's what happens:

-Alfie tries to make new (and hopefully permanent) friends while Valeria shakes up the town by wearing a surprising outfit.

-Rick and Natasha find themselves in a mess when Natasha vows to get a job at the local high school.

-Wilson tries to woo the town's hottest family values group to gain political support in an election, but his wife, Gracie, points out some problems with his goals.

This is a story about family, love, and learning how to accept yourself and others.We're so excited to share it with you.

But we need your help.

We're here because a sitcom requires many things to come together: You need funny writers, a talented crew, and money. We have two of these things covered, but we need your help with the third.

We've been working on this project for over a year. With your help, we'll be able to see it through.

Let's break it down.

Here's where your generosity is going:

Risks & Challenges

Ambitious projects don't come without their challenges. Here's how we'll handle ours.

1. Shooting a 30 min project in 2 weekends, whereas most people do a  10-15 min project in that amount of time

     How we'll beat it: We have a strict shooting schedule, and an experienced crew. We have been rehearsing for a while now. We have re-written the script to make production as seamless as possible for everyone involved.

2. Paying Actors, Heavy Production Design

How we'll beat it: We have a seriously detailed budget, and have a realistic fundraising goal for this campaign. With your help, our sets will look fantastic, and our actors will be paid.

Other ways you can help:

The best way to help is by spreading the love! If you'd be kind enough to direct anyone and everyone to our Indiegogo page, we'd sincerely appreciate it.

All in all, you're amazing. 

We think you're going to love Inside the Woods- it's a fantastic script led by a talented, passionate team. We can't thank you enough for supporting us!

story:
The campaign is over, but you can still support A Life's Work by going to the New York Foundation for the Arts' sponsorship page.

Eleven years ago I committed to making a documentary about people working on projects they won’t see completed in their lifetimes, projects that could have a profound, positive global impact. Ten years ago we started shooting A Life’s Work with an eye towards theatrical screenings and television broadcast. Today, A Life’s Work is nearing the finish line and I’m asking for your support to complete the film and get it out into the world!

Production resulted in gorgeous footage and insightful interviews. Editing was time consuming and meticulous, but it paid off. Now I want to make sure that I can hire top-notch people for sound editing, mixing, scoring, color correcting, and finishing so that A Life’s Work will be the best it can be. 

What’s it like to dedicate your life to work that won’t be completed in your lifetime?

To find out, I focused on four projects and the people behind them. The subjects are: 

Paolo Soleri, the recently deceased architect behind Arcosanti, a complex based on his theories of urban planning that has been under construction since 1970, and his successor, Jeff Stein, AIA. 


Jill Tarter, astronomer and Director of the SETI Institute, who has been involved in the scientific search for extraterrestrial intelligence since the 1970s and who was the basis for the Ellie Arroway character in Carl Sagan’s science fiction novel, Contact.

David and Jared Milarch, father and son tree farmers and co-founders of the Champion Tree Project (recently renamed Archangel Ancient Tree Archive), who clone old-growth trees for long-term reforestation projects.

Robert Darden, a gospel music archivist and journalism professor at Baylor University who founded the Black Gospel Music Restoration Project, an organization that is trying to identify, preserve, digitize, and catalog all of the most at-risk recordings from the black gospel music tradition. 
 

We discover what inspired them to begin, what obstacles they face, what drives and sustains them, how they measure success of an endeavor they will not live to see completed. But most of all we discover that their lives really aren’t that different from everyone else’s: who hasn’t gazed at the stars and wondered if we are unique, nurtured botanicals, sought ideal shelter, fell in love with a song and exposed someone to it? And who among us will truly see our work finished before we leave this mortal coil? The film is an examination of the nature of service to a cause greater than oneself, a contemplation on passion, devotion, continuity, and legacy. In an ADHD, soundbite world, A Life’s Work invites you to slow down and consider the value of taking the long view.

  • Reach millions through theatrical screenings, television broadcast, and online distribution;
  • Reveal the value of, and necessity for, long-term thinking;
  • Reveal through the life of the subjects what it means to devote a life to something beyond “self,” or as Robert Darden says in the film, to be "caught up in something a lot bigger than themselves”;
  • Inspire people to investigate the subjects' work;
  • Inspire people to consider what their legacy will be, and consider how that legacy can be the most positive it can be. 
I know reaching these goals won't be a walk in the park, but I've had support from amazing people thus far, people who are among the best at what they do.

 If the monetary goal of $30,000 is met, the film will be completed in early 2017. If the stretch goal of $35,000 is met, the percentage taken by IndieGoGo and NYFA will be taken care of. If the superstretch goal of $40,000 is met, it will pay for an editor to make a  60-minute cut for television broadcast. If the superduperstretch goal of $45,000 is met, the composer will be paid a fair rate. If the superduperSUPER stretch goal of $50,000 is met, it will pay for E&O (Errors & Omissions) insurance and the  the ALW crowd funding team. 
Distribution of funds, $30,000 goal met.

Distribution of funds, SuperEnormo stretch goal of $50,000 met.



You (Supporter) are a patron of the arts and believe there’s a place in this world for an independent, thoughtful documentary. Without you, there is no A Life's Work. You are awesome and your support makes you a vital part of A Life’s Work. 

(Excuse me while I go third person for a bit)

David Licata (Director-Producer) is a filmmaker and writer. His film Tango Octogenario was broadcast on Reel New York (PBS) and screened at festivals internationally, including New Directors/New Films (curated by the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center), the Tribeca Film Festival, and dozens of others from Yokahama to Krakow. He was Second Unit DP on Roland Tec’s We Pedal Uphill and DP for Tec’s Larry Stanton Project, a documentary in production featuring David Hockney. David received grants from the New York State Council on the Arts, The Yip Harburg Foundation, and Dance Films Association and fellowships from the MacDowell Colony, The Ucross Foundation, Blue Mountain Center, VCCA, Jentel Arts, Fundacion Valparaiso, and Centrum Creative Arts.

David’s writing has appeared in The Literary Review, Pilgrimage, R.KV.R.Y. Quarterly Literary Journal, Hitotoki, Word Riot, Sole Literary Journal, New Purlieu Review, Boston Literary Magazine, and others. He has written for ESPN, contributed articles and conducted interviews for Filmmaker Magazine, and film reviews for the film compendiums The Blockbuster Video Guide to Movies & Videos and Seen That, Now What?

David’s day job is at Columbia University’s School of Social Work, where he shoots and edits videos and produces podcasts. He loves his job and the people he works with. 

Andy Bowley (Cinematography) is a New York-based cinematographer who has shot commercials, features, and documentaries for the last 20 years. He has traveled to conflict areas all over the world, including Bosnia, Ingushetia, Sudan, and Afghanistan, where he shot an Emmy-winning Nickelodeon News documentary with correspondent Linda Ellerbee. He received a Peabody award for his work on Voices of Civil Rights, a History Channel project documenting everyday struggles and triumphs of participants in the civil rights movement.

Wolfgang Held (Cinematographer) is an Emmy award-winning cinematographer (Carrier) whose documentary work includes Bruno, Children Underground (Academy Award nominee), Particle Fever, Metallica: Some Kind of Monster, Years of Living Dangerously, Half the Sky and many others. He has worked with legendary documentarians D.A. Pennebaker and Maysles Film. A Life's Work is the second collaboration between the director and cinematographer.

Additional cinematography by Robert Featherstone and Thomas Harding, CSC. 

Cabot Philbrick (Editor) is a New York-based editor. He edited and co-produced the documentary Other People’s Pictures, which won best documentary awards at the New Orleans Film Festival, the Coney Island Film Festival, and the Ozone Film Festival and is in distribution with the Cinema Guild. The film features colorful obsessives who collect other people’s cast-off family photos and is set at New York City’s Chelsea Flea Market.


A Life’s Work was inspired by two events. When I was nine years old or so I remember being told that medieval cathedrals took hundreds of years to construct, that their architects would not see them completed, that generations of stonemasons would work on them, and this bit of information made quite an impression on my young mind. To this day, whenever I see a cathedral, I become that awestruck nine-year-old.

After completing my previous film, Tango Octogenario, I had decided I wanted to make a documentary. I had several ideas and was researching them. In September of 2004 my mother died after a lengthy battle with cancer. Sometime during the haze of my grief, this time of sorrow and contemplation about purpose and legacy, I thought about the cathedrals, and the idea for A Life’s Work was born.

You have enough t-shirts and mugs with text on them advertising something or other, don't you? You don't need some trinket with A Life's Work plastered on it, right? This is one reason why most of the perks are digital! 

What you may not have are downloads of great, rare, music, terrific art, and a few films by me. By going digital A Life's Work will not encourage the pollution generated by toxic byproducts, will not be contributing to the waste produced from packing materials, will not be increasing the carbon footprint of the film, and will limit the taking down of trees just so I can ship out a poster which you probably won't ever hang.

Additional perks have been added but are of very limited quantity. Other perks to come, and some will be "unlocked" when certain goals are met so check in regularly.

NEW PERK: Polaroid Photos  (Analog!) of the Oldest Trees in the World

I took these when I shot the bristlecone pine trees in the White Mountains, CA. Only seven of these were taken, and one is already spoken for. Support of $70 and one can be yours.

Polaroid no longer makes film, but a company called the Impossible Project does. These were taken while IP was trying to perfect their film, hence the washed out colors and the brown splotches on them. These photos are very sensitive and will fade if they are exposed to even low levels of light. If you want to display them, speak to a framer about UV glass.

I can't stress how unique these are, especially in these days of digital photography.





 

A page from the coloring book, partially colored.



If you can't support A Life's Work monetarily, please consider telling your friends and family about the film via social network. Everyone knows at least one  film/media geek, why not forward this link to him or her. If they can't support the film monetarily, maybe learning about the film will inspire them to make a film. And maybe that film will be great.

A Life's Work is grateful to:

for an independent, thoughtful documentary. Without you, there is no A Life's Work. You are awesome and your support makes you a vital part of A Life’s Work. 

(Excuse me while I go third person for a bit)
David Licata (Director-Producer) is a filmmaker and writer.
His film Tango Octogenario was
broadcast on Reel New York (PBS) and
screened at festivals internationally, including New Directors/New Films (curated by the Museum of Modern Art and the
Film Society of Lincoln Center), the Tribeca Film Festival, and dozens of
others from Yokahama to Krakow. He was Second Unit DP on Roland Tec’s We Pedal Uphill and DP for Tec’s Larry Stanton Project, a documentary in
production featuring David Hockney. David received grants from the New York
State Council on the Arts, The Yip Harburg Foundation, and Dance Films
Association and fellowships from the MacDowell Colony, The Ucross Foundation,
Blue Mountain Center, VCCA, Jentel Arts, Fundacion Valparaiso, and Centrum
Creative Arts. 
David’s writing has appeared
in The Literary Review, Pilgrimage, R.KV.R.Y. Quarterly
Literary Journal, Hitotoki, Word Riot, Sole Literary Journal, New Purlieu
Review, Boston Literary Magazine, and others. He has written for ESPN,
contributed articles and conducted interviews for Filmmaker Magazine, and film reviews for the film compendiums The Blockbuster Video Guide to Movies &
Videos and Seen That, Now What? 
David’s day job is at Columbia University’s School of Social
Work, where he shoots and edits videos and produces podcasts. He loves his job and the people he works with. 


Andy Bowley (Cinematography) is a New York-based cinematographer who has shot commercials, features, and documentaries for the last 20 years. He has traveled to conflict areas all over the world, including Bosnia, Ingushetia, Sudan, and Afghanistan, where he shot an Emmy-winning Nickelodeon News documentary with correspondent Linda Ellerbee. He received a Peabody award for his work on Voices of Civil Rights, a History Channel project documenting everyday struggles and triumphs of participants in the civil rights movement.



Wolfgang Held (Cinematographer) is an Emmy award-winning
cinematographer (Carrier) whose
documentary work includes Bruno,
Children Underground (Academy Award nominee), Particle Fever, Metallica:
Some Kind of Monster, Years of Living Dangerously, Half the Sky and many
others. He has worked with legendary documentarians D.A. Pennebaker and Maysles
Film. A Life's Work is the second
collaboration between the director and cinematographer.

Additional cinematography by Robert Featherstone and Thomas Harding, CSC. 
Cabot
Philbrick (Editor) is a New York-based editor. He edited and co-produced the documentary Other People’s Pictures, which won best
documentary awards at the New Orleans Film Festival, the Coney Island Film
Festival, and the Ozone Film Festival and is in distribution with the Cinema
Guild. The film features colorful obsessives who collect other people’s
cast-off family photos and is set at New York City’s Chelsea Flea Market.




A Life’s Work was inspired by two events. When I was nine years old or so I remember being told that medieval cathedrals took hundreds of years to construct, that their architects would not see them completed, that generations of stonemasons would work on them, and this bit of information made quite an impression on my young mind. To this day, whenever I see a cathedral, I become that awestruck nine-year-old.
After completing my previous film, Tango Octogenario, I had decided I wanted to make a documentary. I had several ideas and was researching them. In September of 2004 my mother died after a lengthy battle with cancer. Sometime during the haze of my grief, this time of sorrow and contemplation about purpose and legacy, I thought about the cathedrals, and the idea for A Life’s Work was born.




You have enough t-shirts and mugs with text on them advertising something or other, don't you? You don't need some trinket with A Life's Work plastered on it, right? This is one reason why most of the perks are digital! 

What you may not have are downloads of great, rare, music, terrific art, and a few films by me. By going digital A Life's Work will not encourage the pollution generated by toxic byproducts, will not be contributing to the waste produced from packing materials, will not be increasing the carbon footprint of the film, and will limit the taking down of trees just so I can ship out a poster which you probably won't ever hang.
Additional perks have been added but are of very limited quantity. Other perks to come, and some will be "unlocked" when certain goals are met so check in regularly.
NEW PERK: Polaroid Photos  (Analog!) of the Oldest Trees in the World
I took these when I shot the bristlecone pine trees in the White Mountains, CA. Only seven of these were taken, and one is already spoken for. Support of $70 and one can be yours.
Polaroid no longer makes film, but a company called the Impossible Project does. These were taken while IP was trying to perfect their film, hence the washed out colors and the brown splotches on them. These photos are very sensitive and will fade if they are exposed to even low levels of light. If you want to display them, speak to a framer about UV glass.
I can't stress how unique these are, especially in these days of digital photography.








 
A page from the coloring book, partially colored.








If you can't support A Life's Work monetarily, please consider telling your friends and family about the film via social network. Everyone knows at least one  film/media geek, why not forward this link to him or her. If they can't support the film monetarily, maybe learning about the film will inspire them to make a film. And maybe that film will be great.



A Life's Work is grateful to:

story:
A LITTLE MORE ABOUT ME

Hi there, my name is Dominique LaFleur. I am the writer and producer of Concrete. I’ve been an actress for many years now but even before that I was a writer. My earliest works date back to age 13 and they consist of poetry, short stories and over 30 unproduced screenplays. All of which star women as the protagonist and heroin of each amazing adventure. I’ve always loved writing. I also have a love for the human language, whether it is verbal or physical I love observing the art of communication between people. This is why my love of writing also translated into a love of acting. My most recent work is the new film, The Congressman  and I am currently starring in a Haitian independent film, Free Will. For more on my acting check out my website.

   http://www.dominiquelafleur.com/

 When I’m not in front of the camera working, I’m behind it working as a staff at a boutique Haitian production company Saturn Visions Productions. I am trusted to be on duty doing anything from location scout, to script manager, to production manager and so on. Our first film which I also acted in entitled, Te Sauver a’ tout Prix, sold out to an amazing audience at its premier last year.

  https://youtu.be/I9ng-qG47Jo

 Another thing I am in love with is being a mother. Being a single mother to two beautiful baby boys definitely has its challenges but the rewards are insurmountable. Juggling two full-time jobs, an additional part time job, on top of that, acting, on top of that, writing, on top of that, the full-time job of being a parent gets crazy. But the ride amazing.

CONCRETE LONG SUMMARY 

Concrete is a dramatic coming of age about Angela, a street hardened, abandoned latch-key kid from Boston who suffers the loss of her loving father to prison and is sent to New York to live with her estranged grandmother, Grandma Mary. Growing up in urban America, Angela is exposed to senseless violence, gang activity, neighborhood quarrels and is subject to the influence of all the usual suspects.  As Angela grows into adulthood, Grandma Mary serves as a guiding light  and instills into Angela knowledge and principles of life that open her eyes to the awareness of a world beyond the one she exists in. Angela eventually grows up to become a conscious rapper, a prodigy of Grandma Mary. But when her father is released from prison and returns back into her life, his influence begins to threaten the integrity of everything she stands for. 

WHY YOUR CONTRIBUTION IS IMPORTANT

Your contributions are immensely important to Concrete.  Do me a favor and close your eyes for a second. Think about a single parent that you know. It might just be you. A staggering 80.5% of us are women doing it on our own with our children. Shout out to the 20% of men raising princes and princesses on their own also. I'm a hardworking single mother who is going to make a movie. I’m coming to you as Dom the filmmaker who needs your help with getting Concrete funded. Your donations would help this project come to life. You would be helping this unstoppable single mom-preneur accomplish her dreams by attaching industry professionals to Concrete that will in turn give you an industry quality film from the industry recommended equipment so we can shoot and deliver industry perfectionism from a great cast of actors.


HOW CONCRETE CAME TO BE

In another life I was a Mental Health Assistant at a residential placement. I worked with a lot of our youth. They were all other people’s children. Some parents just wanted to get rid of their kids and others were hopeful parents who sent their children off for behavioral treatment. A lot of the children I worked with came from deplorable backgrounds with heartbreaking stories.

These young children had the experience equal to that of an adult but lacked the wisdom that age brings us all as we are coming of age. As you can imagine their stories were drenched with pain, suffering, sexual and physical abuse, neglect, malnutrition and they were uneducated. Many of our Sophomore, Junior and Senior-level American children had the equivalent of a third grader's reading level. With that said all of them were filled with a love of music and culture. They had enough rhythm to be one of Beyoncé or Justin Timberlake’s backup dancers. They had enough swag to keep up with the fastest lyrics recited by the hottest rappers.


They have so much talent and potential that they could develop but just did not see. No matter what beautiful setting you put them in or what half million dollar home they had the opportunity to live in with finally their own rooms and their own clothing in their own space all they wanted to do was go back home. Most of these kids came from a street life you and I would not want for our children.


Thankfully is foreign to mine. It always baffled me how they would want nothing more than to leave the comfort of these new environments and go right back to a life that would send them on a dead-end road back to a juvenile facility or prison  where a percentage of them came to us from. This fascination is what motivated me to write Concrete. I delved deep into a world that I thought I already knew and researched everything I could about our history in urban America, the mindset behind it and the history that contributed to the state that we live in. Everything was not perfect at the facility I worked at. I’ve been punched, kicked, spit on, slapped and have half a dozen scratches and bite marks on my body. Warrior scars that I share with hundreds of other  fellow staff members. But besides the scars, I share relationships with a lot of these former students that I worked with. I couldn’t help but to fall in love with your children. I couldn’t help but to care for them and occasionally break the rules and listen to their bleeding hearts which is something that the staff were discouraged to do. Even though I felt helpless in that situation, in this situation the best way I can help with my talent is to bring their stories to light by using Angela as a vessel in Concrete. We keep it intense with real dialogue and we keep it hot with original music. This film is dedicated to all of our American children who have been left behind but if I can help it, with your help, not forgotten.

WHAT WE NEED

$60,000

Is what we need in this early stage of production. This is just partial of the full budget of the film but it would help me secure important paperwork and people.  You know how much you hate he said she said battles? Yeah well I hate those also. You know those annoying contracts that weren’t really clear or maybe a paperwork or two is missing from an important document that you need? Doesn’t that just ruin your day? Well that would ruin my day also and I definitely don’t want that. Along with a long list of other reasons I definitely need an entertainment attorney and those aren’t cheap. Trust me as a single mom I know how to get great deals and clip coupons to bring that cost way down. But when it comes to an entertainment attorney, that is a fixed cost. Fees start well into the thousands and that’s just on a basic level. I also need a casting director who has access to some of your favorite actors. She will cost money and your favorite actors are used to getting paid a lot of money so this will go towards that also. I also need to secure someone to write a great business plan for Concrete just in case I don’t reach the full film budget I can totally roll up to any office in Hollywood with an ironclad business plan written by a professional that would rock the socks off of any executive and have them pulling out their checkbooks so fast just to provide the rest of the funding for Concrete.


Trust me we are offering you massive  incentives and rewards to contribute also. Remember it takes a village not just to raise a child but to raise funds for a film.

WITHOUT YOU

There is no Concrete. Hopefully by now you can definitely see the value in getting this film created and you’re down with it. Just $5- $10 from you goes a long way towards helping me reach my goal for Concrete. Sharing is incredibly caring. Just letting your friends, family, neighbors, strangers and anyone else you come across know is of great help to me. Indiegogo provides some great sharing tools that you can use to help spread the word as far and as often as you like. I implore you to use these tools in helping us. No amount is too great and no act is too small, so donate to Concrete today.

story:
Hey guys I am Paris Holmes, the writer, director and cinematographer of Synchroni City. 

What is Synchroni City about? A writer gets an opportunity to pitch his screenplay to a producer who becomes interested in reading his entire script but a missing flash drive and a nympho girlfriend stand in his way.

No sugar coating is necessary here. We're here to simply create a really good film project and we are in need of your help to achieve that. The actors I have on board are extremely gun hoe about the project and are working for free pretty much. They are dedicating their time to help me bring my script to screen. My actors are the most valuable players on my roster and I need them more than they need me so I want to make sure they are taken care of first.

Of course I can direct, shoot, handle the lighting & sound myself but it's best that I am able to bring on a small crew so that I can solely focus on directing. We're not looking to make a good film, we are trying to make a great film.

I want us all to benefit from this film so we will be submitting to a lot of film festivals which costs a lot. Not just the film festival itself but traveling out to the festivals that are in other states. 

I know you have your own things, rent, bills, internet, cable, parking tickets, friends who need to borrow money but if you support me or anybody who's apart of this film or you just love Independent Film, please donate to the film. Be apart of our project and be forever connected to us.


Paris Holmes IMDB

My Reel as a Cinematographer.


My first film award.


MAIN CAST

MICHAEL METTA AS LUKE


EMILY POLLIO AS DINA


BROOKE GUIDO AS MELANIE


ANDREA KELLY AS ALANNA
